positions.work: SEXUALITY IN THE AETIOLOGY OF THE NEUROSES

positions.title: No one ever becomes neurotic through work or excitement alone - intellectual work is rather a protection against neurasthenia
positions.text: No one ever becomes neurotic through work or excitement alone - intellectual work is rather a protection against neurasthenia
positions.work: SEXUALITY IN THE AETIOLOGY OF THE NEUROSES

positions.title: The most unremitting intellectual workers remain exempt from neurasthenia
positions.text: The most unremitting intellectual workers remain exempt from neurasthenia
positions.work: SEXUALITY IN THE AETIOLOGY OF THE NEUROSES

positions.title: Sexual aetiology makes it possible to understand all details of neurasthenic clinical history including mysterious improvements and incomprehensible deteriorations
positions.text: Sexual aetiology makes it possible to understand all details of neurasthenic clinical history including mysterious improvements and incomprehensible deteriorations
positions.work: SEXUALITY IN THE AETIOLOGY OF THE NEUROSES

positions.title: Removal from home in hydropathic treatment entails interruption of marital intercourse, making temporary elimination of pathogenic cause possible
positions.text: Removal from home in hydropathic treatment entails interruption of marital intercourse, making temporary elimination of pathogenic cause possible
positions.work: SEXUALITY IN THE AETIOLOGY OF THE NEUROSES

positions.title: With neurasthenia, therapeutic problems must be attacked within the framework of the patient's life, not in hydropathic institutions
positions.text: With neurasthenia, therapeutic problems must be attacked within the framework of the patient's life, not in hydropathic institutions
positions.work: SEXUALITY IN THE AETIOLOGY OF THE NEUROSES

positions.title: Masturbation is far commoner among grown-up girls and mature men than generally supposed and produces neurasthenic symptoms
positions.text: Masturbation is far commoner among grown-up girls and mature men than generally supposed and produces neurasthenic symptoms
positions.work: SEXUALITY IN THE AETIOLOGY OF THE NEUROSES

positions.title: Coitus interruptus practiced regularly produces neurotic symptoms
positions.text: Coitus interruptus practiced regularly produces neurotic symptoms
positions.work: SEXUALITY IN THE AETIOLOGY OF THE NEUROSES

positions.title: Natural intercourse during pregnancy provides a curative effect on neurosis
positions.text: Natural intercourse during pregnancy provides a curative effect on neurosis
positions.work: SEXUALITY IN THE AETIOLOGY OF THE NEUROSES

positions.title: Charcot was not a reflective thinker but an artist-scientist who was a 'visuel' - a man who sees
positions.text: Charcot was not a reflective thinker but an artist-scientist who was a 'visuel' - a man who sees

positions.title: Charcot's method was to look repeatedly at things he did not understand until suddenly understanding dawned - the apparent chaos gave way to order
positions.text: Charcot's method was to look repeatedly at things he did not understand until suddenly understanding dawned - the apparent chaos gave way to order

positions.title: Nosography - the intellectual work of seeing new nosological pictures emerge from apparent chaos - was Charcot's particular gift
positions.text: Nosography - the intellectual work of seeing new nosological pictures emerge from apparent chaos - was Charcot's particular gift

positions.title: The greatest satisfaction in science is to see something new - to recognize it as new
positions.text: The greatest satisfaction in science is to see something new - to recognize it as new

positions.title: Verbal malformations in dreams resemble those in paranoia, hysteria, and obsessions, sharing a common source with linguistic tricks performed by children
positions.text: Verbal malformations in dreams resemble those in paranoia, hysteria, and obsessions, sharing a common source with linguistic tricks performed by children

positions.title: Analysis of nonsensical verbal forms in dreams particularly exhibits the dream-work's achievements in condensation
positions.text: Analysis of nonsensical verbal forms in dreams particularly exhibits the dream-work's achievements in condensation

positions.title: Essential dream-thoughts completely replace the dream and would be sufficient in themselves to replace it if there were no censorship
positions.text: Essential dream-thoughts completely replace the dream and would be sufficient in themselves to replace it if there were no censorship

positions.title: Dream-thoughts emerge as a complex structure with all the attributes of trains of thought familiar in waking life, often starting from more than one centre
positions.text: Dream-thoughts emerge as a complex structure with all the attributes of trains of thought familiar in waking life, often starting from more than one centre

positions.title: Each train of dream-thought is almost invariably accompanied by its contradictory counterpart, linked by antithetical association
positions.text: Each train of dream-thought is almost invariably accompanied by its contradictory counterpart, linked by antithetical association

positions.title: Dreams have no means at their disposal for representing logical relations like 'if', 'because', 'either-or' between dream-thoughts
positions.text: Dreams have no means at their disposal for representing logical relations like 'if', 'because', 'either-or' between dream-thoughts

positions.title: Dreams disregard logical conjunctions and take over only the substantive content of dream-thoughts - restoration of connections is a task for interpretation
positions.text: Dreams disregard logical conjunctions and take over only the substantive content of dream-thoughts - restoration of connections is a task for interpretation

positions.title: The incapacity of dreams to express logical relations lies in the nature of the psychical material out of which dreams are made, similar to plastic arts compared to poetry
positions.text: The incapacity of dreams to express logical relations lies in the nature of the psychical material out of which dreams are made, similar to plastic arts compared to poetry

positions.title: Spoken sentences in dreams are unmodified or slightly modified reproductions of speeches found among recollections in dream-thoughts
positions.text: Spoken sentences in dreams are unmodified or slightly modified reproductions of speeches found among recollections in dream-thoughts

positions.title: Dreams reproduce logical connection by simultaneity in time, combining material into a single situation or event
positions.text: Dreams reproduce logical connection by simultaneity in time, combining material into a single situation or event

positions.title: When dreams show two elements close together, this guarantees some specially intimate connection between what corresponds to them among dream-thoughts
positions.text: When dreams show two elements close together, this guarantees some specially intimate connection between what corresponds to them among dream-thoughts

positions.title: Causal relations are represented in dreams by temporal sequence - either as a sequence of introductory and main dream, or by direct transformation of one image into another
positions.text: Causal relations are represented in dreams by temporal sequence - either as a sequence of introductory and main dream, or by direct transformation of one image into another

positions.title: The alternative 'either-or' cannot be expressed in dreams - both alternatives are usually inserted as though they were equally valid
positions.text: The alternative 'either-or' cannot be expressed in dreams - both alternatives are usually inserted as though they were equally valid

positions.title: In the great majority of cases, the causal relation is not represented at all but is lost in the confusion of elements in the dreaming process
positions.text: In the great majority of cases, the causal relation is not represented at all but is lost in the confusion of elements in the dreaming process

positions.title: The most complicated achievements of thought are possible without the assistance of consciousness, as proven by psychoanalysis of hysteria and obsessions
positions.text: The most complicated achievements of thought are possible without the assistance of consciousness, as proven by psychoanalysis of hysteria and obsessions

positions.title: Dream-thoughts may originate from the previous day, proceeding unobserved by consciousness and already completed at sleep onset
positions.text: Dream-thoughts may originate from the previous day, proceeding unobserved by consciousness and already completed at sleep onset

positions.title: Becoming conscious is connected with the application of attention, a function only available in a specific quantity
positions.text: Becoming conscious is connected with the application of attention, a function only available in a specific quantity

positions.title: Symbolism plays a part in dreams from the very first - dreamers have symbolism at their disposal from the earliest age
positions.text: Symbolism plays a part in dreams from the very first - dreamers have symbolism at their disposal from the earliest age

positions.title: Temporal repetition of an act is regularly shown in dreams by numerical multiplication of an object
positions.text: Temporal repetition of an act is regularly shown in dreams by numerical multiplication of an object

positions.title: Psychoanalytic research finds no fundamental but only quantitative distinctions between normal and neurotic life
positions.text: Psychoanalytic research finds no fundamental but only quantitative distinctions between normal and neurotic life

positions.title: Analysis of dreams shows complete identity in mechanisms and symbolism between healthy and sick individuals - repressed complexes operate alike in both
positions.text: Analysis of dreams shows complete identity in mechanisms and symbolism between healthy and sick individuals - repressed complexes operate alike in both

positions.title: Naive dreams of healthy people often contain simpler, more perspicuous and characteristic symbolism than those of neurotics
positions.text: Naive dreams of healthy people often contain simpler, more perspicuous and characteristic symbolism than those of neurotics

positions.title: In neurotic dreams, symbolism may be obscure and hard to interpret due to more powerful workings of censorship and more far-reaching dream-distortion
positions.text: In neurotic dreams, symbolism may be obscure and hard to interpret due to more powerful workings of censorship and more far-reaching dream-distortion

positions.title: Sexual flower symbolism occurs very commonly and symbolizes human sexual organs by blossoms, which are the sexual organs of plants
positions.text: Sexual flower symbolism occurs very commonly and symbolizes human sexual organs by blossoms, which are the sexual organs of plants

positions.title: Gifts of flowers between lovers may have unconscious sexual meaning representing exchange of sexual gifts
positions.text: Gifts of flowers between lovers may have unconscious sexual meaning representing exchange of sexual gifts

positions.title: Dreams can express thoughts of which the dreamer is scarcely aware in waking life, particularly thoughts concerned with sensual love and its organs
positions.text: Dreams can express thoughts of which the dreamer is scarcely aware in waking life, particularly thoughts concerned with sensual love and its organs

positions.title: The meaning of symbols and significance of dreams can be arrived at with particular ease from dreams of people uninitiated into psychoanalysis
positions.text: The meaning of symbols and significance of dreams can be arrived at with particular ease from dreams of people uninitiated into psychoanalysis

positions.title: Dreams can represent serious thoughts far removed from anything sexual by means of infantile sexual material
positions.text: Dreams can represent serious thoughts far removed from anything sexual by means of infantile sexual material

positions.title: In well-formed dreams there is nothing superfluous - every word is a symbol
positions.text: In well-formed dreams there is nothing superfluous - every word is a symbol

positions.title: The dream-work proper is not simply more careless or irrational than waking thought - it is completely different qualitatively and not immediately comparable with it
positions.text: The dream-work proper is not simply more careless or irrational than waking thought - it is completely different qualitatively and not immediately comparable with it

positions.title: The dream-work does not think, calculate or judge at all - it restricts itself to giving things a new form
positions.text: The dream-work does not think, calculate or judge at all - it restricts itself to giving things a new form

positions.title: The dream has above all to evade censorship, and the dream-work uses displacement of psychical intensities to the point of a transvaluation of all psychical values
positions.text: The dream has above all to evade censorship, and the dream-work uses displacement of psychical intensities to the point of a transvaluation of all psychical values

positions.title: Thoughts must be reproduced exclusively or predominantly in visual and acoustic memory-traces, imposing considerations of representability on the dream-work
positions.text: Thoughts must be reproduced exclusively or predominantly in visual and acoustic memory-traces, imposing considerations of representability on the dream-work

positions.title: Extensive condensation serves to produce greater intensities than are available in dream-thoughts at night
positions.text: Extensive condensation serves to produce greater intensities than are available in dream-thoughts at night

positions.title: Little attention is paid to logical relations between thoughts - those relations are given a disguised representation in certain formal characteristics of dreams
positions.text: Little attention is paid to logical relations between thoughts - those relations are given a disguised representation in certain formal characteristics of dreams

positions.title: Affects attached to dream-thoughts undergo less modification than their ideational content - affects are suppressed or detached from proper ideas
positions.text: Affects attached to dream-thoughts undergo less modification than their ideational content - affects are suppressed or detached from proper ideas

positions.title: Dreams are nothing other than a particular form of thinking made possible by conditions of the state of sleep - it is the dream-work which creates that form and is the essence of dreaming
positions.text: Dreams are nothing other than a particular form of thinking made possible by conditions of the state of sleep - it is the dream-work which creates that form and is the essence of dreaming

positions.title: Every dream contains the fulfillment of a wish - the dream was preferred to waking reflection because it could show the wished-for situation
positions.text: Every dream contains the fulfillment of a wish - the dream was preferred to waking reflection because it could show the wished-for situation

positions.title: For the sake of wish fulfillment, sleep can be prolonged by one moment - the dream shows what is wished for as still present
positions.text: For the sake of wish fulfillment, sleep can be prolonged by one moment - the dream shows what is wished for as still present

positions.title: Many analysts wrongly seek the essence of dreams in latent content, overlooking the distinction between latent dream-thoughts and dream-work
positions.text: Many analysts wrongly seek the essence of dreams in latent content, overlooking the distinction between latent dream-thoughts and dream-work

positions.title: The content of dreams must have been overdetermined - words spoken in dreams are made up of words actually spoken in lifetime connected with important events
positions.text: The content of dreams must have been overdetermined - words spoken in dreams are made up of words actually spoken in lifetime connected with important events

positions.title: Memory of dreams is not only fragmentary but positively inaccurate and falsified - we may fill in what was never there with new material
positions.text: Memory of dreams is not only fragmentary but positively inaccurate and falsified - we may fill in what was never there with new material

positions.title: Despite untrustworthiness of memory, it is just as important to interpret the smallest, least conspicuous and most uncertain constituents of dreams as the most clearly preserved
positions.text: Despite untrustworthiness of memory, it is just as important to interpret the smallest, least conspicuous and most uncertain constituents of dreams as the most clearly preserved

positions.title: Precisely the most trivial elements of a dream are indispensable to its interpretation - work is held up if attention is not paid to them
positions.text: Precisely the most trivial elements of a dream are indispensable to its interpretation - work is held up if attention is not paid to them

positions.title: We treat dream texts as Holy Writ what previous writers regarded as arbitrary improvisation hurriedly patched together
positions.text: We treat dream texts as Holy Writ what previous writers regarded as arbitrary improvisation hurriedly patched together

positions.title: No conclusions upon construction and working methods of the mental instrument can be fully proved from investigation of dreams or any other mental function taken in isolation
positions.text: No conclusions upon construction and working methods of the mental instrument can be fully proved from investigation of dreams or any other mental function taken in isolation

positions.title: Psychological hypotheses from dream analysis must remain in suspense until related to findings from other enquiries approaching the same problem from another angle
positions.text: Psychological hypotheses from dream analysis must remain in suspense until related to findings from other enquiries approaching the same problem from another angle

positions.title: Dreams make use of the present tense in the same manner as day-dreams - the present tense is that in which wishes are represented as fulfilled
positions.text: Dreams make use of the present tense in the same manner as day-dreams - the present tense is that in which wishes are represented as fulfilled

positions.title: Not every dream exhibits transformation from idea into sensory image - there are dreams consisting only of thoughts which cannot be denied the essential nature of dreams
positions.text: Not every dream exhibits transformation from idea into sensory image - there are dreams consisting only of thoughts which cannot be denied the essential nature of dreams

positions.title: Transformation of ideas into sensory images also occurs in hallucinations and visions in health and as symptoms in psychoneuroses - this relation is not exclusive to dreams
positions.text: Transformation of ideas into sensory images also occurs in hallucinations and visions in health and as symptoms in psychoneuroses - this relation is not exclusive to dreams

positions.title: The scene of action of dreams is different from that of waking ideational life - this makes the special peculiarities of dream-life intelligible
positions.text: The scene of action of dreams is different from that of waking ideational life - this makes the special peculiarities of dream-life intelligible

positions.title: We picture the mental apparatus as a compound instrument of 'systems' arranged in temporal sequence through which excitation passes
positions.text: We picture the mental apparatus as a compound instrument of 'systems' arranged in temporal sequence through which excitation passes

positions.title: All psychical activity starts from stimuli and ends in innervations - the apparatus has a sensory and motor end with a sense or direction
positions.text: All psychical activity starts from stimuli and ends in innervations - the apparatus has a sensory and motor end with a sense or direction

positions.title: Reflex processes remain the model of every psychical function - the psychical apparatus must be constructed like a reflex apparatus
positions.text: Reflex processes remain the model of every psychical function - the psychical apparatus must be constructed like a reflex apparatus

positions.title: We must distribute perception and memory functions onto different systems - a system receives perceptions but retains no trace, while mnemic systems retain permanent modifications
positions.text: We must distribute perception and memory functions onto different systems - a system receives perceptions but retains no trace, while mnemic systems retain permanent modifications

positions.title: Association consists in the fact that excitation is transmitted more readily from one mnemic element to another due to diminished resistances and facilitating paths
positions.text: Association consists in the fact that excitation is transmitted more readily from one mnemic element to another due to diminished resistances and facilitating paths

positions.title: The perception system without capacity to retain modifications provides consciousness with sensory qualities, while memories even deeply stamped are themselves unconscious
positions.text: The perception system without capacity to retain modifications provides consciousness with sensory qualities, while memories even deeply stamped are themselves unconscious

positions.title: What we describe as our character is based on memory-traces of impressions, especially those of earliest youth which scarcely ever become conscious
positions.text: What we describe as our character is based on memory-traces of impressions, especially those of earliest youth which scarcely ever become conscious

positions.title: Memories can produce all their effects while in an unconscious condition - when they become conscious they exhibit no sensory quality or very slight quality
positions.text: Memories can produce all their effects while in an unconscious condition - when they become conscious they exhibit no sensory quality or very slight quality

positions.title: Formation of dreams required the hypothesis of two psychical agencies - one submitting the other's activity to criticism involving exclusion from consciousness
positions.text: Formation of dreams required the hypothesis of two psychical agencies - one submitting the other's activity to criticism involving exclusion from consciousness

positions.title: The critical agency stands closer to consciousness like a screen between the criticized agency and consciousness, and directs waking life and voluntary actions
positions.text: The critical agency stands closer to consciousness like a screen between the criticized agency and consciousness, and directs waking life and voluntary actions

positions.title: The preconscious system allows excitatory processes to enter consciousness without impediment if certain conditions are fulfilled - it holds the key to voluntary movement
positions.text: The preconscious system allows excitatory processes to enter consciousness without impediment if certain conditions are fulfilled - it holds the key to voluntary movement

positions.title: The unconscious system has no access to consciousness except via the preconscious, through which its excitatory process must submit to modifications
positions.text: The unconscious system has no access to consciousness except via the preconscious, through which its excitatory process must submit to modifications

positions.title: The motive force for producing dreams is supplied by the unconscious system - the dream-wish originates from the Ucs
positions.text: The motive force for producing dreams is supplied by the unconscious system - the dream-wish originates from the Ucs

positions.title: The unconscious must be assumed to be the general basis of psychical life, as the larger sphere which includes within it the smaller sphere of the conscious
positions.text: The unconscious must be assumed to be the general basis of psychical life, as the larger sphere which includes within it the smaller sphere of the conscious

positions.title: Everything conscious has an unconscious preliminary stage; whereas what is unconscious may remain at that stage and nevertheless claim to be regarded as having the full value of a psychical process
positions.text: Everything conscious has an unconscious preliminary stage; whereas what is unconscious may remain at that stage and nevertheless claim to be regarded as having the full value of a psychical process

positions.title: The unconscious is the true psychical reality; in its innermost nature it is as much unknown to us as the reality of the external world
positions.text: The unconscious is the true psychical reality; in its innermost nature it is as much unknown to us as the reality of the external world

positions.title: Dreams prove that what is suppressed continues to exist in normal people as well as abnormal, and remains capable of psychical functioning
positions.text: Dreams prove that what is suppressed continues to exist in normal people as well as abnormal, and remains capable of psychical functioning

positions.title: The interpretation of dreams is the royal road to a knowledge of the unconscious activities of the mind
positions.text: The interpretation of dreams is the royal road to a knowledge of the unconscious activities of the mind

positions.title: Functional illnesses do not presuppose the disintegration of the apparatus or the production of fresh splits, but are to be explained dynamically by the strengthening and weakening of components in the interplay of forces
positions.text: Functional illnesses do not presuppose the disintegration of the apparatus or the production of fresh splits, but are to be explained dynamically by the strengthening and weakening of components in the interplay of forces

positions.title: Consciousness functions as a sense-organ for the perception of psychical qualities
positions.text: Consciousness functions as a sense-organ for the perception of psychical qualities

positions.title: The Cs. system resembles the perceptual systems in being susceptible to excitation by qualities but incapable of retaining traces of alterations - that is, as having no memory
positions.text: The Cs. system resembles the perceptual systems in being susceptible to excitation by qualities but incapable of retaining traces of alterations - that is, as having no memory

positions.title: Consciousness perceives new qualities and makes a new contribution to directing the mobile quantities of cathexis and distributing them in an expedient fashion
positions.text: Consciousness perceives new qualities and makes a new contribution to directing the mobile quantities of cathexis and distributing them in an expedient fashion

positions.title: The unpleasure principle regulates the displacement of cathexes automatically, but consciousness may introduce a second and more discriminating regulation which perfects the efficiency of the apparatus
positions.text: The unpleasure principle regulates the displacement of cathexes automatically, but consciousness may introduce a second and more discriminating regulation which perfects the efficiency of the apparatus

positions.title: Thought-processes acquire quality by being associated with verbal memories, whose residues of quality draw the attention of consciousness to them
positions.text: Thought-processes acquire quality by being associated with verbal memories, whose residues of quality draw the attention of consciousness to them

positions.title: Repression affects memories more easily than perceptions because memories can receive no extra cathexis from the excitation of the psychical sense-organs
positions.text: Repression affects memories more easily than perceptions because memories can receive no extra cathexis from the excitation of the psychical sense-organs

positions.title: The respect paid to dreams in antiquity is based upon correct psychological insight and is homage to the uncontrolled and indestructible forces in the human mind
positions.text: The respect paid to dreams in antiquity is based upon correct psychological insight and is homage to the uncontrolled and indestructible forces in the human mind

positions.title: What we have discovered by the analysis of dreams is the existence of two fundamentally different kinds of psychical process (primary and secondary), and the fact that these two kinds cooperate in the production of our mental acts
positions.text: What we have discovered by the analysis of dreams is the existence of two fundamentally different kinds of psychical process (primary and secondary), and the fact that these two kinds cooperate in the production of our mental acts

positions.title: Dream-work shows the same processes (condensation, displacement, etc.) that operate in the formation of hysterical symptoms, proving these mechanisms are present in the normal mental apparatus
positions.text: Dream-work shows the same processes (condensation, displacement, etc.) that operate in the formation of hysterical symptoms, proving these mechanisms are present in the normal mental apparatus

positions.title: Dreams function as guardians of sleep by providing psychical consummation for suppressed wishes through representing them as fulfilled
positions.text: Dreams function as guardians of sleep by providing psychical consummation for suppressed wishes through representing them as fulfilled

positions.title: The dream provides a compromise which simultaneously satisfies both the suppressed wish and the agency maintaining sleep
positions.text: The dream provides a compromise which simultaneously satisfies both the suppressed wish and the agency maintaining sleep

positions.title: Most dreams of adults are traced back by analysis to erotic wishes, because no other group of instincts has been submitted to such far-reaching suppression by cultural education
positions.text: Most dreams of adults are traced back by analysis to erotic wishes, because no other group of instincts has been submitted to such far-reaching suppression by cultural education

positions.title: Almost every civilized man retains the infantile forms of sexual life in some respect or other, making repressed infantile sexual wishes the most frequent and strongest motive-forces for dream construction
positions.text: Almost every civilized man retains the infantile forms of sexual life in some respect or other, making repressed infantile sexual wishes the most frequent and strongest motive-forces for dream construction

positions.title: Dream-symbols are used by dreamers speaking the same language, and some extend beyond language use, though dreamers themselves are unaware of the symbols' meaning
positions.text: Dream-symbols are used by dreamers speaking the same language, and some extend beyond language use, though dreamers themselves are unaware of the symbols' meaning

positions.title: The forgetting of proper names with substitute names (paramnesia) follows discoverable paths conforming to laws rather than arbitrary psychical choice
positions.text: The forgetting of proper names with substitute names (paramnesia) follows discoverable paths conforming to laws rather than arbitrary psychical choice

positions.title: The displacement leading to substitute names is not left to arbitrary choice but follows predictable paths, with substitute names connected in discoverable ways to the missing name
positions.text: The displacement leading to substitute names is not left to arbitrary choice but follows predictable paths, with substitute names connected in discoverable ways to the missing name

positions.title: Forgetting of names occurs when a motive causes suppression of connected thoughts, and this suppression associates with the name through external connection, causing the name to be forgotten against one's will
positions.text: Forgetting of names occurs when a motive causes suppression of connected thoughts, and this suppression associates with the name through external connection, causing the name to be forgotten against one's will

positions.title: Substitute names represent a compromise, reminding one both of what one wanted to forget and what one wanted to remember, showing that the intention to forget was neither complete success nor complete failure
positions.text: Substitute names represent a compromise, reminding one both of what one wanted to forget and what one wanted to remember, showing that the intention to forget was neither complete success nor complete failure

positions.title: Conditions for forgetting a name with paramnesia include: (1) a disposition for forgetting the name, (2) a process of suppression shortly before, (3) possibility of external association between the name and the previously suppressed element
positions.text: Conditions for forgetting a name with paramnesia include: (1) a disposition for forgetting the name, (2) a process of suppression shortly before, (3) possibility of external association between the name and the previously suppressed element

positions.title: A suppressed element always strives to assert itself elsewhere, but is successful only when suitable conditions meet it halfway
positions.text: A suppressed element always strives to assert itself elsewhere, but is successful only when suitable conditions meet it halfway

positions.title: Phenomena of daily life such as forgetting, slips of the tongue, and bungled actions provide a basis for psychopathology in psychology, showing the same mechanisms operate in normal and pathological mental life
positions.text: Phenomena of daily life such as forgetting, slips of the tongue, and bungled actions provide a basis for psychopathology in psychology, showing the same mechanisms operate in normal and pathological mental life

positions.title: Parapraxes (Freudian slips) are not chance events but result from the interference of two different intentions, one of which is kept from consciousness
positions.text: Parapraxes (Freudian slips) are not chance events but result from the interference of two different intentions, one of which is kept from consciousness

positions.title: Slips of the tongue reveal thoughts the speaker wished to suppress, demonstrating that suppressed material finds indirect pathways to expression
positions.text: Slips of the tongue reveal thoughts the speaker wished to suppress, demonstrating that suppressed material finds indirect pathways to expression

positions.title: There is no such thing as arbitrary determination in the mind - even apparently chance psychical events follow deterministic laws
positions.text: There is no such thing as arbitrary determination in the mind - even apparently chance psychical events follow deterministic laws

positions.title: Forgetting is often motivated by unpleasure - we most easily forget what is associated with feelings of unpleasure or what would awaken such feelings if recalled
positions.text: Forgetting is often motivated by unpleasure - we most easily forget what is associated with feelings of unpleasure or what would awaken such feelings if recalled

positions.title: Bungled actions (symptomatic acts) often represent compromises between conscious intentions and unconscious counter-intentions
positions.text: Bungled actions (symptomatic acts) often represent compromises between conscious intentions and unconscious counter-intentions

positions.title: The same psychical mechanisms revealed in neurotic symptoms operate in the everyday mistakes, forgetting, and slips of normal people
positions.text: The same psychical mechanisms revealed in neurotic symptoms operate in the everyday mistakes, forgetting, and slips of normal people

positions.title: Apparently meaningless and arbitrary psychical products always have motivation and significance when subjected to psychoanalytic investigation
positions.text: Apparently meaningless and arbitrary psychical products always have motivation and significance when subjected to psychoanalytic investigation

positions.title: The forgetting of names, words, and impressions can regularly be traced to the influence of emotional complexes that remain unconscious
positions.text: The forgetting of names, words, and impressions can regularly be traced to the influence of emotional complexes that remain unconscious

positions.title: Superstition is largely concerned with anticipation of misfortune, representing projection of unconscious hostile and envious wishes outward onto external fate
positions.text: Superstition is largely concerned with anticipation of misfortune, representing projection of unconscious hostile and envious wishes outward onto external fate

positions.title: The psychopathology of everyday life demonstrates the continuity between normal and abnormal mental functioning, with the same fundamental mechanisms operative in both
positions.text: The psychopathology of everyday life demonstrates the continuity between normal and abnormal mental functioning, with the same fundamental mechanisms operative in both

positions.title: Popular opinion's view of the sexual instinct - that it is absent in childhood, sets in at puberty, and aims at sexual union - gives a very false picture containing numerous errors and hasty conclusions
positions.text: Popular opinion's view of the sexual instinct - that it is absent in childhood, sets in at puberty, and aims at sexual union - gives a very false picture containing numerous errors and hasty conclusions

positions.title: Sexual object (the person from whom attraction proceeds) and sexual aim (the act toward which the instinct tends) both show numerous deviations from what is assumed to be normal
positions.text: Sexual object (the person from whom attraction proceeds) and sexual aim (the act toward which the instinct tends) both show numerous deviations from what is assumed to be normal

positions.title: Inversion (homosexuality) demonstrates that sexual object choice is not fixed by nature to the opposite sex, as popular fables suggest
positions.text: Inversion (homosexuality) demonstrates that sexual object choice is not fixed by nature to the opposite sex, as popular fables suggest

positions.title: The sexual instinct and the sexual object are merely soldered together, and this connection is looser than popular assumption suggests
positions.text: The sexual instinct and the sexual object are merely soldered together, and this connection is looser than popular assumption suggests

positions.title: The findings of psychoanalysis are based entirely upon everyday medical observation, to which psychoanalytic research lends additional depth and scientific significance
positions.text: The findings of psychoanalysis are based entirely upon everyday medical observation, to which psychoanalytic research lends additional depth and scientific significance

positions.title: The work deliberately remains independent of biological findings, aiming to discover how far psychological investigation can throw light upon the biology of human sexual life
positions.text: The work deliberately remains independent of biological findings, aiming to discover how far psychological investigation can throw light upon the biology of human sexual life

positions.title: Psychoanalytic method may legitimately lead to opinions differing largely from those based on biological considerations
positions.text: Psychoanalytic method may legitimately lead to opinions differing largely from those based on biological considerations

positions.title: Preference is given to accidental factors over disposition, and to ontogenesis over phylogenesis, because accidental factors play the principal part in analysis and are subject to its influence
positions.text: Preference is given to accidental factors over disposition, and to ontogenesis over phylogenesis, because accidental factors play the principal part in analysis and are subject to its influence

positions.title: The enlarged concept of sexuality in psychoanalysis coincides with the Eros of Plato, demonstrating classical precedent for broad conceptions of sexual instinct
positions.text: The enlarged concept of sexuality in psychoanalysis coincides with the Eros of Plato, demonstrating classical precedent for broad conceptions of sexual instinct

positions.title: Inverts vary in behavior from absolute inverts (exclusively same-sex objects) to amphigenic inverts (psychosexual hermaphrodites with objects of either sex) to contingent inverts (capable of same-sex relations under certain conditions)
positions.text: Inverts vary in behavior from absolute inverts (exclusively same-sex objects) to amphigenic inverts (psychosexual hermaphrodites with objects of either sex) to contingent inverts (capable of same-sex relations under certain conditions)

positions.title: Inversion cannot be regarded as degeneracy in the legitimate sense, as it is found in people with no other serious deviations, in those of high intellectual development and ethical culture, and was prevalent in ancient civilizations
positions.text: Inversion cannot be regarded as degeneracy in the legitimate sense, as it is found in people with no other serious deviations, in those of high intellectual development and ethical culture, and was prevalent in ancient civilizations

positions.title: The indiscriminate use of the concept of degeneracy adds nothing to knowledge; degeneracy should only be attributed where several serious deviations are found together and capacity for functioning is severely impaired
positions.text: The indiscriminate use of the concept of degeneracy adds nothing to knowledge; degeneracy should only be attributed where several serious deviations are found together and capacity for functioning is severely impaired

positions.title: The choice between 'innate' and 'acquired' does not cover all issues involved in inversion - both factors must cooperate rather than being mutually exclusive explanations
positions.text: The choice between 'innate' and 'acquired' does not cover all issues involved in inversion - both factors must cooperate rather than being mutually exclusive explanations

positions.title: External influences alone cannot explain acquisition of inversion without cooperation of something in the subject himself, since many people subjected to same influences do not become inverted
positions.text: External influences alone cannot explain acquisition of inversion without cooperation of something in the subject himself, since many people subjected to same influences do not become inverted

positions.title: A certain degree of anatomical hermaphroditism occurs normally, with every normal individual showing traces of the apparatus of the opposite sex
positions.text: A certain degree of anatomical hermaphroditism occurs normally, with every normal individual showing traces of the apparatus of the opposite sex

positions.title: An originally bisexual physical disposition has in evolution become modified into a unisexual one, leaving behind traces of the atrophied sex
positions.text: An originally bisexual physical disposition has in evolution become modified into a unisexual one, leaving behind traces of the atrophied sex

positions.title: Inversion and somatic hermaphroditism are on the whole independent of each other - there is no close connection between hypothetical psychical hermaphroditism and established anatomical hermaphroditism
positions.text: Inversion and somatic hermaphroditism are on the whole independent of each other - there is no close connection between hypothetical psychical hermaphroditism and established anatomical hermaphroditism

positions.title: The most complete mental masculinity can be combined with inversion, showing that sexual object choice is independent of other mental characteristics
positions.text: The most complete mental masculinity can be combined with inversion, showing that sexual object choice is independent of other mental characteristics

positions.title: The popular view that the sexual instinct is absent in childhood and only awakens at puberty is not merely a simple error but one that has grave consequences, causing our present ignorance of fundamental sexual conditions
positions.text: The popular view that the sexual instinct is absent in childhood and only awakens at puberty is not merely a simple error but one that has grave consequences, causing our present ignorance of fundamental sexual conditions

positions.title: A thorough study of sexual manifestations of childhood would reveal the essential characters of the sexual instinct and show its development course and how it is assembled from various sources
positions.text: A thorough study of sexual manifestations of childhood would reveal the essential characters of the sexual instinct and show its development course and how it is assembled from various sources

positions.title: The influence of childhood should be easier to understand and claim consideration before heredity in explaining adult characteristics, yet writers have devoted more attention to phylogenetic than ontogenetic primaeval periods
positions.text: The influence of childhood should be easier to understand and claim consideration before heredity in explaining adult characteristics, yet writers have devoted more attention to phylogenetic than ontogenetic primaeval periods

positions.title: Not a single author has clearly recognized the regular existence of a sexual instinct in childhood, and the chapter on sexual development is as a rule omitted in writings on child development
positions.text: Not a single author has clearly recognized the regular existence of a sexual instinct in childhood, and the chapter on sexual development is as a rule omitted in writings on child development

positions.title: Infantile amnesia - the peculiar amnesia which hides the earliest beginnings of childhood up to the sixth or eighth year - is responsible for neglect of infantile sexuality
positions.text: Infantile amnesia - the peculiar amnesia which hides the earliest beginnings of childhood up to the sixth or eighth year - is responsible for neglect of infantile sexuality

positions.title: The impressions of childhood that we have forgotten have left the deepest traces on our minds and had a determining effect upon our later development, representing repression rather than real abolition
positions.text: The impressions of childhood that we have forgotten have left the deepest traces on our minds and had a determining effect upon our later development, representing repression rather than real abolition

positions.title: Infantile amnesia provides a point of comparison between mental states of children and psychoneurotics, and may be brought into relation with the sexual impulses of childhood
positions.text: Infantile amnesia provides a point of comparison between mental states of children and psychoneurotics, and may be brought into relation with the sexual impulses of childhood

positions.title: Hysterical amnesia is only explicable by the subject already possessing memory-traces withdrawn from conscious disposal which are connected by an associative link to the forgotten material
positions.text: Hysterical amnesia is only explicable by the subject already possessing memory-traces withdrawn from conscious disposal which are connected by an associative link to the forgotten material

positions.title: During the latency period are built up the mental forces which later impede the sexual instinct - disgust, shame, and aesthetic and moral ideals - like dams restricting its flow
positions.text: During the latency period are built up the mental forces which later impede the sexual instinct - disgust, shame, and aesthetic and moral ideals - like dams restricting its flow

positions.title: The construction of mental dams against sexuality is organically determined and fixed by heredity, and can occasionally occur without any help from education
positions.text: The construction of mental dams against sexuality is organically determined and fixed by heredity, and can occasionally occur without any help from education

positions.title: These mental constructions emerge at the cost of infantile sexual impulses themselves, whose energy is diverted from sexual use and directed to other ends - a process deserving the name of sublimation
positions.text: These mental constructions emerge at the cost of infantile sexual impulses themselves, whose energy is diverted from sexual use and directed to other ends - a process deserving the name of sublimation

positions.title: Powerful components are acquired for every kind of cultural achievement by diversion of sexual instinctual forces from sexual aims to new ones through sublimation
positions.text: Powerful components are acquired for every kind of cultural achievement by diversion of sexual instinctual forces from sexual aims to new ones through sublimation

positions.title: The sexual impulses of childhood cannot be utilized since reproductive functions are deferred, and these impulses are perverse - arising from erotogenic zones and arousing unpleasure, evoking opposing mental forces
positions.text: The sexual impulses of childhood cannot be utilized since reproductive functions are deferred, and these impulses are perverse - arising from erotogenic zones and arousing unpleasure, evoking opposing mental forces

positions.title: Sexual activity makes a child ineducable, which is why educators stigmatize every sexual manifestation as a vice, though they cannot do much against it
positions.text: Sexual activity makes a child ineducable, which is why educators stigmatize every sexual manifestation as a vice, though they cannot do much against it

positions.title: Thumb-sucking (sensual sucking) consists in rhythmic repetition of sucking contact by the mouth with no purpose of taking nourishment, involving complete absorption of attention and often leading to a motor reaction like an orgasm
positions.text: Thumb-sucking (sensual sucking) consists in rhythmic repetition of sucking contact by the mouth with no purpose of taking nourishment, involving complete absorption of attention and often leading to a motor reaction like an orgasm

positions.title: Many children proceed from thumb-sucking to masturbation, showing continuity between oral and genital sexuality
positions.text: Many children proceed from thumb-sucking to masturbation, showing continuity between oral and genital sexuality

positions.title: The most striking feature of infantile sexual activity is that the instinct is not directed towards other people but obtains satisfaction from the subject's own body - it is auto-erotic
positions.text: The most striking feature of infantile sexual activity is that the instinct is not directed towards other people but obtains satisfaction from the subject's own body - it is auto-erotic

positions.title: The child's lips behave like an erotogenic zone, and stimulation by the warm flow of milk is the cause of pleasurable sensation - sexual activity first attaches itself to functions serving self-preservation
positions.text: The child's lips behave like an erotogenic zone, and stimulation by the warm flow of milk is the cause of pleasurable sensation - sexual activity first attaches itself to functions serving self-preservation

positions.title: To begin with, sexual activity attaches itself to functions serving the purpose of self-preservation and does not become independent of them until later
positions.text: To begin with, sexual activity attaches itself to functions serving the purpose of self-preservation and does not become independent of them until later

positions.title: The picture of a baby sinking back satiated from the breast with flushed cheeks and blissful smile persists as a prototype of the expression of sexual satisfaction in later life
positions.text: The picture of a baby sinking back satiated from the breast with flushed cheeks and blissful smile persists as a prototype of the expression of sexual satisfaction in later life

positions.title: The need for repeating sexual satisfaction becomes detached from the need for taking nourishment when teeth appear and food is chewed rather than only sucked
positions.text: The need for repeating sexual satisfaction becomes detached from the need for taking nourishment when teeth appear and food is chewed rather than only sucked

positions.title: Constitutional intensification of the erotogenic significance of the labial region persisting into adulthood produces epicures in kissing, perverse kissing, powerful motives for drinking and smoking, or if repression ensues, disgust at food and hysterical vomiting
positions.text: Constitutional intensification of the erotogenic significance of the labial region persisting into adulthood produces epicures in kissing, perverse kissing, powerful motives for drinking and smoking, or if repression ensues, disgust at food and hysterical vomiting

positions.title: The three essential characteristics of infantile sexual manifestation are: (1) it attaches itself to vital somatic functions, (2) it has no sexual object and is thus auto-erotic, (3) its sexual aim is dominated by an erotogenic zone
positions.text: The three essential characteristics of infantile sexual manifestation are: (1) it attaches itself to vital somatic functions, (2) it has no sexual object and is thus auto-erotic, (3) its sexual aim is dominated by an erotogenic zone

positions.title: An erotogenic zone is a part of the skin or mucous membrane in which stimuli of a certain sort evoke a feeling of pleasure possessing a particular quality
positions.text: An erotogenic zone is a part of the skin or mucous membrane in which stimuli of a certain sort evoke a feeling of pleasure possessing a particular quality

positions.title: The anal zone shows that erotogenic zones are portions of the skin with heightened excitability innately present, and all erotogenic zones are used to provide a certain amount of pleasure obtained by stimulation according to some rhythm
positions.text: The anal zone shows that erotogenic zones are portions of the skin with heightened excitability innately present, and all erotogenic zones are used to provide a certain amount of pleasure obtained by stimulation according to some rhythm

positions.title: The anal zone retains considerable susceptibility to genital stimulation throughout life, and intestinal disturbances in childhood have a determining influence on later neurotic symptoms
positions.text: The anal zone retains considerable susceptibility to genital stimulation throughout life, and intestinal disturbances in childhood have a determining influence on later neurotic symptoms

positions.title: Children making use of the anal zone hold back their stool to produce violent muscular contractions and powerful pleasurable stimulation of the mucous membrane as it passes through the anus
positions.text: Children making use of the anal zone hold back their stool to produce violent muscular contractions and powerful pleasurable stimulation of the mucous membrane as it passes through the anus

positions.title: The contents of the bowels are treated as part of the infant's own body, representing his first 'gift' - by producing them he expresses active compliance with environment, by withholding them his disobedience
positions.text: The contents of the bowels are treated as part of the infant's own body, representing his first 'gift' - by producing them he expresses active compliance with environment, by withholding them his disobedience

positions.title: From being a 'gift' feces later acquire the meaning of 'baby' - for babies, according to one sexual theory of children, are acquired by eating and born through the bowels
positions.text: From being a 'gift' feces later acquire the meaning of 'baby' - for babies, according to one sexual theory of children, are acquired by eating and born through the bowels

positions.title: The prohibition against getting pleasure from anal activity and its products has a decisive effect on the child's whole development - this is the first occasion the infant glimpses an environment hostile to instinctual impulses and learns to separate his entity from the alien one, carrying out his first repression
positions.text: The prohibition against getting pleasure from anal activity and its products has a decisive effect on the child's whole development - this is the first occasion the infant glimpses an environment hostile to instinctual impulses and learns to separate his entity from the alien one, carrying out his first repression

positions.title: What is 'anal' remains the symbol of everything to be repudiated and excluded from life after the first prohibition against anal pleasure
positions.text: What is 'anal' remains the symbol of everything to be repudiated and excluded from life after the first prohibition against anal pleasure

positions.title: The genital zone is destined to great things in the future - early infantile masturbation, which scarcely a single individual escapes, establishes the foundations for the future primacy exercised by this erotogenic zone
positions.text: The genital zone is destined to great things in the future - early infantile masturbation, which scarcely a single individual escapes, establishes the foundations for the future primacy exercised by this erotogenic zone

positions.title: Three phases of infantile masturbation are to be distinguished: the first belongs to early infancy, the second to the brief efflorescence of sexual activity about the fourth year of life, and only the third corresponds to pubertal masturbation
positions.text: Three phases of infantile masturbation are to be distinguished: the first belongs to early infancy, the second to the brief efflorescence of sexual activity about the fourth year of life, and only the third corresponds to pubertal masturbation

positions.title: Positive and negative perversions can be traced back to a number of component instincts, which are not of a primary nature but are susceptible to further analysis
positions.text: Positive and negative perversions can be traced back to a number of component instincts, which are not of a primary nature but are susceptible to further analysis

positions.title: An instinct is provisionally understood as the psychical representative of an endosomatic, continuously flowing source of stimulation, contrasted with a stimulus set up by single excitations from without
positions.text: An instinct is provisionally understood as the psychical representative of an endosomatic, continuously flowing source of stimulation, contrasted with a stimulus set up by single excitations from without

positions.title: The concept of instinct lies on the frontier between the mental and the physical, representing a measure of the demand made upon the mind for work
positions.text: The concept of instinct lies on the frontier between the mental and the physical, representing a measure of the demand made upon the mind for work

positions.title: In itself an instinct is without quality - what distinguishes instincts from one another and endows them with specific qualities is their relation to their somatic sources and to their aims
positions.text: In itself an instinct is without quality - what distinguishes instincts from one another and endows them with specific qualities is their relation to their somatic sources and to their aims

positions.title: The source of an instinct is a process of excitation occurring in an organ and the immediate aim of the instinct lies in the removal of this organic stimulus
positions.text: The source of an instinct is a process of excitation occurring in an organ and the immediate aim of the instinct lies in the removal of this organic stimulus

positions.title: Erotogenic zones behave in every respect like a portion of the sexual apparatus - in hysteria they become the seat of new sensations and changes in innervation comparable to genital erection
positions.text: Erotogenic zones behave in every respect like a portion of the sexual apparatus - in hysteria they become the seat of new sensations and changes in innervation comparable to genital erection

positions.title: The eye corresponds to an erotogenic zone in scopophilia and exhibitionism, while the skin assumes this role in components of sexual instinct involving pain and cruelty
positions.text: The eye corresponds to an erotogenic zone in scopophilia and exhibitionism, while the skin assumes this role in components of sexual instinct involving pain and cruelty

positions.title: When libido fails to obtain satisfaction along normal lines, it behaves like a stream whose main bed has become blocked, proceeding to fill up collateral channels which may hitherto have been empty
positions.text: When libido fails to obtain satisfaction along normal lines, it behaves like a stream whose main bed has become blocked, proceeding to fill up collateral channels which may hitherto have been empty

positions.title: Sexual repression as an internal factor must be put alongside external factors like limitation of freedom and inaccessibility of normal sexual objects, which bring about perversions in persons who might otherwise remain normal
positions.text: Sexual repression as an internal factor must be put alongside external factors like limitation of freedom and inaccessibility of normal sexual objects, which bring about perversions in persons who might otherwise remain normal

positions.title: Neurosis will always produce its greatest effects when constitution and experience work together in the same direction - what is innate and what is accidentally experienced are not opposing but cooperative factors
positions.text: Neurosis will always produce its greatest effects when constitution and experience work together in the same direction - what is innate and what is accidentally experienced are not opposing but cooperative factors

positions.title: An unbroken chain bridges the gap between the neuroses in all their manifestations and normality - we are all to some extent hysterics
positions.text: An unbroken chain bridges the gap between the neuroses in all their manifestations and normality - we are all to some extent hysterics

positions.title: The extraordinarily wide dissemination of perversions forces us to suppose that the disposition to perversions is of no great rarity but must form a part of what passes as the normal constitution
positions.text: The extraordinarily wide dissemination of perversions forces us to suppose that the disposition to perversions is of no great rarity but must form a part of what passes as the normal constitution

positions.title: There is something innate lying behind the perversions, but it is something innate in everyone as a disposition varying in intensity and increased by influences of actual life
positions.text: There is something innate lying behind the perversions, but it is something innate in everyone as a disposition varying in intensity and increased by influences of actual life

positions.title: What is innate are the constitutional roots of the sexual instinct - these may grow into actual vehicles of sexual activity (perversions), attract sexual energy as symptoms (neurosis), or through effective restriction bring about normal sexual life
positions.text: What is innate are the constitutional roots of the sexual instinct - these may grow into actual vehicles of sexual activity (perversions), attract sexual energy as symptoms (neurosis), or through effective restriction bring about normal sexual life

positions.title: The postulated constitution containing germs of all perversions will only be demonstrable in children - a formula takes shape that the sexuality of neurotics has remained in or been brought back to an infantile state
positions.text: The postulated constitution containing germs of all perversions will only be demonstrable in children - a formula takes shape that the sexuality of neurotics has remained in or been brought back to an infantile state

positions.title: Every active perversion is accompanied by its passive counterpart in the unconscious - exhibitionists are simultaneously voyeurs, those with repressed sadistic impulses have masochistic determinants of symptoms
positions.text: Every active perversion is accompanied by its passive counterpart in the unconscious - exhibitionists are simultaneously voyeurs, those with repressed sadistic impulses have masochistic determinants of symptoms

positions.title: In any fairly marked case of psychoneurosis, a considerable number of perverse instincts are usually found, with traces of them all, though the degree of development of each is independent of the others
positions.text: In any fairly marked case of psychoneurosis, a considerable number of perverse instincts are usually found, with traces of them all, though the degree of development of each is independent of the others

positions.title: The aetiological factors of neurosis operate according to a complemental series, in which diminishing intensity of one factor (constitution) is balanced by increasing intensity of another (accidental experiences); extreme cases exist at both ends where one factor alone may be sufficient.
positions.text: The aetiological factors of neurosis operate according to a complemental series, in which diminishing intensity of one factor (constitution) is balanced by increasing intensity of another (accidental experiences); extreme cases exist at both ends where one factor alone may be sufficient.

positions.title: The single aetiological series must be divided into two subseries: the dispositional series (where constitution and childhood experiences interact) and the definitive series (where disposition and later traumatic experiences interact).
positions.text: The single aetiological series must be divided into two subseries: the dispositional series (where constitution and childhood experiences interact) and the definitive series (where disposition and later traumatic experiences interact).

positions.title: All factors that impair sexual development show their effects by bringing about regression - a return to an earlier phase of development.
positions.text: All factors that impair sexual development show their effects by bringing about regression - a return to an earlier phase of development.

positions.title: Spontaneous sexual precocity can be demonstrated with certainty in the aetiology of neuroses, though it is not in itself a sufficient cause; it manifests in the interruption, abbreviation, or ending of the latency period.
positions.text: Spontaneous sexual precocity can be demonstrated with certainty in the aetiology of neuroses, though it is not in itself a sufficient cause; it manifests in the interruption, abbreviation, or ending of the latency period.

positions.title: Sexual precocity causes disturbances by occasioning sexual manifestations that, due to incomplete sexual inhibitions and undeveloped genital system, are bound to be in the nature of perversions.
positions.text: Sexual precocity causes disturbances by occasioning sexual manifestations that, due to incomplete sexual inhibitions and undeveloped genital system, are bound to be in the nature of perversions.

positions.title: Sexual precocity makes more difficult the later control of the sexual instinct by higher mental agencies and increases the impulsive quality characterizing the psychical representations of the instinct.
positions.text: Sexual precocity makes more difficult the later control of the sexual instinct by higher mental agencies and increases the impulsive quality characterizing the psychical representations of the instinct.

positions.title: Sexual precocity often runs parallel with premature intellectual development; when linked in this way, it is found in the childhood history of persons of greatest eminence and capacity, and under such conditions its effects are not as pathogenic as when it appears in isolation.
positions.text: Sexual precocity often runs parallel with premature intellectual development; when linked in this way, it is found in the childhood history of persons of greatest eminence and capacity, and under such conditions its effects are not as pathogenic as when it appears in isolation.

positions.title: The order in which various instinctual impulses come into activity is phylogenetically determined, as is the length of time they can manifest before succumbing to newly emerging impulses or typical repression.
positions.text: The order in which various instinctual impulses come into activity is phylogenetically determined, as is the length of time they can manifest before succumbing to newly emerging impulses or typical repression.

positions.title: Variations occur in both temporal sequence and duration of instinctual impulses, and these variations exercise a determining influence upon the final developmental outcome.
positions.text: Variations occur in both temporal sequence and duration of instinctual impulses, and these variations exercise a determining influence upon the final developmental outcome.

positions.title: The effect of a repression cannot be undone; therefore, whether a given current appears earlier or later than an opposing current is not a matter of indifference, and divergences in temporal sequence invariably produce differences in outcome.
positions.text: The effect of a repression cannot be undone; therefore, whether a given current appears earlier or later than an opposing current is not a matter of indifference, and divergences in temporal sequence invariably produce differences in outcome.

positions.title: Instinctual impulses that emerge with special intensity often run a surprisingly short course (as seen in the heterosexual attachment of persons who later become manifest homosexuals); there is no justification for fearing that trends setting in violently in childhood will permanently dominate adult character.
positions.text: Instinctual impulses that emerge with special intensity often run a surprisingly short course (as seen in the heterosexual attachment of persons who later become manifest homosexuals); there is no justification for fearing that trends setting in violently in childhood will permanently dominate adult character.

positions.title: Early sexual impressions are characterized by increased pertinacity or susceptibility to fixation in persons who later become neurotics or perverts; the same premature manifestations in others fail to make deep impressions and do not tend toward compulsive repetition.
positions.text: Early sexual impressions are characterized by increased pertinacity or susceptibility to fixation in persons who later become neurotics or perverts; the same premature manifestations in others fail to make deep impressions and do not tend toward compulsive repetition.

positions.title: The pertinacity of early impressions may be partially explained by the preponderance attaching in mental life to memory-traces in comparison with recent impressions; this factor is clearly dependent on intellectual education and increases in proportion to the degree of individual culture.
positions.text: The pertinacity of early impressions may be partially explained by the preponderance attaching in mental life to memory-traces in comparison with recent impressions; this factor is clearly dependent on intellectual education and increases in proportion to the degree of individual culture.

positions.title: There exists an inverse relation between civilization and the free development of sexuality; consequently, the course of a child's sexual life is unimportant for later life where cultural level is low, but highly important where that level is high.
positions.text: There exists an inverse relation between civilization and the free development of sexuality; consequently, the course of a child's sexual life is unimportant for later life where cultural level is low, but highly important where that level is high.

positions.title: Accidental stimulations of infantile sexuality (especially seduction by other children or adults) provide material that, with the help of constitutional factors and pertinacity, can become fixated as permanent disorder.
positions.text: Accidental stimulations of infantile sexuality (especially seduction by other children or adults) provide material that, with the help of constitutional factors and pertinacity, can become fixated as permanent disorder.

positions.title: A good proportion of deviations from normal sexual life observed in neurotics and perverts are established from the very first by impressions of childhood - a period regarded as devoid of sexuality.
positions.text: A good proportion of deviations from normal sexual life observed in neurotics and perverts are established from the very first by impressions of childhood - a period regarded as devoid of sexuality.

positions.title: The causation of sexual pathology is shared between compliant constitution, precocity, increased pertinacity of early impressions, and chance stimulation of sexual instinct by extraneous influences.
positions.text: The causation of sexual pathology is shared between compliant constitution, precocity, increased pertinacity of early impressions, and chance stimulation of sexual instinct by extraneous influences.

positions.title: We know far too little of the biological processes constituting the essence of sexuality to construct from our fragmentary information a theory adequate to understanding both normal and pathological conditions.
positions.text: We know far too little of the biological processes constituting the essence of sexuality to construct from our fragmentary information a theory adequate to understanding both normal and pathological conditions.

positions.title: Psycho-analysis is an outgrowth of the cathartic method discussed in Studies on Hysteria (1895); the cathartic therapy was Breuer's discovery, first used successfully ten years before the Studies.
positions.text: Psycho-analysis is an outgrowth of the cathartic method discussed in Studies on Hysteria (1895); the cathartic therapy was Breuer's discovery, first used successfully ten years before the Studies.

positions.title: The cathartic method presupposed that the patient could be hypnotized and was based on the widening of consciousness that occurs under hypnosis; its aim was symptom removal by inducing the patient to return to the psychical state in which the symptom first appeared.
positions.text: The cathartic method presupposed that the patient could be hypnotized and was based on the widening of consciousness that occurs under hypnosis; its aim was symptom removal by inducing the patient to return to the psychical state in which the symptom first appeared.

positions.title: The symptom represents a transformation ('conversion') of suppressed processes that have not reached consciousness; therapeutic effectiveness was due to discharge of 'strangulated' affect attaching to suppressed mental acts ('abreaction').
positions.text: The symptom represents a transformation ('conversion') of suppressed processes that have not reached consciousness; therapeutic effectiveness was due to discharge of 'strangulated' affect attaching to suppressed mental acts ('abreaction').

positions.title: The cathartic method's therapeutic efficacy lies not in suggestion but in the expectation that symptoms will disappear automatically once the operation succeeds in diverting mental processes from their previous channel that found outlet in symptom formation.
positions.text: The cathartic method's therapeutic efficacy lies not in suggestion but in the expectation that symptoms will disappear automatically once the operation succeeds in diverting mental processes from their previous channel that found outlet in symptom formation.

positions.title: Freud abandoned hypnosis while retaining the cathartic method's rejection of suggestion; patients lie comfortably on a sofa with the analyst sitting behind them outside their field of vision, proceeding like a conversation between two equally awake people.
positions.text: Freud abandoned hypnosis while retaining the cathartic method's rejection of suggestion; patients lie comfortably on a sofa with the analyst sitting behind them outside their field of vision, proceeding like a conversation between two equally awake people.

positions.title: Abandoning hypnosis assured applicability of treatment to unlimited numbers of patients, since many neurotic patients cannot be hypnotized by any means and hypnotizability depends on the patient's choice regardless of physician's skill.
positions.text: Abandoning hypnosis assured applicability of treatment to unlimited numbers of patients, since many neurotic patients cannot be hypnotized by any means and hypnotizability depends on the patient's choice regardless of physician's skill.

positions.title: Free associations - the involuntary thoughts ordinarily pushed aside as disturbing - serve as completely satisfactory substitute for the widening of consciousness that hypnosis provided.
positions.text: Free associations - the involuntary thoughts ordinarily pushed aside as disturbing - serve as completely satisfactory substitute for the widening of consciousness that hypnosis provided.

positions.title: The patient must 'let himself go' in what he says, including whatever comes into his head even if he thinks it unimportant, irrelevant, nonsensical, or embarrassing; he must not omit any thought because relating it would be distressing.
positions.text: The patient must 'let himself go' in what he says, including whatever comes into his head even if he thinks it unimportant, irrelevant, nonsensical, or embarrassing; he must not omit any thought because relating it would be distressing.

positions.title: Gaps appear in the neurotic patient's memory during narration: actual occurrences are forgotten, chronological order is confused, causal connections are broken; no neurotic case history is without amnesia of some kind.
positions.text: Gaps appear in the neurotic patient's memory during narration: actual occurrences are forgotten, chronological order is confused, causal connections are broken; no neurotic case history is without amnesia of some kind.

positions.title: When the patient is urged to fill memory gaps, all ideas that occur are pushed back by every possible critical expedient until he feels positive discomfort when the memory really returns; this demonstrates that amnesias result from repression motivated by feelings of unpleasure.
positions.text: When the patient is urged to fill memory gaps, all ideas that occur are pushed back by every possible critical expedient until he feels positive discomfort when the memory really returns; this demonstrates that amnesias result from repression motivated by feelings of unpleasure.

positions.title: The psychical forces that brought about repression can be detected in the 'resistance' that operates against recovery of lost memories; resistance is one of the corner-stones of psychoanalytic theory.
positions.text: The psychical forces that brought about repression can be detected in the 'resistance' that operates against recovery of lost memories; resistance is one of the corner-stones of psychoanalytic theory.
