positions.title: Ideas normally pushed aside are derivatives of repressed psychical phenomena (thoughts and impulses), distorted owing to resistance against their reproduction.
positions.text: Ideas normally pushed aside are derivatives of repressed psychical phenomena (thoughts and impulses), distorted owing to resistance against their reproduction.

positions.title: The greater the resistance, the greater the distortion; the relation between substitute idea and repressed material is brought to consciousness through interpretation, which constructs the repressed material from signs provided by the derivative.
positions.text: The greater the resistance, the greater the distortion; the relation between substitute idea and repressed material is brought to consciousness through interpretation, which constructs the repressed material from signs provided by the derivative.

positions.title: Psychical material appears to be organized in multiple stratifications ordered according to themes; fragments of the same theme run through collections of memories with varying chronological distance, requiring zigzag movement through the patient's life history.
positions.text: Psychical material appears to be organized in multiple stratifications ordered according to themes; fragments of the same theme run through collections of memories with varying chronological distance, requiring zigzag movement through the patient's life history.

positions.title: Most striking is the organization of pathogenic material into concentric stratifications around the pathogenic nucleus, ordered by degrees of resistance; the most peripheral strata contain memories easily remembered and clearly conscious, while approaching the nucleus encounters increasing resistance.
positions.text: Most striking is the organization of pathogenic material into concentric stratifications around the pathogenic nucleus, ordered by degrees of resistance; the most peripheral strata contain memories easily remembered and clearly conscious, while approaching the nucleus encounters increasing resistance.

positions.title: Memories composing the nucleus never become fully conscious; even after resolution of resistances, they can only be constructed and accepted by the patient with varying degrees of recognition.
positions.text: Memories composing the nucleus never become fully conscious; even after resolution of resistances, they can only be constructed and accepted by the patient with varying degrees of recognition.

positions.title: Resistances must be recognized and pointed out to the patient; once a resistance is overcome, the next appears, so that following resistances systematically enables working through to the pathogenic nucleus.
positions.text: Resistances must be recognized and pointed out to the patient; once a resistance is overcome, the next appears, so that following resistances systematically enables working through to the pathogenic nucleus.

positions.title: The physician's task is like excavating a buried city: clearing away resistances in the material, then constructing from hints and remains what can never be fully brought to consciousness but must be accepted through intellectual conviction.
positions.text: The physician's task is like excavating a buried city: clearing away resistances in the material, then constructing from hints and remains what can never be fully brought to consciousness but must be accepted through intellectual conviction.

positions.title: The work of overcoming resistances is the essential function distinguishing psycho-analysis from other suggestive procedures and constitutes its scientific character.
positions.text: The work of overcoming resistances is the essential function distinguishing psycho-analysis from other suggestive procedures and constitutes its scientific character.

positions.title: Theoretically, one might expect that overcoming all resistances would bring recovery; however, a complication arises from the tendency called 'transference' - the patient directing powerful emotional impulses toward the physician.
positions.text: Theoretically, one might expect that overcoming all resistances would bring recovery; however, a complication arises from the tendency called 'transference' - the patient directing powerful emotional impulses toward the physician.

positions.title: Transference can be positive (affectionate) or hostile; it arises spontaneously in all human relationships and especially in the patient-physician relation; in analysis, it becomes the most powerful instrument of resistance.
positions.text: Transference can be positive (affectionate) or hostile; it arises spontaneously in all human relationships and especially in the patient-physician relation; in analysis, it becomes the most powerful instrument of resistance.

positions.title: Initially, transference carries analysis forward with physician's authority; but when it becomes hostile or erotic, it becomes the most powerful resistance, making the patient suddenly lose understanding and interest in the work.
positions.text: Initially, transference carries analysis forward with physician's authority; but when it becomes hostile or erotic, it becomes the most powerful resistance, making the patient suddenly lose understanding and interest in the work.

positions.title: Transference must itself be uncovered and recognized; it originates from the same sources as earlier resistances and must be resolved by demonstration that such feelings are reproductions of old reactions.
positions.text: Transference must itself be uncovered and recognized; it originates from the same sources as earlier resistances and must be resolved by demonstration that such feelings are reproductions of old reactions.

positions.title: When the patient's relation to the physician is straightened out, all obstacles to understanding and accepting repressed material disappear; psycho-analysis succeeds in solving the psychological problem of treatment that suggestion-based methods leave unsolved.
positions.text: When the patient's relation to the physician is straightened out, all obstacles to understanding and accepting repressed material disappear; psycho-analysis succeeds in solving the psychological problem of treatment that suggestion-based methods leave unsolved.

positions.title: Psycho-analysis does not simply command the patient to overcome resistances but traces their origin and helps reduce them; the patient's residual resistance and degree of self-change achieve the therapeutic alteration sought.
positions.text: Psycho-analysis does not simply command the patient to overcome resistances but traces their origin and helps reduce them; the patient's residual resistance and degree of self-change achieve the therapeutic alteration sought.

positions.title: The whole complex of influences determining recovery can be brought together under the single heading 'transference'; cure is achieved by suggestion, but suggestion means influencing someone by transferential phenomena.
positions.text: The whole complex of influences determining recovery can be brought together under the single heading 'transference'; cure is achieved by suggestion, but suggestion means influencing someone by transferential phenomena.

positions.title: Psycho-analytic independence of suggestion consists in transforming transference itself into the object of treatment and dissolving it by recognizing it as a repetition of earlier reactions.
positions.text: Psycho-analytic independence of suggestion consists in transforming transference itself into the object of treatment and dissolving it by recognizing it as a repetition of earlier reactions.

positions.title: Repression fails to suppress the instinct's capacity to become conscious; instead, it develops power to generate psychical derivatives and substitute connections that become symptoms - substitute satisfactions for what has been repressed.
positions.text: Repression fails to suppress the instinct's capacity to become conscious; instead, it develops power to generate psychical derivatives and substitute connections that become symptoms - substitute satisfactions for what has been repressed.

positions.title: Symptoms are substitute satisfactions that cause suffering either from their own nature or by bringing the person into conflict with their environment and social requirements.
positions.text: Symptoms are substitute satisfactions that cause suffering either from their own nature or by bringing the person into conflict with their environment and social requirements.

positions.title: Treatment induces the patient to give up repressions early in life and replace them with reactions corresponding to psychical maturity; this is accomplished through overcoming resistances by special art of interpretation.
positions.text: Treatment induces the patient to give up repressions early in life and replace them with reactions corresponding to psychical maturity; this is accomplished through overcoming resistances by special art of interpretation.

positions.title: Psycho-analysis demands continuous work by patient and physician over period of months, arousing unpopularity compared to shorter methods; but this very difficulty is used as new motive for combating the patient's illness.
positions.text: Psycho-analysis demands continuous work by patient and physician over period of months, arousing unpopularity compared to shorter methods; but this very difficulty is used as new motive for combating the patient's illness.

positions.title: Psycho-analysis is not applicable to persons lacking certain cultural and reliable character; indications include all chronic forms of hysteria and obsessions, and patients with pathological character traits, perversions, phobias.
positions.text: Psycho-analysis is not applicable to persons lacking certain cultural and reliable character; indications include all chronic forms of hysteria and obsessions, and patients with pathological character traits, perversions, phobias.

positions.title: Psycho-analysis may worsen acute hysteria or intensify confusional states in certain disorders; patients over fifty lack plasticity of mental processes necessary for therapy.
positions.text: Psycho-analysis may worsen acute hysteria or intensify confusional states in certain disorders; patients over fifty lack plasticity of mental processes necessary for therapy.

positions.title: Normality results from repression of certain component instincts and infantile disposition constituents, with remaining constituents subordinated under genital zone primacy in service of the reproductive function.
positions.text: Normality results from repression of certain component instincts and infantile disposition constituents, with remaining constituents subordinated under genital zone primacy in service of the reproductive function.
positions.work: SEXUALITY IN THE AETIOLOGY OF THE NEUROSES

positions.title: Perversions correspond to disturbances of normal coalescence owing to overpowering and compulsive development of certain component instincts; neuroses can be traced to excessive repression of libidinal trends.
positions.text: Perversions correspond to disturbances of normal coalescence owing to overpowering and compulsive development of certain component instincts; neuroses can be traced to excessive repression of libidinal trends.
positions.work: SEXUALITY IN THE AETIOLOGY OF THE NEUROSES

positions.title: Almost all perverse instincts of infantile disposition can be recognized as forces concerned in symptom formation in neuroses, though in state of repression; neurosis is the 'negative' of perversion.
positions.text: Almost all perverse instincts of infantile disposition can be recognized as forces concerned in symptom formation in neuroses, though in state of repression; neurosis is the 'negative' of perversion.
positions.work: SEXUALITY IN THE AETIOLOGY OF THE NEUROSES

positions.title: Two positions have never been repudiated or abandoned despite modifications: the importance of sexuality and of infantilism in aetiology of psychoneuroses.
positions.text: Two positions have never been repudiated or abandoned despite modifications: the importance of sexuality and of infantilism in aetiology of psychoneuroses.
positions.work: SEXUALITY IN THE AETIOLOGY OF THE NEUROSES

positions.title: Accidental influences have been replaced by constitutional factors, and 'defence' in purely psychological sense has been replaced by organic 'sexual repression' in the evolution of aetiological theory.
positions.text: Accidental influences have been replaced by constitutional factors, and 'defence' in purely psychological sense has been replaced by organic 'sexual repression' in the evolution of aetiological theory.
positions.work: SEXUALITY IN THE AETIOLOGY OF THE NEUROSES

positions.title: Psycho-analytic examination reveals that the patient's symptoms constitute his sexual activity (wholly or in part), arising from sources of normal or perverse component instincts of sexuality.
positions.text: Psycho-analytic examination reveals that the patient's symptoms constitute his sexual activity (wholly or in part), arising from sources of normal or perverse component instincts of sexuality.
positions.work: SEXUALITY IN THE AETIOLOGY OF THE NEUROSES

positions.title: Large part of hysterical symptomatology derives directly from expressions of sexual excitement; erotogenic zones attain genital significance during neuroses through intensification of infantile characteristics.
positions.text: Large part of hysterical symptomatology derives directly from expressions of sexual excitement; erotogenic zones attain genital significance during neuroses through intensification of infantile characteristics.
positions.work: SEXUALITY IN THE AETIOLOGY OF THE NEUROSES

positions.title: Most complicated symptoms represent, through 'conversion,' phantasies having sexual situation as subject-matter; anyone who interprets hysteria's language recognizes the neurosis concerns only the patient's repressed sexuality.
positions.text: Most complicated symptoms represent, through 'conversion,' phantasies having sexual situation as subject-matter; anyone who interprets hysteria's language recognizes the neurosis concerns only the patient's repressed sexuality.
positions.work: SEXUALITY IN THE AETIOLOGY OF THE NEUROSES

positions.title: Sexual function must be understood in its true extent as laid down by disposition in infancy; wherever commonplace emotion appears among determinants of illness onset, analysis invariably shows the sexual component of traumatic experience produced the pathogenic result.
positions.text: Sexual function must be understood in its true extent as laid down by disposition in infancy; wherever commonplace emotion appears among determinants of illness onset, analysis invariably shows the sexual component of traumatic experience produced the pathogenic result.
positions.work: SEXUALITY IN THE AETIOLOGY OF THE NEUROSES

positions.title: The essence of psychoneuroses lies in disturbances of sexual processes - the processes determining formation and utilization of sexual libido in the organism.
positions.text: The essence of psychoneuroses lies in disturbances of sexual processes - the processes determining formation and utilization of sexual libido in the organism.
positions.work: SEXUALITY IN THE AETIOLOGY OF THE NEUROSES

positions.title: These sexual processes are in the last resort of a chemical nature; 'actual' neuroses represent somatic effects of disturbances of sexual metabolism, while psychoneuroses represent psychical effects of those same disturbances.
positions.text: These sexual processes are in the last resort of a chemical nature; 'actual' neuroses represent somatic effects of disturbances of sexual metabolism, while psychoneuroses represent psychical effects of those same disturbances.
positions.work: SEXUALITY IN THE AETIOLOGY OF THE NEUROSES

positions.title: The similarity of neuroses to intoxication/abstinence phenomena and to Graves' disease and Addison's disease is clinically striking; like those diseases, neuroses may eventually be excluded from 'nervous diseases' category despite their name.
positions.text: The similarity of neuroses to intoxication/abstinence phenomena and to Graves' disease and Addison's disease is clinically striking; like those diseases, neuroses may eventually be excluded from 'nervous diseases' category despite their name.
positions.work: SEXUALITY IN THE AETIOLOGY OF THE NEUROSES

positions.title: Aetiology of neuroses comprises everything that can act detrimentally upon processes serving sexual function; foremost are noxae affecting sexual function itself as judged injurious by sexual constitution varying with culture and education.
positions.text: Aetiology of neuroses comprises everything that can act detrimentally upon processes serving sexual function; foremost are noxae affecting sexual function itself as judged injurious by sexual constitution varying with culture and education.
positions.work: SEXUALITY IN THE AETIOLOGY OF THE NEUROSES

positions.title: A single pathogenic influence is scarcely ever sufficient; in large majority of cases, multiple aetiological factors are required that support one another and must not be regarded as mutually opposed.
positions.text: A single pathogenic influence is scarcely ever sufficient; in large majority of cases, multiple aetiological factors are required that support one another and must not be regarded as mutually opposed.
positions.work: SEXUALITY IN THE AETIOLOGY OF THE NEUROSES

positions.title: Neurotic illness cannot be sharply differentiated from health; illness onset is product of summation, and the necessary total of aetiological determinants can be completed from any direction.
positions.text: Neurotic illness cannot be sharply differentiated from health; illness onset is product of summation, and the necessary total of aetiological determinants can be completed from any direction.
positions.work: SEXUALITY IN THE AETIOLOGY OF THE NEUROSES

positions.title: To attribute aetiology of neuroses exclusively to heredity/constitution or solely to accidental influences on sexuality would be equally one-sided; better insight shows the essence lies in disturbance of organism's sexual processes.
positions.text: To attribute aetiology of neuroses exclusively to heredity/constitution or solely to accidental influences on sexuality would be equally one-sided; better insight shows the essence lies in disturbance of organism's sexual processes.
positions.work: SEXUALITY IN THE AETIOLOGY OF THE NEUROSES

positions.title: Foremost among psychical treatment measures is the use of words; words are the essential tool operating immediately upon the human mind, whether treating mental or physical disorders.
positions.text: Foremost among psychical treatment measures is the use of words; words are the essential tool operating immediately upon the human mind, whether treating mental or physical disorders.

positions.title: Words originally possessed magical power and retain much of ancient potency; through words one person can make another blessed or drive them to despair, transmit knowledge, and induce affective states.
positions.text: Words originally possessed magical power and retain much of ancient potency; through words one person can make another blessed or drive them to despair, transmit knowledge, and induce affective states.

positions.title: The magical power of words is intelligible to psychologists: words evoke affects and are the universal means by which humans influence each other; despising word-use in psychotherapy means abandoning psychical influence.
positions.text: The magical power of words is intelligible to psychologists: words evoke affects and are the universal means by which humans influence each other; despising word-use in psychotherapy means abandoning psychical influence.

positions.title: Jokes have not received nearly as much philosophical consideration as they deserve given the part they play in mental life; only few thinkers (Jean Paul, Vischer, Fischer, Lipps) have entered deeply into problems of jokes.
positions.text: Jokes have not received nearly as much philosophical consideration as they deserve given the part they play in mental life; only few thinkers (Jean Paul, Vischer, Fischer, Lipps) have entered deeply into problems of jokes.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: It appears impracticable to deal with jokes otherwise than in connection with the comic; jokes represent something comic that is entirely subjective - produced by us, attached to our action.
positions.text: It appears impracticable to deal with jokes otherwise than in connection with the comic; jokes represent something comic that is entirely subjective - produced by us, attached to our action.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: A joke is generally defined as 'any conscious and successful evocation of what is comic, whether comic of observation or of situation.'
positions.text: A joke is generally defined as 'any conscious and successful evocation of what is comic, whether comic of observation or of situation.'
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Fischer defines a joke as 'a playful judgement' - just as aesthetic freedom lies in playful contemplation of things, aesthetic attitude being characterized by not demanding satisfaction of serious needs but contenting ourselves with contemplative enjoyment.
positions.text: Fischer defines a joke as 'a playful judgement' - just as aesthetic freedom lies in playful contemplation of things, aesthetic attitude being characterized by not demanding satisfaction of serious needs but contenting ourselves with contemplative enjoyment.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: A favorite definition of joking is 'the ability to find similarity between dissimilar things - hidden similarities'; Jean Paul: 'Joking is the disguised priest who weds every couple.'
positions.text: A favorite definition of joking is 'the ability to find similarity between dissimilar things - hidden similarities'; Jean Paul: 'Joking is the disguised priest who weds every couple.'
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Vischer defines joking as 'the ability to bind into a unity, with surprising rapidity, several ideas alien to one another both in internal content and in nexus to which they belong.'
positions.text: Vischer defines joking as 'the ability to bind into a unity, with surprising rapidity, several ideas alien to one another both in internal content and in nexus to which they belong.'
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Other definitions characterize jokes through 'contrast of ideas,' 'sense in nonsense,' and 'bewilderment and illumination.'
positions.text: Other definitions characterize jokes through 'contrast of ideas,' 'sense in nonsense,' and 'bewilderment and illumination.'
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Brevity is the body and soul of jokes; a joke says what it has to say not always in few words, but in too few words - words insufficient by strict logic or common modes of thought and speech, even saying what it has to say by not saying it.
positions.text: Brevity is the body and soul of jokes; a joke says what it has to say not always in few words, but in too few words - words insufficient by strict logic or common modes of thought and speech, even saying what it has to say by not saying it.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Jokes 'must bring forward something that is concealed or hidden'; this determinant has more to do with the nature of jokes than with their being part of the comic.
positions.text: Jokes 'must bring forward something that is concealed or hidden'; this determinant has more to do with the nature of jokes than with their being part of the comic.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Previous theories provide scattered characteristics (activity, playful judgement, coupling dissimilar things, contrasting ideas, sense in nonsense, bewilderment/enlightenment, bringing forward hidden, peculiar brevity) but these are dijecta membra lacking organic connection.
positions.text: Previous theories provide scattered characteristics (activity, playful judgement, coupling dissimilar things, contrasting ideas, sense in nonsense, bewilderment/enlightenment, bringing forward hidden, peculiar brevity) but these are dijecta membra lacking organic connection.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: There is intimate connection between all mental happenings; a psychological discovery even in a remote field like jokes will be of unpredictable value in other fields.
positions.text: There is intimate connection between all mental happenings; a psychological discovery even in a remote field like jokes will be of unpredictable value in other fields.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: A new joke acts almost like an event of universal interest, passed from person to person like news of latest victory; even men of eminence report excellent jokes in their autobiographies.
positions.text: A new joke acts almost like an event of universal interest, passed from person to person like news of latest victory; even men of eminence report excellent jokes in their autobiographies.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: The character of being a joke may lie either in the thought itself or in the expression given to the thought; to understand jokes, we must determine whether joking resides in form or content.
positions.text: The character of being a joke may lie either in the thought itself or in the expression given to the thought; to understand jokes, we must determine whether joking resides in form or content.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: In Heine's 'famillionairely' joke, the joking character lies entirely in the form of expression, not in the thought; translating the thought into other words destroys the joke entirely, though the sense remains.
positions.text: In Heine's 'famillionairely' joke, the joking character lies entirely in the form of expression, not in the thought; translating the thought into other words destroys the joke entirely, though the sense remains.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: 'Famillionairely' is a composite word - a condensation; it fuses 'familiär' (familiarly) and 'Millionär' (millionaire), with the overlapping syllable 'iliär'/'ilionär' serving as the point of fusion.
positions.text: 'Famillionairely' is a composite word - a condensation; it fuses 'familiär' (familiarly) and 'Millionär' (millionaire), with the overlapping syllable 'iliär'/'ilionär' serving as the point of fusion.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: The technique of condensation with substitute-formation is the essence of verbal jokes; this same technique operates in dream-work, establishing fundamental connection between jokes and dreams.
positions.text: The technique of condensation with substitute-formation is the essence of verbal jokes; this same technique operates in dream-work, establishing fundamental connection between jokes and dreams.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Condensation jokes create economy in psychical expenditure; the pleasure in jokes derives from this economy - what was previously divided is now united, requiring less psychical effort.
positions.text: Condensation jokes create economy in psychical expenditure; the pleasure in jokes derives from this economy - what was previously divided is now united, requiring less psychical effort.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Multiple use of same material is a widespread joke technique: same word or material repeated whole or with slight modification, appearing in double application (once with changed application, once with original meaning).
positions.text: Multiple use of same material is a widespread joke technique: same word or material repeated whole or with slight modification, appearing in double application (once with changed application, once with original meaning).
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Double meaning jokes exploit the richness of language, using ambiguity where the same word has multiple meanings or where similar-sounding words carry different meanings (name/meaning double use, metaphorical/literal double use).
positions.text: Double meaning jokes exploit the richness of language, using ambiguity where the same word has multiple meanings or where similar-sounding words carry different meanings (name/meaning double use, metaphorical/literal double use).
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Displacement jokes involve diversion of train of thought - the joke answer moves along different path from what was expected, often involving shift from one category to another or sudden change in psychical attitude.
positions.text: Displacement jokes involve diversion of train of thought - the joke answer moves along different path from what was expected, often involving shift from one category to another or sudden change in psychical attitude.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Representation by opposite is a common joke technique; saying the opposite of what one wants to convey, with tone and accompanying gestures making the true meaning clear.
positions.text: Representation by opposite is a common joke technique; saying the opposite of what one wants to convey, with tone and accompanying gestures making the true meaning clear.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Nonsense jokes produce the comic effect through bewilderment followed by illumination; what initially appears nonsensical is revealed to have sense under certain conditions or from particular viewpoint.
positions.text: Nonsense jokes produce the comic effect through bewilderment followed by illumination; what initially appears nonsensical is revealed to have sense under certain conditions or from particular viewpoint.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: All jokes techniques can be reduced to two principles: condensation (with or without substitute-formation) and multiple use of same material; these same processes appear in dream-work.
positions.text: All jokes techniques can be reduced to two principles: condensation (with or without substitute-formation) and multiple use of same material; these same processes appear in dream-work.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Conceptual jokes (where joking lies in thought rather than form) operate through faulty reasoning, displacement of psychical accent, absurdity, representation by opposite, and indirect representation.
positions.text: Conceptual jokes (where joking lies in thought rather than form) operate through faulty reasoning, displacement of psychical accent, absurdity, representation by opposite, and indirect representation.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Tendency jokes serve to make something ridiculous, aggressive, cynical, or skeptical, allowing expression of impulses that social inhibitions would otherwise prevent; they evade restrictions and open up sources of pleasure that have become inaccessible.
positions.text: Tendency jokes serve to make something ridiculous, aggressive, cynical, or skeptical, allowing expression of impulses that social inhibitions would otherwise prevent; they evade restrictions and open up sources of pleasure that have become inaccessible.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Obscene jokes make repressed sexual material capable of becoming conscious; the third person's laughter demonstrates that censorship has been overcome - repressed impulse can achieve representation despite inhibitions.
positions.text: Obscene jokes make repressed sexual material capable of becoming conscious; the third person's laughter demonstrates that censorship has been overcome - repressed impulse can achieve representation despite inhibitions.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Hostile jokes (serving aggression, satire, defense) permit enemy's disparagement with circumvention of restrictions; they represent rebellion against authority and liberation from its pressure.
positions.text: Hostile jokes (serving aggression, satire, defense) permit enemy's disparagement with circumvention of restrictions; they represent rebellion against authority and liberation from its pressure.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Cynical jokes attack not persons but institutions, dogmas, moral/religious precepts respected as binding by society; they undermine respect for these authorities by revealing their other side.
positions.text: Cynical jokes attack not persons but institutions, dogmas, moral/religious precepts respected as binding by society; they undermine respect for these authorities by revealing their other side.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Skeptical jokes attack certainty of our knowledge itself, directed against philosophical speculation that tends to lose sight of uncertainties in reality.
positions.text: Skeptical jokes attack certainty of our knowledge itself, directed against philosophical speculation that tends to lose sight of uncertainties in reality.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: The pleasure in jokes derives from three sources: (1) saving of psychical expenditure through technique (economy); (2) lifting of inhibitions allowing previously inaccessible pleasure sources; (3) pre-pleasure serving as incentive premium to release greater pleasure from removal of internal inhibitions.
positions.text: The pleasure in jokes derives from three sources: (1) saving of psychical expenditure through technique (economy); (2) lifting of inhibitions allowing previously inaccessible pleasure sources; (3) pre-pleasure serving as incentive premium to release greater pleasure from removal of internal inhibitions.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Innocent jokes derive their pleasure entirely from their technique (economy of psychical expenditure); tendentious jokes obtain additional pleasure from lifting inhibitions and freeing previously suppressed impulses.
positions.text: Innocent jokes derive their pleasure entirely from their technique (economy of psychical expenditure); tendentious jokes obtain additional pleasure from lifting inhibitions and freeing previously suppressed impulses.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Jokes require three persons: the joke-maker, the object of hostile/sexual aggressiveness, and the person in whom the joke's purpose of producing pleasure is fulfilled; the third person's laughter is essential.
positions.text: Jokes require three persons: the joke-maker, the object of hostile/sexual aggressiveness, and the person in whom the joke's purpose of producing pleasure is fulfilled; the third person's laughter is essential.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: The third person must possess similar psychical constellation as joke-maker, including similar internal inhibitions; jokes fail if this similarity is absent, as when told to person from different culture or to children lacking adult repressions.
positions.text: The third person must possess similar psychical constellation as joke-maker, including similar internal inhibitions; jokes fail if this similarity is absent, as when told to person from different culture or to children lacking adult repressions.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Laughter expresses a pleasurable discharge of psychical energy; the energy saved by joke technique or freed by lifting inhibitions is discharged in laughter if not used for other psychical work.
positions.text: Laughter expresses a pleasurable discharge of psychical energy; the energy saved by joke technique or freed by lifting inhibitions is discharged in laughter if not used for other psychical work.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: The social nature of jokes explains why no one is content with making a joke for himself alone; the urge to tell the joke to someone is inseparable from the joke-work, compulsion to communicate being connected with the joke's purpose.
positions.text: The social nature of jokes explains why no one is content with making a joke for himself alone; the urge to tell the joke to someone is inseparable from the joke-work, compulsion to communicate being connected with the joke's purpose.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Jokes and dreams share fundamental mechanisms; both employ condensation, displacement, indirect representation, and representation by opposite - the mechanisms of primary process thinking.
positions.text: Jokes and dreams share fundamental mechanisms; both employ condensation, displacement, indirect representation, and representation by opposite - the mechanisms of primary process thinking.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: The difference between jokes and dreams lies in their social aims: dreams are completely asocial products serving no social purpose, while jokes are the most social of all mental functions aimed at obtaining pleasure and requiring other people.
positions.text: The difference between jokes and dreams lies in their social aims: dreams are completely asocial products serving no social purpose, while jokes are the most social of all mental functions aimed at obtaining pleasure and requiring other people.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Dreams arise from compromise between repressed wishes seeking fulfillment and resistance of censoring agency; they remain unintelligible because the wish they represent has been distorted by resistance, reduced to allusions and approximations.
positions.text: Dreams arise from compromise between repressed wishes seeking fulfillment and resistance of censoring agency; they remain unintelligible because the wish they represent has been distorted by resistance, reduced to allusions and approximations.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Jokes also make use of distortion, but do not submit to restriction; they avoid repression by ingeniously choosing words and constellations of thought situations that enable forbidden thought to pass censorship unmodified.
positions.text: Jokes also make use of distortion, but do not submit to restriction; they avoid repression by ingeniously choosing words and constellations of thought situations that enable forbidden thought to pass censorship unmodified.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Joke-work does not create compromises but operates with complete freedom in choice of words, exploiting all possibilities of word-usage and verbal connections - liberties avoided in conscious thought.
positions.text: Joke-work does not create compromises but operates with complete freedom in choice of words, exploiting all possibilities of word-usage and verbal connections - liberties avoided in conscious thought.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: The genesis of jokes proceeds from pre-conscious thought being given over for a moment to unconscious revision; the joke arises when pre-conscious thought is worked over by primary process mechanisms.
positions.text: The genesis of jokes proceeds from pre-conscious thought being given over for a moment to unconscious revision; the joke arises when pre-conscious thought is worked over by primary process mechanisms.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Children do not possess jokes in true sense; what children call jokes are playful activities using words without concern for meaning, enjoying pure sound-pleasure and movement-pleasure of speech apparatus.
positions.text: Children do not possess jokes in true sense; what children call jokes are playful activities using words without concern for meaning, enjoying pure sound-pleasure and movement-pleasure of speech apparatus.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Children find pleasure in constant repetition of similarity and in rediscovering the familiar; adults abandon such pleasures under pressure of critical reason, but jokes allow temporary recovery of these abandoned pleasures through circumvention of inhibitions.
positions.text: Children find pleasure in constant repetition of similarity and in rediscovering the familiar; adults abandon such pleasures under pressure of critical reason, but jokes allow temporary recovery of these abandoned pleasures through circumvention of inhibitions.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Jokes represent regression to childhood sources of pleasure now forbidden by critical reason; through joking technique, we temporarily suspend inhibitions and momentarily return to infantile modes of thought and pleasure.
positions.text: Jokes represent regression to childhood sources of pleasure now forbidden by critical reason; through joking technique, we temporarily suspend inhibitions and momentarily return to infantile modes of thought and pleasure.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: The comic arises from comparison between two expenditures of psychical energy - one's own and another person's (in the case of comic of movement or situation), or between one's present state and a former state (in comic of expectation).
positions.text: The comic arises from comparison between two expenditures of psychical energy - one's own and another person's (in the case of comic of movement or situation), or between one's present state and a former state (in comic of expectation).
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: The comic of movement arises when we perceive in another person expenditure greater than we judge necessary; we laugh at the 'too much' of their exertion or the 'too little' of their achievement.
positions.text: The comic of movement arises when we perceive in another person expenditure greater than we judge necessary; we laugh at the 'too much' of their exertion or the 'too little' of their achievement.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Degradation or debasing of the sublime is fundamental mechanism of the comic; bringing down something from higher to lower level (from intellectual to physical, from adult to childish, from human to animal) produces comic effect.
positions.text: Degradation or debasing of the sublime is fundamental mechanism of the comic; bringing down something from higher to lower level (from intellectual to physical, from adult to childish, from human to animal) produces comic effect.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Caricature achieves degradation by emphasizing single feature which is comic in itself, sacrificing other features and substituting that which is low for what is high - but this is permissible only when the lowly is simultaneously high.
positions.text: Caricature achieves degradation by emphasizing single feature which is comic in itself, sacrificing other features and substituting that which is low for what is high - but this is permissible only when the lowly is simultaneously high.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Parody and travesty achieve degradation of something exalted by two methods: (1) destroying unity of character by replacing high elements with low ones (travesty); (2) maintaining form but replacing high content with low content (parody).
positions.text: Parody and travesty achieve degradation of something exalted by two methods: (1) destroying unity of character by replacing high elements with low ones (travesty); (2) maintaining form but replacing high content with low content (parody).
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Imitation produces comic effect when imitator puts out more expenditure than object; imitation becomes comic only when combined with caricature - when emphasizing feature not prominent in original.
positions.text: Imitation produces comic effect when imitator puts out more expenditure than object; imitation becomes comic only when combined with caricature - when emphasizing feature not prominent in original.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Naiveté produces comic effect when someone completely disregards an inhibition because it does not exist for them; we laugh at the economy they have achieved compared to our own necessity of maintaining the inhibition.
positions.text: Naiveté produces comic effect when someone completely disregards an inhibition because it does not exist for them; we laugh at the economy they have achieved compared to our own necessity of maintaining the inhibition.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Humour is a means of obtaining pleasure in spite of distressing affects that interfere with it; humour prevents outbreak of affect, displaces cathexis from pain-producing content to other ideas, and thus economizes on expenditure of emotion.
positions.text: Humour is a means of obtaining pleasure in spite of distressing affects that interfere with it; humour prevents outbreak of affect, displaces cathexis from pain-producing content to other ideas, and thus economizes on expenditure of emotion.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Humour represents triumph of narcissism - the ego's victorious assertion of its invulnerability, refusing to be distressed by provocations of reality or compelled to suffer, maintaining pleasure principle despite external trauma.
positions.text: Humour represents triumph of narcissism - the ego's victorious assertion of its invulnerability, refusing to be distressed by provocations of reality or compelled to suffer, maintaining pleasure principle despite external trauma.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Humour has something liberating about it but also something of grandeur and elevation lacking in other methods of obtaining pleasure from mental activity; this grandeur lies in triumph of narcissism and ego's invincibility.
positions.text: Humour has something liberating about it but also something of grandeur and elevation lacking in other methods of obtaining pleasure from mental activity; this grandeur lies in triumph of narcissism and ego's invincibility.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Jokes, the comic, and humour all produce pleasure through economizing psychical expenditure; they differ in psychological situation: jokes create economy through technique, the comic through comparison, humour through affect-displacement.
positions.text: Jokes, the comic, and humour all produce pleasure through economizing psychical expenditure; they differ in psychological situation: jokes create economy through technique, the comic through comparison, humour through affect-displacement.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Jokes are made (produced with intention and effort); the comic is found (discovered in people, situations, or actions); humour is both made and found - the humorous attitude being adopted deliberately.
positions.text: Jokes are made (produced with intention and effort); the comic is found (discovered in people, situations, or actions); humour is both made and found - the humorous attitude being adopted deliberately.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Jokes serve principally to produce pleasure through their technique and by freeing repressed impulses; the comic aims at obtaining pleasure through intellectual comparison; humour serves to avoid unpleasure that would arise from affect.
positions.text: Jokes serve principally to produce pleasure through their technique and by freeing repressed impulses; the comic aims at obtaining pleasure through intellectual comparison; humour serves to avoid unpleasure that would arise from affect.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: The joke-work transforms pre-conscious thought by handing it over momentarily to the unconscious for revision; this accounts for apparent spontaneity and sudden illumination characteristic of jokes.
positions.text: The joke-work transforms pre-conscious thought by handing it over momentarily to the unconscious for revision; this accounts for apparent spontaneity and sudden illumination characteristic of jokes.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Understanding a joke requires recognizing its technique; the hearer must perform an unconscious operation opposite to the joke-work, reconstructing what was condensed or displaced, thus re-experiencing the economy that produced pleasure in the joke-maker.
positions.text: Understanding a joke requires recognizing its technique; the hearer must perform an unconscious operation opposite to the joke-work, reconstructing what was condensed or displaced, thus re-experiencing the economy that produced pleasure in the joke-maker.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Wit (joking ability) requires not only intelligence but special talent; capacity for joke-making is unevenly distributed and many intelligent people lack it entirely, suggesting dependence on particular psychical constitution.
positions.text: Wit (joking ability) requires not only intelligence but special talent; capacity for joke-making is unevenly distributed and many intelligent people lack it entirely, suggesting dependence on particular psychical constitution.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Witty people possess easier access to infantile sources of pleasure and have lesser resistance between unconscious and pre-conscious thought; their capacity depends on constitutional factors allowing temporary regression to primary process thinking.
positions.text: Witty people possess easier access to infantile sources of pleasure and have lesser resistance between unconscious and pre-conscious thought; their capacity depends on constitutional factors allowing temporary regression to primary process thinking.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Good jokes are found more often among oppressed peoples (Jews) because jokes serve to express criticism and rebellion against authority; when direct aggression is forbidden, hostile jokes flourish as substitute satisfaction.
positions.text: Good jokes are found more often among oppressed peoples (Jews) because jokes serve to express criticism and rebellion against authority; when direct aggression is forbidden, hostile jokes flourish as substitute satisfaction.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: The most favorable condition for joke-production is cheerful toxic state (slight alcohol intoxication), which loosens inhibitions and facilitates access to unconscious thought processes without impairing intellectual functions.
positions.text: The most favorable condition for joke-production is cheerful toxic state (slight alcohol intoxication), which loosens inhibitions and facilitates access to unconscious thought processes without impairing intellectual functions.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Jokes cannot be translated successfully into other languages because they depend on specific linguistic features (sound, multiple meanings, idiomatic expressions) that have no equivalents; only conceptual jokes translate reasonably.
positions.text: Jokes cannot be translated successfully into other languages because they depend on specific linguistic features (sound, multiple meanings, idiomatic expressions) that have no equivalents; only conceptual jokes translate reasonably.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Hostile jokes against oneself (self-criticism jokes) represent modified self-aggression; they express hostility originally directed toward external object now turned upon self, or defensive reversal of aggression through humorous acceptance.
positions.text: Hostile jokes against oneself (self-criticism jokes) represent modified self-aggression; they express hostility originally directed toward external object now turned upon self, or defensive reversal of aggression through humorous acceptance.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Jewish jokes made by Jews themselves often contain harsh self-criticism that would be offensive coming from outsiders; they represent democratic leveling that prevents idealization and maintains realistic self-assessment within the group.
positions.text: Jewish jokes made by Jews themselves often contain harsh self-criticism that would be offensive coming from outsiders; they represent democratic leveling that prevents idealization and maintains realistic self-assessment within the group.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: The pleasure in smut derives from exposure of sexually different person to whom the smut is directed; smut originally served courtship function, but when direct sexual satisfaction became impossible, persisted as regression to infantile sexual interest.
positions.text: The pleasure in smut derives from exposure of sexually different person to whom the smut is directed; smut originally served courtship function, but when direct sexual satisfaction became impossible, persisted as regression to infantile sexual interest.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Obscene jokes require three persons because direct sexual approach between two persons has been inhibited by civilization; the third person allows forbidden impulse expression through laughter, confirming that repression has been circumvented.
positions.text: Obscene jokes require three persons because direct sexual approach between two persons has been inhibited by civilization; the third person allows forbidden impulse expression through laughter, confirming that repression has been circumvented.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: The stricter the censorship, the more sophisticated must be the joke technique; in times of strong repression, jokes that evade censorship through clever disguise give greatest pleasure.
positions.text: The stricter the censorship, the more sophisticated must be the joke technique; in times of strong repression, jokes that evade censorship through clever disguise give greatest pleasure.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: The compulsion to tell jokes indicates their service to the pleasure principle; the joke-maker must communicate the joke because he cannot fully enjoy his own creation without the confirming laughter of the listener.
positions.text: The compulsion to tell jokes indicates their service to the pleasure principle; the joke-maker must communicate the joke because he cannot fully enjoy his own creation without the confirming laughter of the listener.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Good listeners become crucial to joke-tellers; the ideal listener possesses similar inhibitions and repressions, ensuring psychical resonance that allows the joke to produce full effect.
positions.text: Good listeners become crucial to joke-tellers; the ideal listener possesses similar inhibitions and repressions, ensuring psychical resonance that allows the joke to produce full effect.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Professional joke-tellers and comedians exploit jokes parasitically; they experience attenuated pleasure themselves but live from the greater pleasure their performance generates in audiences.
positions.text: Professional joke-tellers and comedians exploit jokes parasitically; they experience attenuated pleasure themselves but live from the greater pleasure their performance generates in audiences.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Context and mood profoundly affect joke appreciation; the same joke may be hilarious in one situation and fall flat in another, depending on current inhibitions, recent experiences, and group atmosphere.
positions.text: Context and mood profoundly affect joke appreciation; the same joke may be hilarious in one situation and fall flat in another, depending on current inhibitions, recent experiences, and group atmosphere.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Tendentious jokes serve ego's purposes more directly than innocent jokes; they allow expression of aggression, criticism, and sexual impulses that would otherwise be prohibited, making them psychologically more significant despite lesser technical refinement.
positions.text: Tendentious jokes serve ego's purposes more directly than innocent jokes; they allow expression of aggression, criticism, and sexual impulses that would otherwise be prohibited, making them psychologically more significant despite lesser technical refinement.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Cynical jokes attacking institutions and authorities reveal the ambivalence underlying social conformity; they express doubt and criticism that conscious thought suppresses out of prudence or fear.
positions.text: Cynical jokes attacking institutions and authorities reveal the ambivalence underlying social conformity; they express doubt and criticism that conscious thought suppresses out of prudence or fear.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Joke technique of 'faulty thinking' deliberately employs logical errors (false analogy, faulty inference, confusion of part and whole) to achieve comic effect while suggesting hidden truth beneath apparent nonsense.
positions.text: Joke technique of 'faulty thinking' deliberately employs logical errors (false analogy, faulty inference, confusion of part and whole) to achieve comic effect while suggesting hidden truth beneath apparent nonsense.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Sophistic jokes use formally correct reasoning to reach absurd conclusions, exposing weaknesses in logical argumentation and demonstrating how reason can be manipulated to serve unconscious purposes.
positions.text: Sophistic jokes use formally correct reasoning to reach absurd conclusions, exposing weaknesses in logical argumentation and demonstrating how reason can be manipulated to serve unconscious purposes.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: The technique of 'unification' brings together disparate elements that share unexpected similarity; this mirrors the work of unconscious thinking which ignores contradictions and finds connections conscious thought overlooks.
positions.text: The technique of 'unification' brings together disparate elements that share unexpected similarity; this mirrors the work of unconscious thinking which ignores contradictions and finds connections conscious thought overlooks.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Indirect representation in jokes parallels dream symbolism; forbidden content is expressed through allusion, analogy, or substitute that maintains connection to original while evading censorship.
positions.text: Indirect representation in jokes parallels dream symbolism; forbidden content is expressed through allusion, analogy, or substitute that maintains connection to original while evading censorship.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Jokes of unification create pleasure by momentarily restoring the primitive unity of thinking that preceded the differentiation between conscious and unconscious processes.
positions.text: Jokes of unification create pleasure by momentarily restoring the primitive unity of thinking that preceded the differentiation between conscious and unconscious processes.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: The best jokes combine technical excellence with significant tendentious purpose; pure technique without purpose yields only mild amusement, while pure tendency without technique appears merely aggressive or obscene.
positions.text: The best jokes combine technical excellence with significant tendentious purpose; pure technique without purpose yields only mild amusement, while pure tendency without technique appears merely aggressive or obscene.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Jokes lose effectiveness through repetition because the economy they create depends on surprise; once the technique is known, no psychical expenditure is saved and pleasure diminishes.
positions.text: Jokes lose effectiveness through repetition because the economy they create depends on surprise; once the technique is known, no psychical expenditure is saved and pleasure diminishes.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: The technique of 'displacement of psychical accent' moves emphasis from important to trivial element; this mimics a defensive process where dangerous material is avoided by focusing attention elsewhere.
positions.text: The technique of 'displacement of psychical accent' moves emphasis from important to trivial element; this mimics a defensive process where dangerous material is avoided by focusing attention elsewhere.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Jokes exploit ambiguity not just in words but in logic itself; they demonstrate that same thought material can yield opposite conclusions depending on perspective or framing.
positions.text: Jokes exploit ambiguity not just in words but in logic itself; they demonstrate that same thought material can yield opposite conclusions depending on perspective or framing.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: The comic feeling arises when we expect large psychical expenditure but find small one sufficient; we laugh at this pleasant surprise of finding things easier than anticipated.
positions.text: The comic feeling arises when we expect large psychical expenditure but find small one sufficient; we laugh at this pleasant surprise of finding things easier than anticipated.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Comic of situation arises from comparison between effort we imagine necessary and actual effort observed; when someone uses roundabout path to simple goal, we laugh at wasted expenditure.
positions.text: Comic of situation arises from comparison between effort we imagine necessary and actual effort observed; when someone uses roundabout path to simple goal, we laugh at wasted expenditure.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Mimicry and imitation produce comic effect through exaggeration of non-essential features; the imitator expends more energy than necessary, allowing audience to enjoy the surplus expenditure.
positions.text: Mimicry and imitation produce comic effect through exaggeration of non-essential features; the imitator expends more energy than necessary, allowing audience to enjoy the surplus expenditure.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Idealization prevents comic effect by demanding we ignore faults and exaggerate virtues; comic thrives on realistic observation that notes every disproportion and inadequacy.
positions.text: Idealization prevents comic effect by demanding we ignore faults and exaggerate virtues; comic thrives on realistic observation that notes every disproportion and inadequacy.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Children's utterances become comic for adults when child violates inhibitions adults possess; naiveté allows expression of truths that social restrictions prevent adults from speaking.
positions.text: Children's utterances become comic for adults when child violates inhibitions adults possess; naiveté allows expression of truths that social restrictions prevent adults from speaking.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Sexual naiveté of children provides adults with pleasure of seeing uninhibited expression of sexual curiosity and interest; this pleasure combines comic (from lack of inhibition) with voyeuristic satisfaction.
positions.text: Sexual naiveté of children provides adults with pleasure of seeing uninhibited expression of sexual curiosity and interest; this pleasure combines comic (from lack of inhibition) with voyeuristic satisfaction.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Humour's mechanism involves adopting attitude of adult toward child, treating one's own ego as child and taking up position of adult who has superior perspective on life's troubles.
positions.text: Humour's mechanism involves adopting attitude of adult toward child, treating one's own ego as child and taking up position of adult who has superior perspective on life's troubles.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Gallows humour represents extreme case where person about to die makes joke about execution; this demonstrates ego's refusal to let reality traumatize it, maintaining pleasure principle despite imminent annihilation.
positions.text: Gallows humour represents extreme case where person about to die makes joke about execution; this demonstrates ego's refusal to let reality traumatize it, maintaining pleasure principle despite imminent annihilation.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Humour is not resigned but rebellious; it signifies not only ego's triumph over suffering but also triumph of pleasure principle, which asserts itself despite unfavorable reality.
positions.text: Humour is not resigned but rebellious; it signifies not only ego's triumph over suffering but also triumph of pleasure principle, which asserts itself despite unfavorable reality.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: The capacity for humour is rare and represents one of highest psychical achievements; not everyone possesses the mental constitution allowing ego to adopt humorous attitude toward suffering.
positions.text: The capacity for humour is rare and represents one of highest psychical achievements; not everyone possesses the mental constitution allowing ego to adopt humorous attitude toward suffering.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Humour can be directed at oneself or at others; in both cases it represents empathy - either with one's own suffering ego or with another's, adopting superior viewpoint that diminishes the suffering.
positions.text: Humour can be directed at oneself or at others; in both cases it represents empathy - either with one's own suffering ego or with another's, adopting superior viewpoint that diminishes the suffering.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Jokes provide window into unconscious mental processes; by studying joke techniques, we learn how unconscious thinking operates - through condensation, displacement, and disregard for logical constraints.
positions.text: Jokes provide window into unconscious mental processes; by studying joke techniques, we learn how unconscious thinking operates - through condensation, displacement, and disregard for logical constraints.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: The study of jokes confirms fundamental psychoanalytic principles: the power of unconscious processes, the role of repression in creating psychical conflict, and the constant seeking of pleasure through indirect paths.
positions.text: The study of jokes confirms fundamental psychoanalytic principles: the power of unconscious processes, the role of repression in creating psychical conflict, and the constant seeking of pleasure through indirect paths.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Jokes demonstrate that no psychical act is purposeless; even seemingly trivial verbal play serves important functions of pleasure-seeking, aggression-discharge, and social bonding.
positions.text: Jokes demonstrate that no psychical act is purposeless; even seemingly trivial verbal play serves important functions of pleasure-seeking, aggression-discharge, and social bonding.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: The pleasure mechanism in jokes (economy of psychical expenditure) operates throughout mental life; any saving of energy - whether in thinking, perceiving, or acting - tends to produce pleasurable feeling.
positions.text: The pleasure mechanism in jokes (economy of psychical expenditure) operates throughout mental life; any saving of energy - whether in thinking, perceiving, or acting - tends to produce pleasurable feeling.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Jokes reveal the fundamental opposition between instinctual demands and civilized restrictions; they survive as artifacts of this conflict, representing successful compromises that satisfy both sides.
positions.text: Jokes reveal the fundamental opposition between instinctual demands and civilized restrictions; they survive as artifacts of this conflict, representing successful compromises that satisfy both sides.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: The universal appeal of certain jokes across cultures suggests common human repressions and universal structure of unconscious processes; despite cultural differences, fundamental conflicts and defenses remain similar.
positions.text: The universal appeal of certain jokes across cultures suggests common human repressions and universal structure of unconscious processes; despite cultural differences, fundamental conflicts and defenses remain similar.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Joke appreciation requires temporary suspension of critical faculties; we must allow ourselves to regress to primary process thinking while retaining enough secondary process to recognize the technique.
positions.text: Joke appreciation requires temporary suspension of critical faculties; we must allow ourselves to regress to primary process thinking while retaining enough secondary process to recognize the technique.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: The laughter of the joke-hearer serves communicative function; it signals to the joke-teller that the joke succeeded, that censorship was circumvented, and that repressed material achieved representation.
positions.text: The laughter of the joke-hearer serves communicative function; it signals to the joke-teller that the joke succeeded, that censorship was circumvented, and that repressed material achieved representation.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Jokes occupy intermediate position between conscious and unconscious mental activity; they are consciously created yet employ unconscious mechanisms, produced deliberately yet require spontaneous inspiration from unconscious sources.
positions.text: Jokes occupy intermediate position between conscious and unconscious mental activity; they are consciously created yet employ unconscious mechanisms, produced deliberately yet require spontaneous inspiration from unconscious sources.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: The ultimate significance of jokes lies in demonstrating that pleasure remains possible despite civilization's restrictions; they prove that renunciation need not be complete, that infantile sources of satisfaction remain accessible through ingenuity.
positions.text: The ultimate significance of jokes lies in demonstrating that pleasure remains possible despite civilization's restrictions; they prove that renunciation need not be complete, that infantile sources of satisfaction remain accessible through ingenuity.
positions.work: JOKES AND THEIR RELATION TO THE UNCONSCIOUS

positions.title: Creative writers are valuable allies in psychological understanding because they draw upon sources of knowledge about the mind that science has not yet accessed, being far in advance of everyday people in their knowledge of mental processes.
positions.text: Creative writers are valuable allies in psychological understanding because they draw upon sources of knowledge about the mind that science has not yet accessed, being far in advance of everyday people in their knowledge of mental processes.
positions.work: DELUSIONS AND DREAMS IN JENSEN'S GRADIVA

positions.title: There is far less freedom and arbitrariness in mental life than commonly assumed - perhaps none at all. What appears as chance in external world and arbitrariness in mind both rest upon laws we are only beginning to suspect.
positions.text: There is far less freedom and arbitrariness in mental life than commonly assumed - perhaps none at all. What appears as chance in external world and arbitrariness in mind both rest upon laws we are only beginning to suspect.
positions.work: DELUSIONS AND DREAMS IN JENSEN'S GRADIVA

positions.title: Fictional characters constructed by imaginative writers can be analyzed using psychoanalytic principles as though they were real people, since authors follow everyday experience in depicting mental processes and draw on genuine psychological knowledge.
positions.text: Fictional characters constructed by imaginative writers can be analyzed using psychoanalytic principles as though they were real people, since authors follow everyday experience in depicting mental processes and draw on genuine psychological knowledge.
positions.work: DELUSIONS AND DREAMS IN JENSEN'S GRADIVA

positions.title: There is no better analogy for repression, by which something in the mind is at once made inaccessible and preserved, than the burial experienced by Pompeii, from which the buried could emerge again through archaeological excavation.
positions.text: There is no better analogy for repression, by which something in the mind is at once made inaccessible and preserved, than the burial experienced by Pompeii, from which the buried could emerge again through archaeological excavation.
positions.work: DELUSIONS AND DREAMS IN JENSEN'S GRADIVA

positions.title: The return of repressed material is accomplished through a remarkable mechanism: it is precisely what was chosen as the instrument of repression that becomes the vehicle for the return. In and behind the repressing force, what is repressed proves itself victor in the end.
positions.text: The return of repressed material is accomplished through a remarkable mechanism: it is precisely what was chosen as the instrument of repression that becomes the vehicle for the return. In and behind the repressing force, what is repressed proves itself victor in the end.
positions.work: DELUSIONS AND DREAMS IN JENSEN'S GRADIVA

positions.title: In states of repression, the human mind becomes extraordinarily sensitive to any approach by what has been repressed, such that even trivial similarities suffice for the repressed to emerge behind the repressing force and take effect by means of it.
positions.text: In states of repression, the human mind becomes extraordinarily sensitive to any approach by what has been repressed, such that even trivial similarities suffice for the repressed to emerge behind the repressing force and take effect by means of it.
positions.work: DELUSIONS AND DREAMS IN JENSEN'S GRADIVA

positions.title: When patients' delusional compulsion is loosened by revealing the repressed material lying behind it, they themselves bring forward solutions to the final and most important riddles of their condition through sudden ideas that occur to them.
positions.text: When patients' delusional compulsion is loosened by revealing the repressed material lying behind it, they themselves bring forward solutions to the final and most important riddles of their condition through sudden ideas that occur to them.
positions.work: DELUSIONS AND DREAMS IN JENSEN'S GRADIVA

positions.title: A loss of memory for previous attitudes and feelings is the most trustworthy sign that a genuine transformation of attitude has occurred.
positions.text: A loss of memory for previous attitudes and feelings is the most trustworthy sign that a genuine transformation of attitude has occurred.
positions.work: DELUSIONS AND DREAMS IN JENSEN'S GRADIVA

positions.title: Obsessive actions appear foolish and senseless on the surface, but psychoanalytic investigation reveals that they are perfectly significant in every detail, serving important interests of the personality and giving expression to operative experiences and affect-laden thoughts through either direct or symbolic representation.
positions.text: Obsessive actions appear foolish and senseless on the surface, but psychoanalytic investigation reveals that they are perfectly significant in every detail, serving important interests of the personality and giving expression to operative experiences and affect-laden thoughts through either direct or symbolic representation.

positions.title: Neurotic ceremonials resemble religious rituals in their conscientiousness, isolation from other actions, prohibition against interruption, and the anxiety provoked by their neglect, but differ in being private rather than communal and apparently meaningless rather than symbolic.
positions.text: Neurotic ceremonials resemble religious rituals in their conscientiousness, isolation from other actions, prohibition against interruption, and the anxiety provoked by their neglect, but differ in being private rather than communal and apparently meaningless rather than symbolic.
