positions.title: Psycho-analysis has interest for biology in demonstrating the fundamental bisexuality of human beings - both physical and psychological bisexual tendencies are present and influence sexual development and object-choice.
positions.text: Psycho-analysis has interest for biology in demonstrating the fundamental bisexuality of human beings - both physical and psychological bisexual tendencies are present and influence sexual development and object-choice.
positions.work: THE CLAIMS OF PSYCHO-ANALYSIS TO SCIENTIFIC INTEREST

positions.title: For the history of civilization, psycho-analysis shows that the development of culture depends upon restriction of instinctual satisfaction - cultural progress requires instinctual renunciation and sublimation.
positions.text: For the history of civilization, psycho-analysis shows that the development of culture depends upon restriction of instinctual satisfaction - cultural progress requires instinctual renunciation and sublimation.
positions.work: THE CLAIMS OF PSYCHO-ANALYSIS TO SCIENTIFIC INTEREST

positions.title: In the study of religion, psycho-analysis demonstrates that religious beliefs and practices derive from the same sources as neurotic symptoms - both represent attempts to master infantile conflicts, particularly those relating to the father.
positions.text: In the study of religion, psycho-analysis demonstrates that religious beliefs and practices derive from the same sources as neurotic symptoms - both represent attempts to master infantile conflicts, particularly those relating to the father.
positions.work: THE CLAIMS OF PSYCHO-ANALYSIS TO SCIENTIFIC INTEREST

positions.title: Psycho-analysis shows that mythology and folklore preserve collective unconscious phantasies - myths represent disguised wish-fulfillments of whole peoples, just as dreams represent wish-fulfillments of individuals.
positions.text: Psycho-analysis shows that mythology and folklore preserve collective unconscious phantasies - myths represent disguised wish-fulfillments of whole peoples, just as dreams represent wish-fulfillments of individuals.
positions.work: THE CLAIMS OF PSYCHO-ANALYSIS TO SCIENTIFIC INTEREST

positions.title: For aesthetics, psycho-analysis reveals that artistic creation involves regression to primary process thinking combined with masterful form - the artist reconciles infantile pleasure sources with mature technique.
positions.text: For aesthetics, psycho-analysis reveals that artistic creation involves regression to primary process thinking combined with masterful form - the artist reconciles infantile pleasure sources with mature technique.
positions.work: THE CLAIMS OF PSYCHO-ANALYSIS TO SCIENTIFIC INTEREST

positions.title: In education, psycho-analysis shows that early childhood experiences have lasting effects on character formation - education should aim at optimal management of instinctual forces rather than mere suppression.
positions.text: In education, psycho-analysis shows that early childhood experiences have lasting effects on character formation - education should aim at optimal management of instinctual forces rather than mere suppression.
positions.work: THE CLAIMS OF PSYCHO-ANALYSIS TO SCIENTIFIC INTEREST

positions.title: Psycho-analysis demonstrates to sociology that individual psychology and group psychology are fundamentally connected - social institutions arise from attempts to solve common psychological problems.
positions.text: Psycho-analysis demonstrates to sociology that individual psychology and group psychology are fundamentally connected - social institutions arise from attempts to solve common psychological problems.
positions.work: THE CLAIMS OF PSYCHO-ANALYSIS TO SCIENTIFIC INTEREST

positions.title: For jurisprudence, psycho-analysis shows that the concept of responsibility requires consideration of unconscious motivation - legal responsibility cannot be determined without understanding the unconscious forces behind actions.
positions.text: For jurisprudence, psycho-analysis shows that the concept of responsibility requires consideration of unconscious motivation - legal responsibility cannot be determined without understanding the unconscious forces behind actions.
positions.work: THE CLAIMS OF PSYCHO-ANALYSIS TO SCIENTIFIC INTEREST

positions.title: In psychiatry, psycho-analysis has shown that mental disorders previously thought meaningless have psychological meaning - every symptom serves a purpose in the patient's mental economy.
positions.text: In psychiatry, psycho-analysis has shown that mental disorders previously thought meaningless have psychological meaning - every symptom serves a purpose in the patient's mental economy.
positions.work: THE CLAIMS OF PSYCHO-ANALYSIS TO SCIENTIFIC INTEREST

positions.title: The position in which a person wakes from a dream often relates to the content of the dream and may represent a bodily expression of what was dreamed.
positions.text: The position in which a person wakes from a dream often relates to the content of the dream and may represent a bodily expression of what was dreamed.
positions.work: OBSERVATIONS AND EXAMPLES FROM ANALYTIC PRACTICE

positions.title: Self-criticism by neurotics often represents an internalized critical voice (superego precursor) directed against forbidden instinctual wishes - the patient attacks himself to avoid punishment from outside.
positions.text: Self-criticism by neurotics often represents an internalized critical voice (superego precursor) directed against forbidden instinctual wishes - the patient attacks himself to avoid punishment from outside.
positions.work: OBSERVATIONS AND EXAMPLES FROM ANALYTIC PRACTICE

positions.title: Dreams may condense or expand the representation of time - years may be represented as moments or moments as extended periods, reflecting the timelessness of unconscious processes.
positions.text: Dreams may condense or expand the representation of time - years may be represented as moments or moments as extended periods, reflecting the timelessness of unconscious processes.
positions.work: OBSERVATIONS AND EXAMPLES FROM ANALYTIC PRACTICE

positions.title: Two rooms in a dream often represent the two openings of the female body (mouth and genitals) or the transformation from 'two' (breasts, buttocks) to 'one' (genitals), expressing sexual symbolism through spatial representation.
positions.text: Two rooms in a dream often represent the two openings of the female body (mouth and genitals) or the transformation from 'two' (breasts, buttocks) to 'one' (genitals), expressing sexual symbolism through spatial representation.
positions.work: OBSERVATIONS AND EXAMPLES FROM ANALYTIC PRACTICE

positions.title: Fragmentary dreams that seem incomplete often defend against disturbing material by breaking off the dream narrative before reaching the anxiety-producing conclusion.
positions.text: Fragmentary dreams that seem incomplete often defend against disturbing material by breaking off the dream narrative before reaching the anxiety-producing conclusion.
positions.work: OBSERVATIONS AND EXAMPLES FROM ANALYTIC PRACTICE

positions.title: Dreams about dead people often fulfill wishes about their death or express guilt over having wished for their death - the dreamer's relationship with the deceased is re-experienced in the dream.
positions.text: Dreams about dead people often fulfill wishes about their death or express guilt over having wished for their death - the dreamer's relationship with the deceased is re-experienced in the dream.
positions.work: OBSERVATIONS AND EXAMPLES FROM ANALYTIC PRACTICE

positions.title: When symptoms of the illness appear in the dream, this often indicates that the symptoms are being used as day-residues to express unconscious wish-fulfillment - the symptom becomes material for dream-work.
positions.text: When symptoms of the illness appear in the dream, this often indicates that the symptoms are being used as day-residues to express unconscious wish-fulfillment - the symptom becomes material for dream-work.
positions.work: OBSERVATIONS AND EXAMPLES FROM ANALYTIC PRACTICE

positions.title: Overcoats in dreams typically symbolize condoms - the dream expresses sexual wishes or anxieties about sexual intercourse through the overcoat representation.
positions.text: Overcoats in dreams typically symbolize condoms - the dream expresses sexual wishes or anxieties about sexual intercourse through the overcoat representation.
positions.work: OBSERVATIONS AND EXAMPLES FROM ANALYTIC PRACTICE

positions.title: Shoes in dreams commonly represent the female genitals - dirty, torn, or disgraced shoes (feet) express devaluation or disgust toward sexuality.
positions.text: Shoes in dreams commonly represent the female genitals - dirty, torn, or disgraced shoes (feet) express devaluation or disgust toward sexuality.
positions.work: OBSERVATIONS AND EXAMPLES FROM ANALYTIC PRACTICE

positions.title: The representation of ages in dreams often condenses different time periods - a person may appear simultaneously at different ages, or one person's age may represent another's, expressing temporal displacement.
positions.text: The representation of ages in dreams often condenses different time periods - a person may appear simultaneously at different ages, or one person's age may represent another's, expressing temporal displacement.
positions.work: OBSERVATIONS AND EXAMPLES FROM ANALYTIC PRACTICE

positions.title: Dreams with an unrecognized precipitating cause often conceal distressing current events that the dreamer wishes to deny - the manifest dream obscures its connection to recent trauma.
positions.text: Dreams with an unrecognized precipitating cause often conceal distressing current events that the dreamer wishes to deny - the manifest dream obscures its connection to recent trauma.
positions.work: OBSERVATIONS AND EXAMPLES FROM ANALYTIC PRACTICE

positions.title: In folklore dreams, particularly those about bodily functions and sexuality, the dream-symbolism reveals unconscious equations between disparate bodily products and sexual elements that are shared across cultures.
positions.text: In folklore dreams, particularly those about bodily functions and sexuality, the dream-symbolism reveals unconscious equations between disparate bodily products and sexual elements that are shared across cultures.

positions.title: Penis symbolism appears commonly in folklore dreams through representations of elongated objects, tools, and weapons - the symbolic equation is evident across different cultural traditions.
positions.text: Penis symbolism appears commonly in folklore dreams through representations of elongated objects, tools, and weapons - the symbolic equation is evident across different cultural traditions.

positions.title: Faeces symbolism in dreams and folklore equates excrement with gold, money, and gifts - the unconscious preserves the infantile equation between bodily products and valuable possessions.
positions.text: Faeces symbolism in dreams and folklore equates excrement with gold, money, and gifts - the unconscious preserves the infantile equation between bodily products and valuable possessions.

positions.title: Dreams about finding treasure typically represent wish-fulfillments related to anal erotism and the discovery of one's own body - the treasure symbolizes valuable bodily products or sexual organs.
positions.text: Dreams about finding treasure typically represent wish-fulfillments related to anal erotism and the discovery of one's own body - the treasure symbolizes valuable bodily products or sexual organs.

positions.title: The ring in dreams and folklore commonly symbolizes the female genitals - stories about magic rings or rings of fidelity express unconscious phantasies about female sexuality.
positions.text: The ring in dreams and folklore commonly symbolizes the female genitals - stories about magic rings or rings of fidelity express unconscious phantasies about female sexuality.

positions.title: Educational experiences in adolescence (particularly at gymnasium/secondary school) leave lasting impressions because they occur during a time of heightened emotional receptivity and when the personality is being formed.
positions.text: Educational experiences in adolescence (particularly at gymnasium/secondary school) leave lasting impressions because they occur during a time of heightened emotional receptivity and when the personality is being formed.

positions.title: Teachers inevitably serve as father-substitutes for their students - the student's emotional relationship with teachers recapitulates and is determined by his relationship with his father.
positions.text: Teachers inevitably serve as father-substitutes for their students - the student's emotional relationship with teachers recapitulates and is determined by his relationship with his father.

positions.title: Students transfer onto their teachers the ambivalent feelings they harbor toward their fathers - they both admire and rebel against teachers with the same ambivalence that characterizes the father-son relationship.
positions.text: Students transfer onto their teachers the ambivalent feelings they harbor toward their fathers - they both admire and rebel against teachers with the same ambivalence that characterizes the father-son relationship.

positions.title: The liberation from parental authority is one of the most necessary but also most painful achievements of development - education aids this process by providing other authority figures (teachers) through whom the conflict with the father can be partially worked through.
positions.text: The liberation from parental authority is one of the most necessary but also most painful achievements of development - education aids this process by providing other authority figures (teachers) through whom the conflict with the father can be partially worked through.

positions.title: Former students' idealization of certain teachers and scorn for others reflects not the objective merits of these teachers but the students' own emotional needs and conflicts projected onto them.
positions.text: Former students' idealization of certain teachers and scorn for others reflects not the objective merits of these teachers but the students' own emotional needs and conflicts projected onto them.

positions.title: The significant psychological influence of teachers derives not from their knowledge but from their personalities - students are affected by the teacher as a person rather than by the subject matter taught.
positions.text: The significant psychological influence of teachers derives not from their knowledge but from their personalities - students are affected by the teacher as a person rather than by the subject matter taught.

positions.title: School experiences gain their significance from the fact that they represent the student's first major encounter with social organization outside the family - the school is the training ground for adult social life.
positions.text: School experiences gain their significance from the fact that they represent the student's first major encounter with social organization outside the family - the school is the training ground for adult social life.

positions.title: Students' ambivalent feelings toward their teachers protect them from being overwhelmed by exclusive attachment to their fathers - the distribution of ambivalence across multiple authority figures is developmentally beneficial.
positions.text: Students' ambivalent feelings toward their teachers protect them from being overwhelmed by exclusive attachment to their fathers - the distribution of ambivalence across multiple authority figures is developmentally beneficial.

positions.title: The psycho-analytic view of psychogenic disturbance demonstrates that conversion symptoms occur when the ego-instincts are overwhelmed by sexual instincts - the organ 'struck with repression' becomes unable to fulfill its ego-function.
positions.text: The psycho-analytic view of psychogenic disturbance demonstrates that conversion symptoms occur when the ego-instincts are overwhelmed by sexual instincts - the organ 'struck with repression' becomes unable to fulfill its ego-function.
positions.work: THE PSYCHO-ANALYTIC VIEW OF PSYCHOGENIC DISTURBANCE OF VISION

positions.title: The selection of the organ for conversion symptom is not arbitrary but determined by the specific role that organ plays in both ego-preservation and sexual gratification - the organ must serve both instinctual groups.
positions.text: The selection of the organ for conversion symptom is not arbitrary but determined by the specific role that organ plays in both ego-preservation and sexual gratification - the organ must serve both instinctual groups.
positions.work: THE PSYCHO-ANALYTIC VIEW OF PSYCHOGENIC DISTURBANCE OF VISION

positions.title: The relation of the eye to objects combines both functions - perception for self-preservation and scopophilic sexual pleasure - which is why it becomes a site for conversion symptoms when these functions conflict.
positions.text: The relation of the eye to objects combines both functions - perception for self-preservation and scopophilic sexual pleasure - which is why it becomes a site for conversion symptoms when these functions conflict.
positions.work: THE PSYCHO-ANALYTIC VIEW OF PSYCHOGENIC DISTURBANCE OF VISION

positions.title: In Schreber's delusional system, his transformation into God's wife and the subsequent redemption of the world through bearing divine offspring represents the ultimate fulfillment of his feminine homosexual wish toward his father, sublimated into religious-cosmic significance.
positions.text: In Schreber's delusional system, his transformation into God's wife and the subsequent redemption of the world through bearing divine offspring represents the ultimate fulfillment of his feminine homosexual wish toward his father, sublimated into religious-cosmic significance.

positions.title: The voices (Stimmenhören) experienced in paranoia and related conditions represent the auditory perception of thoughts - what should remain internal mental processes break through into consciousness as external voices.
positions.text: The voices (Stimmenhören) experienced in paranoia and related conditions represent the auditory perception of thoughts - what should remain internal mental processes break through into consciousness as external voices.

positions.title: Schreber's concept of 'soul murder' (Seelenmord) represents his unconscious perception of the psychological danger posed by submission to homosexual wishes - the fear that yielding to these wishes would destroy his masculine identity.
positions.text: Schreber's concept of 'soul murder' (Seelenmord) represents his unconscious perception of the psychological danger posed by submission to homosexual wishes - the fear that yielding to these wishes would destroy his masculine identity.

positions.title: The successful adaptation to reality in paranoia's reconstruction phase should not be mistaken for recovery - the delusional system represents a new pathological equilibrium rather than restoration of normal functioning.
positions.text: The successful adaptation to reality in paranoia's reconstruction phase should not be mistaken for recovery - the delusional system represents a new pathological equilibrium rather than restoration of normal functioning.

positions.title: Psycho-analysis is Freud's creation and remains fundamentally associated with hi...
positions.text: Psycho-analysis is Freud's creation and remains fundamentally associated with his name, distinguishing it from the theories of Adler and Jung which are not properly psycho-analytic
positions.work: ON THE HISTORY OF THE PSYCHO-ANALYTIC MOVEMENT

positions.title: The theory of repression is the cornerstone on which the whole structure of psyc...
positions.text: The theory of repression is the cornerstone on which the whole structure of psycho-analysis rests, and anyone who cannot accept repression cannot belong to psychoanalysis
positions.work: ON THE HISTORY OF THE PSYCHO-ANALYTIC MOVEMENT

positions.title: The theory of resistance and repression, of the unconscious, of the aetiological...
positions.text: The theory of resistance and repression, of the unconscious, of the aetiological significance of sexual life and of the importance of infantile experiences constitute the principal subject-matter of psycho-analysis and the foundations of its theory
positions.work: ON THE HISTORY OF THE PSYCHO-ANALYTIC MOVEMENT

positions.title: Adler's theory replaces sexual motivation with the 'masculine protest' and 'neur...
positions.text: Adler's theory replaces sexual motivation with the 'masculine protest' and 'neurotic character', thereby abandoning the foundations of psycho-analysis while claiming to improve it
positions.work: ON THE HISTORY OF THE PSYCHO-ANALYTIC MOVEMENT

positions.title: Jung's modifications dissolve the findings of psycho-analysis by reinterpreting ...
positions.text: Jung's modifications dissolve the findings of psycho-analysis by reinterpreting the Oedipus complex symbolically rather than literally, thereby making it a mere figure of speech rather than an actual childhood experience
positions.work: ON THE HISTORY OF THE PSYCHO-ANALYTIC MOVEMENT

positions.title: Jung's denial of infantile sexuality and his recasting of libido as general psyc...
positions.text: Jung's denial of infantile sexuality and his recasting of libido as general psychic energy represent a complete abandonment of psychoanalytic principles, making his system incompatible with psycho-analysis
positions.work: ON THE HISTORY OF THE PSYCHO-ANALYTIC MOVEMENT

positions.title: The history of psycho-analysis falls into two phases: in the first, Freud worked...
positions.text: The history of psycho-analysis falls into two phases: in the first, Freud worked alone; in the second, after 1907, the movement expanded internationally with collaborators who both advanced and threatened the integrity of the theory
positions.work: ON THE HISTORY OF THE PSYCHO-ANALYTIC MOVEMENT

positions.title: Psycho-analysis necessarily arouses resistances because it challenges narcissism...
positions.text: Psycho-analysis necessarily arouses resistances because it challenges narcissism by showing that the ego is not master in its own house, following earlier blows to human narcissism from Copernicus and Darwin
positions.work: ON THE HISTORY OF THE PSYCHO-ANALYTIC MOVEMENT

positions.title: The technique of free association, where patients report everything that comes t...
positions.text: The technique of free association, where patients report everything that comes to mind without selection, is the fundamental method of psycho-analytic investigation, replacing hypnosis
positions.work: ON THE HISTORY OF THE PSYCHO-ANALYTIC MOVEMENT

positions.title: Dream-interpretation is the via regia (royal road) to knowledge of the unconscio...
positions.text: Dream-interpretation is the via regia (royal road) to knowledge of the unconscious and remains the most secure foundation of psycho-analysis
positions.work: ON THE HISTORY OF THE PSYCHO-ANALYTIC MOVEMENT

positions.title: Parapraxes (slips of the tongue, pen, forgetting, bungled actions, etc.) are not...
positions.text: Parapraxes (slips of the tongue, pen, forgetting, bungled actions, etc.) are not mere accidents or chance events but have psychological meaning and arise from the interference of two different intentions
positions.work: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE II-III

positions.title: In slips of the tongue, an intention interferes with another intention, producin...
positions.text: In slips of the tongue, an intention interferes with another intention, producing a compromise formation where both intentions are partially expressed in the resultant speech error
positions.work: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE II

positions.title: The disturbing intention in parapraxes may be a direct contrary intention (sayin...
positions.text: The disturbing intention in parapraxes may be a direct contrary intention (saying the opposite of what is intended) or may be entirely unrelated content that intrudes from another psychological complex
positions.work: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE II

positions.title: The forgetting of intentions (forgetting to do something) regularly derives from...
positions.text: The forgetting of intentions (forgetting to do something) regularly derives from a counter-will or contrary intention, though the person is typically unaware of this opposing motive
positions.work: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE III

positions.title: The forgetting of names often occurs when the name is associatively connected to...
positions.text: The forgetting of names often occurs when the name is associatively connected to material that the person wishes to avoid or that arouses painful affect, even when the connection is indirect or symbolic
positions.work: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE III

positions.title: Losing or mislaying objects is frequently a sacrifice to Fate, an unconscious at...
positions.text: Losing or mislaying objects is frequently a sacrifice to Fate, an unconscious attempt to ward off feared losses by voluntarily sacrificing something of lesser importance
positions.work: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE III

positions.title: Bungled actions that appear to be mere clumsiness often fulfill wishes that shou...
positions.text: Bungled actions that appear to be mere clumsiness often fulfill wishes that should be denied, with the intention disguising itself as a lucky accident
positions.work: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE III

positions.title: The study of parapraxes demonstrates that there are mental purposes or intention...
positions.text: The study of parapraxes demonstrates that there are mental purposes or intentions operating in people without their conscious knowledge, forcing us to accept the hypothesis of unconscious mental processes
positions.work: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE IV

positions.title: Superstitious people who believe in chance and omens are correct in sensing that...
positions.text: Superstitious people who believe in chance and omens are correct in sensing that external events have meaning, but they project outward what psycho-analysis finds inward—that seemingly chance psychical events have internal psychological causation
positions.work: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE IV

positions.title: The apparently arbitrary choice of numbers that someone 'freely' selects is actu...
positions.text: The apparently arbitrary choice of numbers that someone 'freely' selects is actually determined by unconscious thoughts and associations, proving that even seemingly random mental acts follow deterministic laws
positions.work: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE IV

positions.title: Dreams are not somatic but psychical phenomena, the products of the dreamer's ow...
positions.text: Dreams are not somatic but psychical phenomena, the products of the dreamer's own mental activity with sense and meaning that can be uncovered through psycho-analytic interpretation
positions.work: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE V

positions.title: The manifest content of the dream (what the dreamer remembers and reports) diffe...
positions.text: The manifest content of the dream (what the dreamer remembers and reports) differs from the latent dream-thoughts (the unconscious meaning), and the dream-work transforms the latter into the former through specific mechanisms
positions.work: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE VI

positions.title: The technique of dream interpretation requires the dreamer to free-associate to ...
positions.text: The technique of dream interpretation requires the dreamer to free-associate to each element of the manifest dream without criticism, allowing the latent thoughts to emerge through these associations
positions.work: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE VI

positions.title: Dreams regularly fulfill wishes, though the wish may be disguised or distorted; ...
positions.text: Dreams regularly fulfill wishes, though the wish may be disguised or distorted; even anxiety dreams and punishment dreams represent wish-fulfillments, though of a complex kind
positions.work: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE VIII

positions.title: The dream-censorship is a psychical force that distorts the latent dream-thought...
positions.text: The dream-censorship is a psychical force that distorts the latent dream-thoughts to make them acceptable to consciousness, operating like a political censorship that modifies communications to make them permissible
positions.work: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE IX

positions.title: Dream-distortion increases with the intensity of censorship; transparent dreams ...
positions.text: Dream-distortion increases with the intensity of censorship; transparent dreams occur when censorship is weak (as in children or when waking wishes align with unconscious wishes), while highly distorted dreams indicate strong censorship
positions.work: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE IX

positions.title: Dream-symbolism represents a primitive, archaic mode of expression where certain...
positions.text: Dream-symbolism represents a primitive, archaic mode of expression where certain manifest elements regularly stand for particular latent contents (e.g., houses for the human body, rooms for women, climbing for sexual intercourse)
positions.work: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURES X-XI

positions.title: The majority of dream-symbols are sexual in nature, with an overwhelming prepond...
positions.text: The majority of dream-symbols are sexual in nature, with an overwhelming preponderance of symbols representing the male genital organ, female genitals, and the sexual act itself
positions.work: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURES X-XI

positions.title: Dream-symbols are not peculiar to dreams but appear in myths, fairy-tales, jokes...
positions.text: Dream-symbols are not peculiar to dreams but appear in myths, fairy-tales, jokes, folklore, and everyday speech, suggesting a universal symbolic language rooted in phylogenetic inheritance
positions.work: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XI

positions.title: The dream-work employs four main mechanisms: condensation (multiple latent eleme...
positions.text: The dream-work employs four main mechanisms: condensation (multiple latent elements compressed into single manifest element), displacement (psychical intensity transferred from important to trivial elements), considerations of representability (abstract thoughts converted to visual images), and secondary revision (logical facade imposed post-hoc)
positions.work: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURES XI-XIV

positions.title: Condensation in dreams allows a single manifest element to represent multiple la...
positions.text: Condensation in dreams allows a single manifest element to represent multiple latent thoughts simultaneously, creating the remarkable compression that makes manifest dreams much shorter than latent content
positions.work: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XII

positions.title: Displacement in dreams transfers psychical value from important elements to unim...
positions.text: Displacement in dreams transfers psychical value from important elements to unimportant ones, making what is trivial prominent and what is significant peripheral, thereby evading censorship
positions.work: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XII

positions.title: The requirement of representability forces dream-thoughts to be translated into ...
positions.text: The requirement of representability forces dream-thoughts to be translated into predominantly visual images, favoring concrete over abstract content and creating the hallucinatory quality of dreams
positions.work: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XIII

positions.title: Secondary revision attempts to impose logical coherence and narrative structure ...
positions.text: Secondary revision attempts to impose logical coherence and narrative structure on the incoherent dream material after the fact, creating the false impression that dreams are more organized than they actually are
positions.work: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XIII

positions.title: Dreams invariably include a day's residue—recent impressions from waking life—bu...
positions.text: Dreams invariably include a day's residue—recent impressions from waking life—but these are never the true instigator of the dream; rather, they provide material through which unconscious infantile wishes achieve expression
positions.work: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XIV

positions.title: Every dream is instigated by an unconscious infantile wish that seeks fulfillmen...
positions.text: Every dream is instigated by an unconscious infantile wish that seeks fulfillment; adult rational wishes alone cannot produce dreams but must connect with these deeper infantile sources
positions.work: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XIV

positions.title: Dreams perform the function of preserving sleep by converting disturbing stimuli...
positions.text: Dreams perform the function of preserving sleep by converting disturbing stimuli (internal or external) into dream images that allow sleep to continue, making the dream the guardian of sleep
positions.work: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XIV

positions.title: Anxiety dreams do not contradict wish-fulfillment theory; they occur when censor...
positions.text: Anxiety dreams do not contradict wish-fulfillment theory; they occur when censorship fails partially, allowing repressed wishes to emerge with sufficient clarity to provoke anxiety, or when the ego fulfills its own wish to punish forbidden desires
positions.work: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XIV

positions.title: Punishment dreams represent the fulfillment of a wish on the part of the censori...
positions.text: Punishment dreams represent the fulfillment of a wish on the part of the censoring agency (superego) to punish the person for harboring forbidden wishes, thus still conforming to wish-fulfillment theory
positions.work: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XIV

positions.title: The archaic, regressive character of dreams shows that dreaming reverts to earli...
positions.text: The archaic, regressive character of dreams shows that dreaming reverts to earlier modes of mental functioning, employing primary process mechanisms and primitive forms of thought characteristic of childhood and unconscious mental life
positions.work: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XV

positions.title: Symptoms, like dreams and parapraxes, are meaningful psychical products that can...
positions.text: Symptoms, like dreams and parapraxes, are meaningful psychical products that can be interpreted; they represent compromise formations between repressed wishes and the forces of repression
positions.work: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XVII

positions.title: Neurotic symptoms always have sense and meaning relating to the patient's life e...
positions.text: Neurotic symptoms always have sense and meaning relating to the patient's life experiences; they are substitutes for satisfactions that have been renounced in reality
positions.work: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XVII

positions.title: The fixation of libido at early developmental points creates predispositions to ...
positions.text: The fixation of libido at early developmental points creates predispositions to neurosis; when libido is frustrated in adult life, it regresses to these fixation points, producing neurotic symptoms
positions.work: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XVIII-XIX

positions.title: Sexual development proceeds through a series of stages (oral, anal, phallic) bef...
positions.text: Sexual development proceeds through a series of stages (oral, anal, phallic) before reaching the genital stage, with each stage capable of becoming a fixation point to which libido may later regress
positions.work: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURES XIX-XX

positions.title: Infantile sexuality is characterized by component instincts (oral, anal, sadisti...
positions.text: Infantile sexuality is characterized by component instincts (oral, anal, sadistic, scopophilic, exhibitionistic) that only gradually become organized under genital primacy; neurosis represents a failure of this organization
positions.work: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XX

positions.title: The Oedipus complex—the child's erotic attachment to the parent of the opposite ...
positions.text: The Oedipus complex—the child's erotic attachment to the parent of the opposite sex and hostile attitude toward the same-sex parent—is universal and forms the nuclear complex of the neuroses
positions.work: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XXI

positions.title: The aetiology of neurosis requires multiple factors working in a 'complemental s...
positions.text: The aetiology of neurosis requires multiple factors working in a 'complemental series': hereditary constitutional factors, infantile experiences producing fixations, and precipitating adult frustrations that trigger regression
positions.work: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XXII

positions.title: Neurosis results from frustration (Versagung) when the libido is denied satisfac...
positions.text: Neurosis results from frustration (Versagung) when the libido is denied satisfaction in reality, but not all frustration produces neurosis—only when no adequate substitute satisfaction can be found and when ego-libido conflict develops
positions.work: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XXII

positions.title: The libido that is frustrated in reality flows backward (regresses) to earlier f...
positions.text: The libido that is frustrated in reality flows backward (regresses) to earlier fixation points, reactivating infantile wishes and modes of satisfaction that then become the source of symptom formation
positions.work: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XXII-XXIII

positions.title: Symptoms arise from conflict between ego instincts (self-preservative) and sexua...
positions.text: Symptoms arise from conflict between ego instincts (self-preservative) and sexual instincts (libido); the ego represses unacceptable libidinal demands, but the repressed libido returns in the form of symptoms
positions.work: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XXIII

positions.title: The pleasure principle governs unconscious mental processes, demanding immediate...
positions.text: The pleasure principle governs unconscious mental processes, demanding immediate satisfaction, while the reality principle, developed by the ego, requires postponement and modification of satisfaction according to external conditions
positions.work: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XXIII

positions.title: Phantasy (imagination) represents a domain where the pleasure principle continue...
positions.text: Phantasy (imagination) represents a domain where the pleasure principle continues to reign unchallenged, providing substitute satisfactions and serving as the bridge between unfulfilled wishes and symptoms
positions.work: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XXIII

positions.title: Symptoms have two sides: they provide substitute sexual satisfaction for repress...
positions.text: Symptoms have two sides: they provide substitute sexual satisfaction for repressed libido (pleasure gain), but they also involve suffering that satisfies the need for punishment (guilt)
positions.work: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XXIV

positions.title: Common nervous states (neurasthenia, anxiety neurosis) differ from psychoneurose...
positions.text: Common nervous states (neurasthenia, anxiety neurosis) differ from psychoneuroses in that their symptoms are directly produced by disturbed sexual physiology (actual neuroses) rather than being psychical products requiring interpretation
positions.work: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XXIV

positions.title: Anxiety in neurosis arises from undischarged libido that has been transformed di...
positions.text: Anxiety in neurosis arises from undischarged libido that has been transformed directly into anxiety—libido that cannot find adequate release is converted into the affect of anxiety
positions.work: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XXV

positions.title: There are three types of anxiety: realistic anxiety (fear of external danger), n...
positions.text: There are three types of anxiety: realistic anxiety (fear of external danger), neurotic anxiety (fear of one's own libido), and moral anxiety (fear of the superego/conscience)
positions.work: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XXV

positions.title: Symptoms have the character of a 'secondary gain from illness' beyond their prim...
positions.text: Symptoms have the character of a 'secondary gain from illness' beyond their primary function; they become integrated into the ego and serve various purposes (excuse for failure, means of dominating others, self-punishment), making the patient resist giving them up
positions.work: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XXIV

positions.title: Libido-theory distinguishes between ego-libido (narcissistic libido directed tow...
positions.text: Libido-theory distinguishes between ego-libido (narcissistic libido directed toward the self) and object-libido (directed toward external objects), with the two in inverse relationship
positions.work: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XXVI

positions.title: Transference occurs in all human relationships as stereotyped editions of emotio...
positions.text: Transference occurs in all human relationships as stereotyped editions of emotional impulses and reactions from childhood, but in analysis it becomes concentrated on the analyst and must be recognized and interpreted
positions.work: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XXVII

positions.title: Transference can manifest as positive (affectionate, loving) or negative (hostil...
positions.text: Transference can manifest as positive (affectionate, loving) or negative (hostile, antagonistic); both forms must be recognized and worked through in analysis, as unrecognized transference becomes resistance
positions.work: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XXVII

positions.title: Analytic therapy works by making the unconscious conscious, filling gaps in memo...
positions.text: Analytic therapy works by making the unconscious conscious, filling gaps in memory, overcoming resistances, and thus liberating repressed libido from its pathological fixations to become available for reality satisfactions
positions.work: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XXVII-XXVIII

positions.title: Psycho-analytic therapy does not create something new but removes obstacles (rep...
positions.text: Psycho-analytic therapy does not create something new but removes obstacles (repressions, resistances) that prevent normal development, allowing libido to flow into more adaptive channels
positions.work: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XXVIII

positions.title: The analyst must maintain neutrality and abstinence, neither gratifying the pati...
positions.text: The analyst must maintain neutrality and abstinence, neither gratifying the patient's wishes nor imposing his own values, serving as a mirror that reflects only what is shown to him
positions.work: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XXVII-XXVIII

positions.title: Hysterical symptoms result from the conversion of psychical excitation into soma...
positions.text: Hysterical symptoms result from the conversion of psychical excitation into somatic innervation, with the symptom expressing a repressed sexual phantasy through a bodily manifestation
positions.work: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XXIV

positions.title: Obsessional neurosis differs from hysteria in employing different defense mechan...
positions.text: Obsessional neurosis differs from hysteria in employing different defense mechanisms: instead of conversion, it uses displacement, reaction-formation, isolation, and undoing to manage repressed impulses
positions.work: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XVI-XVII

positions.title: In obsessional neurosis, regression typically goes back to the sadistic-anal sta...
positions.text: In obsessional neurosis, regression typically goes back to the sadistic-anal stage, producing characteristic ambivalence, omnipotence of thoughts, and ritualistic behaviors

positions.title: The choice of neurosis (whether someone develops hysteria, obsessional neurosis,...
positions.text: The choice of neurosis (whether someone develops hysteria, obsessional neurosis, or another form) depends primarily on the point of fixation to which libido regresses when frustrated in adult life

positions.title: Perversions represent direct expressions of component instincts that have not be...
positions.text: Perversions represent direct expressions of component instincts that have not been subordinated to genital organization, whereas neuroses are 'the negative of perversions'—the same instincts repressed rather than directly gratified

positions.title: Narcissism represents a stage in libidinal development where the subject takes h...
positions.text: Narcissism represents a stage in libidinal development where the subject takes his own body and ego as love-object before directing love toward external objects
positions.work: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XXVI

positions.title: In narcissistic neuroses (including dementia praecox, paranoia, and melancholia)...
positions.text: In narcissistic neuroses (including dementia praecox, paranoia, and melancholia), libido is withdrawn from external objects and turned back upon the ego, making transference impossible and these conditions largely inaccessible to psycho-analytic treatment
positions.work: INTRODUCTORY LECTURES ON PSYCHO-ANALYSIS, LECTURE XXVI

positions.title: Sublimation is the process by which sexual instinctual energy is deflected from ...
positions.text: Sublimation is the process by which sexual instinctual energy is deflected from sexual aims and directed toward socially valuable achievements in art, science, and culture, providing an alternative to repression

positions.title: The capacity for sublimation varies considerably between individuals, and insuff...
positions.text: The capacity for sublimation varies considerably between individuals, and insufficient capacity for sublimation is an important factor in neurosis predisposition

positions.title: Identification is the earliest form of emotional tie with another person and pla...
positions.text: Identification is the earliest form of emotional tie with another person and plays a crucial role in the formation of the ego, as the child assimilates aspects of important figures (particularly parents) into his own personality

positions.title: The superego (conscience, ego-ideal) forms through identification with parental ...
positions.text: The superego (conscience, ego-ideal) forms through identification with parental authority, internalizing their prohibitions and commands, and thereafter exercises internal moral censorship independent of external authority

positions.title: Guilt (unconscious sense of guilt) arises from conflict between ego and superego...
positions.text: Guilt (unconscious sense of guilt) arises from conflict between ego and superego, particularly when forbidden oedipal wishes persist in the unconscious, and this guilt can manifest as need for punishment leading to self-sabotage

positions.title: Repetition compulsion drives individuals to repeat painful experiences, traumas,...
positions.text: Repetition compulsion drives individuals to repeat painful experiences, traumas, and unsatisfying patterns of behavior, suggesting forces beyond the pleasure principle

positions.title: Resistance arises from the ego's need to maintain repressions and avoid the unpl...
positions.text: Resistance arises from the ego's need to maintain repressions and avoid the unpleasure that would result from becoming conscious of repressed material; this resistance must be systematically overcome in analysis

positions.title: The fundamental rule of psycho-analysis requires the patient to say everything t...
positions.text: The fundamental rule of psycho-analysis requires the patient to say everything that comes to mind without selection or criticism (free association), no matter how trivial, embarrassing, or apparently irrelevant

positions.title: Interpretation should be given only when the material is near consciousness and ...
positions.text: Interpretation should be given only when the material is near consciousness and strong resistance has been overcome; premature interpretation provokes increased resistance and is therapeutically counterproductive

positions.title: Working-through requires repeated examination of resistances and conflicts from ...
positions.text: Working-through requires repeated examination of resistances and conflicts from different angles over time; intellectual understanding alone (intellectual insight) is insufficient for therapeutic change

positions.title: Psycho-analysis cannot abbreviate treatment or produce rapid cures because the p...
positions.text: Psycho-analysis cannot abbreviate treatment or produce rapid cures because the pathological structures took years to form and require correspondingly lengthy work to dissolve

positions.title: The goal of psycho-analytic treatment is to strengthen the ego, expand its organ...
positions.text: The goal of psycho-analytic treatment is to strengthen the ego, expand its organization, make it independent of the superego, widen its field of perception, and extend its organization so that it can appropriate fresh portions of the id

positions.title: Psycho-analysis is not a Weltanschauung (world-view) but a specialized scientifi...
positions.text: Psycho-analysis is not a Weltanschauung (world-view) but a specialized scientific method for investigating unconscious mental processes; it accepts the worldview of science in general

positions.title: Bisexuality (constitutional presence of both masculine and feminine dispositions...
positions.text: Bisexuality (constitutional presence of both masculine and feminine dispositions) is universal in humans and plays a role in all neurotic conflict, as repression often targets the opposite-sex component of the personality

positions.title: The castration complex in boys (fear of losing the penis as punishment) and peni...
positions.text: The castration complex in boys (fear of losing the penis as punishment) and penis envy in girls (resentment at lacking the male organ) are universal phenomena arising from phallic stage experiences and profoundly shape subsequent development

positions.title: Female sexual development is more complicated than male development because girl...
positions.text: Female sexual development is more complicated than male development because girls must change both their leading erotogenic zone (from clitoris to vagina) and their love-object (from mother to father), making them more vulnerable to developmental disturbances

positions.title: The concept of psychical reality distinguishes the reality of unconscious phanta...
positions.text: The concept of psychical reality distinguishes the reality of unconscious phantasies and wishes, which have causal efficacy in producing symptoms, from material reality; phantasies are psychically real even when materially false

positions.title: The economic point of view in metapsychology concerns quantities of psychical en...
positions.text: The economic point of view in metapsychology concerns quantities of psychical energy (cathexis), their distribution, and transformations; symptoms represent particular distributions of libidinal energy

positions.title: The dynamic point of view concerns the forces and conflicts between psychical ag...
positions.text: The dynamic point of view concerns the forces and conflicts between psychical agencies (ego, id, superego) and between instinctual impulses and defenses

positions.title: The topographical point of view concerns the organization of mental processes in...
positions.text: The topographical point of view concerns the organization of mental processes into systems (conscious, preconscious, unconscious) with different characteristics and laws of functioning

positions.title: Memory-traces are organized in multiple registrations and systems; what becomes ...
positions.text: Memory-traces are organized in multiple registrations and systems; what becomes conscious is only the most recent version, while earlier versions persist in the unconscious and may remain active

positions.title: Preconscious processes can become conscious through attention, while unconscious...
positions.text: Preconscious processes can become conscious through attention, while unconscious processes are barred from consciousness by repression and can only become conscious after the lifting of repression

positions.title: The unconscious system operates according to primary process (disregarding logic...
positions.text: The unconscious system operates according to primary process (disregarding logic, allowing contradictions, timeless, replacing external by psychical reality), while the preconscious/conscious operates by secondary process (logical, temporal, reality-oriented)

positions.title: Affects and emotions become detached from their original ideational content thro...
positions.text: Affects and emotions become detached from their original ideational content through repression and may attach to different ideas, explaining why people often have strong feelings whose origin they cannot identify

positions.title: Screen memories are apparently innocent childhood memories that conceal more sig...
positions.text: Screen memories are apparently innocent childhood memories that conceal more significant repressed material through symbolic substitution or condensation of multiple memories

positions.title: Childhood amnesia (the inability to remember experiences before age 3-5) results...
positions.text: Childhood amnesia (the inability to remember experiences before age 3-5) results from repression of infantile sexual experiences and represents the foundation for later neurotic amnesias

positions.title: Psychical conflict is inevitable in humans because sexual instincts demand satis...
positions.text: Psychical conflict is inevitable in humans because sexual instincts demand satisfaction while ego instincts require adaptation to reality and social norms, making some form of instinct modification (repression, sublimation, or compromise) necessary

positions.title: The sense of reality undergoes development from initial hallucinatory wish-fulfi...
positions.text: The sense of reality undergoes development from initial hallucinatory wish-fulfillment (where wished-for objects are simply hallucinated) to reality-testing (where the ego learns to distinguish perception from phantasy)

positions.title: Attention is an ego function that scans both external perceptions and internal p...
positions.text: Attention is an ego function that scans both external perceptions and internal processes, directing cathexis toward significant stimuli and away from irrelevant ones

positions.title: Judgment is a later ego function that decides whether a given idea is true or fa...
positions.text: Judgment is a later ego function that decides whether a given idea is true or false (correspondence with reality) and whether a given object should be taken in or spat out (acceptance or rejection)

positions.title: Thought originated as a substitute for hallucinatory wish-fulfillment, allowing ...
positions.text: Thought originated as a substitute for hallucinatory wish-fulfillment, allowing experimental action with small amounts of psychical energy before committing to real action

positions.title: Inhibition is a restriction of ego function imposed to avoid conflict with id, s...
positions.text: Inhibition is a restriction of ego function imposed to avoid conflict with id, superego, or external reality; different inhibitions arise depending on which agency is being appeased

positions.title: Sexual symbolism is remarkably limited and constant across individuals and cultu...
positions.text: Sexual symbolism is remarkably limited and constant across individuals and cultures, suggesting phylogenetic inheritance rather than individual creation

positions.title: Neurotic symptoms regularly have multiple determinants (overdetermination), expr...
positions.text: Neurotic symptoms regularly have multiple determinants (overdetermination), expressing several different unconscious meanings simultaneously through a single manifestation

positions.title: The somatic compliance in hysteria refers to the body's provision of a suitable ...
positions.text: The somatic compliance in hysteria refers to the body's provision of a suitable location for symptom expression based on previous illness, constitutional factors, or symbolic appropriateness

positions.title: Hysterical identification allows a person to express through symptoms not only h...
positions.text: Hysterical identification allows a person to express through symptoms not only her own repressed wishes but also those of other people with whom she identifies (as in epidemic hysteria)

positions.title: The economic factor (quantity of libidinal energy) is as important as qualitativ...
positions.text: The economic factor (quantity of libidinal energy) is as important as qualitative factors in determining symptom formation; sometimes quantitative increase alone can produce pathology

positions.title: Primal phantasies (primal scene, castration, seduction) show such regularity and...
positions.text: Primal phantasies (primal scene, castration, seduction) show such regularity and universality that they must be regarded as phylogenetic schemata, with individual experience merely filling in inherited structures

positions.title: The compulsion neurotic's omnipotence of thoughts treats mental acts as equivale...
positions.text: The compulsion neurotic's omnipotence of thoughts treats mental acts as equivalent to physical acts, believing that thinking something can make it happen or prevent it, showing regression to animistic thinking

positions.title: Reaction-formation produces traits that are the opposite of repressed instinctua...
positions.text: Reaction-formation produces traits that are the opposite of repressed instinctual aims (e.g., excessive cleanliness as defense against anal-erotic impulses, excessive sympathy as defense against cruelty)

positions.title: Isolation in obsessional neurosis separates an idea from its affect, allowing th...
positions.text: Isolation in obsessional neurosis separates an idea from its affect, allowing the idea to remain conscious while the associated feeling is repressed, producing apparently emotionless thoughts about disturbing content

positions.title: Undoing is an obsessional mechanism where a second action symbolically cancels o...
positions.text: Undoing is an obsessional mechanism where a second action symbolically cancels or negates a first action, as if the first had not occurred (e.g., compulsive rituals)

positions.title: Ambivalence (simultaneous love and hate toward the same object) is particularly ...
positions.text: Ambivalence (simultaneous love and hate toward the same object) is particularly intense at the sadistic-anal stage and is characteristic of obsessional neurosis where it produces doubting, indecision, and opposing compulsions

positions.title: The talking cure works because putting things into words creates an avenue from ...
positions.text: The talking cure works because putting things into words creates an avenue from unconscious to conscious, and words themselves are derivatives of preconscious processes that can bridge the gap between systems

positions.title: Acting out is the tendency to discharge unconscious impulses in action rather th...
positions.text: Acting out is the tendency to discharge unconscious impulses in action rather than remembering them, particularly manifest in transference where patients repeat rather than recollect childhood patterns

positions.title: The negative therapeutic reaction occurs when clinical improvement produces incr...
positions.text: The negative therapeutic reaction occurs when clinical improvement produces increased guilt and self-punishment in some patients, paradoxically making them worse when treatment succeeds

positions.title: Psycho-analysis can be applied beyond therapy to understanding cultural products...
positions.text: Psycho-analysis can be applied beyond therapy to understanding cultural products (art, literature, myth, religion), social phenomena, and normal psychology, making it a general psychology of mental functioning

positions.title: The artist creates as substitute satisfaction for repressed wishes, using his wo...
positions.text: The artist creates as substitute satisfaction for repressed wishes, using his works to express unconscious phantasies in socially acceptable form, achieving both personal gratification and social recognition

positions.title: Religion represents a collective obsessional neurosis arising from the same conf...
positions.text: Religion represents a collective obsessional neurosis arising from the same conflicts (oedipal guilt, ambivalence toward father) that produce individual obsessional neurosis, offering ritualized defenses against forbidden wishes

positions.title: Education should aim to help the child find a middle path between unrestricted i...
positions.text: Education should aim to help the child find a middle path between unrestricted instinctual expression (which would make civilization impossible) and excessive repression (which produces neurosis)

positions.title: The therapeutic aim is not to eliminate conflict but to help the ego make better...
positions.text: The therapeutic aim is not to eliminate conflict but to help the ego make better choices about managing conflicts, replacing pathological solutions (symptoms) with adaptive ones (reality satisfactions, sublimations)

positions.title: Character traits are precipitates of abandoned object-cathexes, formed when the ...
positions.text: Character traits are precipitates of abandoned object-cathexes, formed when the ego responds to loss of an object by identifying with it and taking on its characteristics

positions.title: The constitutional factor (innate variations in instinctual strength, capacity f...
positions.text: The constitutional factor (innate variations in instinctual strength, capacity for sublimation, ego resilience) always plays a role in neurosis aetiology and explains why similar experiences produce different outcomes in different individuals

positions.title: Dementia praecox (schizophrenia) involves profound narcissistic withdrawal where...
positions.text: Dementia praecox (schizophrenia) involves profound narcissistic withdrawal where libido is retracted from objects and turned inward to such degree that reality-contact is lost and internal phantasy world becomes predominant

positions.title: Melancholia results when loss of an object is handled not by mourning but by nar...
positions.text: Melancholia results when loss of an object is handled not by mourning but by narcissistic identification, with the ego setting up the lost object inside itself and then directing ambivalent feelings (particularly hatred) against this internalized object, thus attacking itself

positions.title: Normal mourning and pathological melancholia share the feature of reaction to ob...
positions.text: Normal mourning and pathological melancholia share the feature of reaction to object-loss, but mourning works through the loss gradually while melancholia involves regression to narcissistic identification

positions.title: Paranoia results from projection of repressed homosexual impulses onto a persecu...
positions.text: Paranoia results from projection of repressed homosexual impulses onto a persecutor, transforming 'I love him' (forbidden) into 'He hates me' (acceptable but persecutory)

positions.title: The theory of instincts is our mythology; instincts are mythical entities, magni...
positions.text: The theory of instincts is our mythology; instincts are mythical entities, magnificent in their indefiniteness, yet indispensable for understanding mental processes

positions.title: Psycho-analysis has no Weltanschauung of its own but shares the scientific Welta...
positions.text: Psycho-analysis has no Weltanschauung of its own but shares the scientific Weltanschauung, characterized by emphasis on external world, rejection of illusions, and acceptance that our picture of reality is incomplete and revisable

positions.title: The pleasure-unpleasure principle governs primary process, seeking immediate dis...
positions.text: The pleasure-unpleasure principle governs primary process, seeking immediate discharge of tension (pleasure) and avoiding increase in tension (unpleasure), without regard for reality or consequences

positions.title: Reality adaptation requires that pleasure be postponed, immediate satisfactions ...
positions.text: Reality adaptation requires that pleasure be postponed, immediate satisfactions renounced, and unpleasure temporarily tolerated in service of greater long-term advantage

positions.title: The sexual instinct is particularly resistant to education and taming by the rea...
positions.text: The sexual instinct is particularly resistant to education and taming by the reality principle, maintaining its pressure toward immediate satisfaction even when ego interests require renunciation

positions.title: The common feature of all psychical phenomena studied by psycho-analysis (dreams...
positions.text: The common feature of all psychical phenomena studied by psycho-analysis (dreams, parapraxes, symptoms, jokes) is that they represent compromises between opposing mental forces, making compromise-formation the fundamental pattern of unconscious expression

positions.title: Sexuality in the psycho-analytic sense (sexuelle, Eros) is broader than genital ...
positions.text: Sexuality in the psycho-analytic sense (sexuelle, Eros) is broader than genital sexuality, encompassing all pleasurable bodily sensations and the full range of libidinal strivings including infantile, component, and perverse sexualities

positions.title: The distinction between ego-instincts (self-preservative) and sexual instincts (...
positions.text: The distinction between ego-instincts (self-preservative) and sexual instincts (species-preservative) represents the fundamental duality driving psychical conflict, though this distinction may require future revision

positions.title: The incompatibility between civilization's demands and instinctual nature create...
positions.text: The incompatibility between civilization's demands and instinctual nature creates universal discontent, making some degree of neurosis or sublimation inevitable in civilized life

positions.title: Dreams are the normal prototype of all pathological mental products—they show in...
positions.text: Dreams are the normal prototype of all pathological mental products—they show in miniature all the mechanisms (regression, displacement, condensation, symbolism, compromise-formation) that operate in neurotic symptom-formation

positions.title: The forgetting of proper names demonstrates that apparently arbitrary failures o...
positions.text: The forgetting of proper names demonstrates that apparently arbitrary failures of memory follow deterministic laws, being caused by specific interfering thoughts even when the person is unaware of these thoughts

positions.title: Slips of the tongue often reveal what the speaker really thinks or feels despite...
positions.text: Slips of the tongue often reveal what the speaker really thinks or feels despite conscious intentions to conceal it, making them a form of inadvertent self-betrayal

positions.title: Adler's individual psychology represents a defection from psycho-analysis becaus...
positions.text: Adler's individual psychology represents a defection from psycho-analysis because it denies infantile sexuality, eliminates the unconscious, rejects repression, and reduces all motivation to ego-striving (will to power), thereby abandoning the foundations that define psychoanalysis
positions.work: ON THE HISTORY OF THE PSYCHO-ANALYTIC MOVEMENT

positions.title: Jung's analytic psychology dissolves psycho-analysis by reinterpreting libido as...
positions.text: Jung's analytic psychology dissolves psycho-analysis by reinterpreting libido as general life-energy rather than sexual energy, treating the Oedipus complex as symbolic rather than literal, and denying the reality of infantile sexuality
positions.work: ON THE HISTORY OF THE PSYCHO-ANALYTIC MOVEMENT

positions.title: The controversies with Adler and Jung demonstrate that the core principles of ps...
positions.text: The controversies with Adler and Jung demonstrate that the core principles of psycho-analysis (unconscious, repression, infantile sexuality, transference) are non-negotiable—anyone rejecting these cannot properly call their work psychoanalysis
positions.work: ON THE HISTORY OF THE PSYCHO-ANALYTIC MOVEMENT

positions.title: Psycho-analysis began in 1895-1896 with Freud's recognition that hysterical symp...
positions.text: Psycho-analysis began in 1895-1896 with Freud's recognition that hysterical symptoms have sexual meaning and arise from repressed sexual traumas, though the seduction theory was later revised
positions.work: ON THE HISTORY OF THE PSYCHO-ANALYTIC MOVEMENT

positions.title: The recognition that patients' reports of childhood seduction were often phantas...
positions.text: The recognition that patients' reports of childhood seduction were often phantasies rather than real events led to the discovery of infantile sexuality and psychical reality, representing a crucial theoretical advance
positions.work: ON THE HISTORY OF THE PSYCHO-ANALYTIC MOVEMENT

positions.title: Free association emerged as the fundamental method when Freud abandoned hypnosis...
positions.text: Free association emerged as the fundamental method when Freud abandoned hypnosis, asking patients to report everything that came to mind, thereby providing access to unconscious material through the chain of associations
positions.work: ON THE HISTORY OF THE PSYCHO-ANALYTIC MOVEMENT

positions.title: The interpretation of a dream requires that the dreamer associate freely to each...
positions.text: The interpretation of a dream requires that the dreamer associate freely to each element, not that the analyst impose symbolic meanings; fixed symbolic translations without associations are insufficient

positions.title: Children's dreams are typically undistorted wish-fulfillments because the censor...
positions.text: Children's dreams are typically undistorted wish-fulfillments because the censorship is not yet strong, showing directly what later becomes disguised in adult dreams

positions.title: Dreams incorporate recent waking impressions (day-residues) not because these ar...
positions.text: Dreams incorporate recent waking impressions (day-residues) not because these are important in themselves but because they provide convenient material through which deeper unconscious wishes can express themselves

positions.title: The manifest dream is typically much shorter than the latent dream-thoughts it r...
positions.text: The manifest dream is typically much shorter than the latent dream-thoughts it represents, demonstrating massive condensation through which multiple meanings are compressed into single images

positions.title: Dreams show preference for representing abstract relationships and logical conne...
positions.text: Dreams show preference for representing abstract relationships and logical connections through spatial arrangements, simultaneity, or transformations rather than through language

positions.title: The interpretation of symptoms follows the same principles as dream interpretati...
positions.text: The interpretation of symptoms follows the same principles as dream interpretation, treating the symptom as a manifest content concealing latent meanings that emerge through patient's associations

positions.title: Symptom-formation serves as a substitute satisfaction when normal satisfaction i...
positions.text: Symptom-formation serves as a substitute satisfaction when normal satisfaction is blocked, but the satisfaction gained is distorted, partial, and inseparable from suffering

positions.title: The strength required to maintain repression is drawn from the ego's supply of e...
positions.text: The strength required to maintain repression is drawn from the ego's supply of energy, weakening the ego and reducing its capacity for adaptation and sublimation

positions.title: Successful analysis liberates the energy bound in maintaining repressions, makin...
positions.text: Successful analysis liberates the energy bound in maintaining repressions, making it available for ego functions, adaptation, and sublimation

positions.title: Not all conflicts produce neurosis—only when the ego's capacity is overwhelmed, ...
positions.text: Not all conflicts produce neurosis—only when the ego's capacity is overwhelmed, when regression to infantile fixation-points occurs, and when substitute satisfactions fail to provide adequate relief

positions.title: The therapeutic process requires not just intellectual insight but emotional wor...
positions.text: The therapeutic process requires not just intellectual insight but emotional working-through, where resistances are repeatedly encountered and overcome until the patient can genuinely accept and integrate the unconscious material

positions.title: Anxiety (Angst) constitutes the fundamental problem of the neuroses, the nodal point at which the most various and important questions converge, and a
positions.text: Anxiety (Angst) constitutes the fundamental problem of the neuroses, the nodal point at which the most various and important questions converge, and a riddle whose solution would cast a flood of light upon our whole mental existence
positions.work: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXV: Anxiety (1917)

positions.title: Three types of anxiety must be distinguished: realistic anxiety (normal fear of external dangers), neurotic anxiety (fear disproportionate to actual d
positions.text: Three types of anxiety must be distinguished: realistic anxiety (normal fear of external dangers), neurotic anxiety (fear disproportionate to actual danger), and moral anxiety (conscience or superego anxiety)
positions.work: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXV: Anxiety (1917)

positions.title: Realistic anxiety appears entirely rational and intelligible, representing a reaction to the perception of an external danger - an injury that is expe
positions.text: Realistic anxiety appears entirely rational and intelligible, representing a reaction to the perception of an external danger - an injury that is expected and foreseen; it is connected with the flight reflex and may be regarded as an expression of the self-preservative instinct
positions.work: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXV: Anxiety (1917)

positions.title: Anxiety prepares the organism for danger by heightening sensory attention and motor tension; the anxiety-affect consists of motor discharge (trembling
positions.text: Anxiety prepares the organism for danger by heightening sensory attention and motor tension; the anxiety-affect consists of motor discharge (trembling, perspiration, palpitations) and sensations of unpleasure
positions.work: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXV: Anxiety (1917)

positions.title: Neurotic anxiety manifests in three forms: free-floating general apprehensiveness (expectant anxiety), anxiety attached to specific phobic objects or
positions.text: Neurotic anxiety manifests in three forms: free-floating general apprehensiveness (expectant anxiety), anxiety attached to specific phobic objects or situations, and anxiety in hysteria and other neuroses appearing without apparent connection to danger
positions.work: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXV: Anxiety (1917)

positions.title: In anxiety neurosis, libido is turned into anxiety when denied normal discharge: the anxiety represents transformed libido which has not been employed
positions.text: In anxiety neurosis, libido is turned into anxiety when denied normal discharge: the anxiety represents transformed libido which has not been employed psychically but discharged in the form of anxiety
positions.work: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXV: Anxiety (1917)

positions.title: Phobic anxiety differs from expectant anxiety by being attached to specific objects or situations, but shares with it the characteristic of anxiety di
positions.text: Phobic anxiety differs from expectant anxiety by being attached to specific objects or situations, but shares with it the characteristic of anxiety disproportionate to actual danger; the phobic object serves as a condition under which anxiety is permitted release
positions.work: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXV: Anxiety (1917)

positions.title: The ego creates the phobia as an attempt to escape from the libidinal demand made by the id; the phobic avoidance protects the ego from experiencing a
positions.text: The ego creates the phobia as an attempt to escape from the libidinal demand made by the id; the phobic avoidance protects the ego from experiencing anxiety by avoiding the situation that would provoke the forbidden libidinal impulse
positions.work: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXV: Anxiety (1917)

positions.title: Anxiety in hysteria and obsessional neurosis accompanies symptoms: the anxiety is the quota of affect that has become liberated through the process of
positions.text: Anxiety in hysteria and obsessional neurosis accompanies symptoms: the anxiety is the quota of affect that has become liberated through the process of repression and which would otherwise have been employed in some other way if it had not been repressed
positions.work: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXV: Anxiety (1917)

positions.title: The transformation of libido into anxiety occurs through two mechanisms: direct transformation when libido cannot be discharged (anxiety neurosis), an
positions.text: The transformation of libido into anxiety occurs through two mechanisms: direct transformation when libido cannot be discharged (anxiety neurosis), and liberation of affect quota when repression occurs (hysteria and obsessional neurosis)
positions.work: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXV: Anxiety (1917)
