positions.title: The equation 'repression = anxiety' is fundamentally correct: repression arises from the ego's anxiety-readiness, and the repressed libidinal impulse
positions.text: The equation 'repression = anxiety' is fundamentally correct: repression arises from the ego's anxiety-readiness, and the repressed libidinal impulse is transformed into the anxiety which accompanies neurotic symptoms
positions.work: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXV: Anxiety (1917)

positions.title: The right to separate ego-instincts from sexual instincts cannot be shaken: it is implied in the existence of sexual life as a distinct activity of th
positions.text: The right to separate ego-instincts from sexual instincts cannot be shaken: it is implied in the existence of sexual life as a distinct activity of the individual, though the depth and importance of this separation must be determined by observing how differently the two behave
positions.work: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVI: Libido Theory and Narcissism (1917)

positions.title: If hunger and thirst (self-preservative instincts) are unsatisfied, the result is never their transformation into anxiety, whereas the changing of uns
positions.text: If hunger and thirst (self-preservative instincts) are unsatisfied, the result is never their transformation into anxiety, whereas the changing of unsatisfied libido into anxiety is among the best known and most frequently observed of phenomena - demonstrating a fundamental difference between ego and sexual instincts
positions.work: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVI: Libido Theory and Narcissism (1917)

positions.title: Libido is the energy of the sexual instincts directed to an object; it is qualitatively distinct from the energy of the ego-instincts and is capable o
positions.text: Libido is the energy of the sexual instincts directed to an object; it is qualitatively distinct from the energy of the ego-instincts and is capable of transformations, displacements, and regressions not observed in self-preservative impulses
positions.work: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVI: Libido Theory and Narcissism (1917)

positions.title: Narcissism is the libidinal complement to egoism of the self-preservative instinct: it is the libidinal cathexis of the ego, representing a state in w
positions.text: Narcissism is the libidinal complement to egoism of the self-preservative instinct: it is the libidinal cathexis of the ego, representing a state in which the ego itself is taken as the love-object
positions.work: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVI: Libido Theory and Narcissism (1917)

positions.title: Primary narcissism is the original state of earliest childhood before any object-love develops; the infant's libido is entirely self-directed, and onl
positions.text: Primary narcissism is the original state of earliest childhood before any object-love develops; the infant's libido is entirely self-directed, and only gradually does libido extend to external objects while retaining the ego as a reservoir
positions.work: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVI: Libido Theory and Narcissism (1917)

positions.title: The distribution of libido follows a hydraulic model: the more libido is employed in object-cathexes, the more it is withdrawn from the ego, and vice
positions.text: The distribution of libido follows a hydraulic model: the more libido is employed in object-cathexes, the more it is withdrawn from the ego, and vice versa; object-love impoverishes the ego, while narcissistic withdrawal enriches it
positions.work: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVI: Libido Theory and Narcissism (1917)

positions.title: Secondary narcissism occurs when object-libido is withdrawn back to the ego, as in states of sleep, organic illness, hypochondria, and the narcissisti
positions.text: Secondary narcissism occurs when object-libido is withdrawn back to the ego, as in states of sleep, organic illness, hypochondria, and the narcissistic neuroses (schizophrenia, paranoia, melancholia)
positions.work: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVI: Libido Theory and Narcissism (1917)

positions.title: The narcissistic neuroses (dementia praecox, paranoia, melancholia) are characterized by withdrawal of libido from objects and the external world; thi
positions.text: The narcissistic neuroses (dementia praecox, paranoia, melancholia) are characterized by withdrawal of libido from objects and the external world; this makes them largely inaccessible to psychoanalytic influence, since transference cannot be established where no object-cathexis exists
positions.work: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVI: Libido Theory and Narcissism (1917)

positions.title: Megalomania in paranoia and schizophrenia results from the cathexis of the ego with libido withdrawn from objects; the ego swells with the influx of n
positions.text: Megalomania in paranoia and schizophrenia results from the cathexis of the ego with libido withdrawn from objects; the ego swells with the influx of narcissistic libido, producing grandiose delusions and omnipotent fantasies
positions.work: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVI: Libido Theory and Narcissism (1917)

positions.title: The ego-ideal is a substitute for the lost narcissism of childhood; what the individual projects before him as his ideal is the substitute for the nar
positions.text: The ego-ideal is a substitute for the lost narcissism of childhood; what the individual projects before him as his ideal is the substitute for the narcissistic perfection he enjoyed as a child, attempting to recover the perfection attributed to his earlier state
positions.work: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVI: Libido Theory and Narcissism (1917)

positions.title: Object-choice can follow either the narcissistic type (loving what one is, was, or would like to be) or the anaclitic/attachment type (loving those wh
positions.text: Object-choice can follow either the narcissistic type (loving what one is, was, or would like to be) or the anaclitic/attachment type (loving those who satisfy self-preservative needs, modeled on parents); narcissistic choice predominates in homosexuality and in certain forms of love
positions.work: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVI: Libido Theory and Narcissism (1917)

positions.title: Transference is the fundamental phenomenon that makes psychoanalytic therapy possible: patients develop intense emotional attitudes toward the analyst
positions.text: Transference is the fundamental phenomenon that makes psychoanalytic therapy possible: patients develop intense emotional attitudes toward the analyst - love, hate, dependency - which are repetitions of attitudes toward important figures from childhood, particularly parents
positions.work: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVII: Transference (1917)

positions.title: Transference is not created by analysis but merely uncovered by it; it arises spontaneously in all human relationships and is particularly intense in
positions.text: Transference is not created by analysis but merely uncovered by it; it arises spontaneously in all human relationships and is particularly intense in neurotics, whose capacity for object-love has been impaired by fixation to infantile objects
positions.work: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVII: Transference (1917)

positions.title: Positive transference (affectionate feelings toward the analyst) can be divided into conscious friendly feelings, which are unobjectionable and mainta
positions.text: Positive transference (affectionate feelings toward the analyst) can be divided into conscious friendly feelings, which are unobjectionable and maintain the therapeutic alliance, and unconscious erotic feelings, which become resistance when they push for gratification rather than understanding
positions.work: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVII: Transference (1917)

positions.title: Negative transference (hostile feelings toward the analyst) and the erotic component of positive transference constitute the transference-resistance:
positions.text: Negative transference (hostile feelings toward the analyst) and the erotic component of positive transference constitute the transference-resistance: they obstruct the work by demanding emotional gratification instead of intellectual understanding and remembering
positions.work: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVII: Transference (1917)

positions.title: The transference-neurosis replaces the patient's ordinary neurosis: the symptoms are re-created in the relationship with the analyst, transforming the
positions.text: The transference-neurosis replaces the patient's ordinary neurosis: the symptoms are re-created in the relationship with the analyst, transforming the neurosis into a transference phenomenon that can be directly observed and analyzed in the present
positions.work: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVII: Transference (1917)

positions.title: Transference creates an intermediate realm between illness and real life through which the transition from one to the other is made; the new condition
positions.text: Transference creates an intermediate realm between illness and real life through which the transition from one to the other is made; the new condition (transference-neurosis) has taken over all features of the illness but represents an artificial illness that is accessible to intervention at every point
positions.work: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVII: Transference (1917)

positions.title: The handling of transference is the most difficult but also the most important part of analytic technique: overcoming transference-resistances accompl
positions.text: The handling of transference is the most difficult but also the most important part of analytic technique: overcoming transference-resistances accomplishes the removal of repressions and alters the economic conditions, making cure possible
positions.work: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVII: Transference (1917)

positions.title: Transference manifestations differ across neurotic structures: hysterics rapidly form intense erotic transferences; obsessionals maintain negative tra
positions.text: Transference manifestations differ across neurotic structures: hysterics rapidly form intense erotic transferences; obsessionals maintain negative transference and ambivalence; narcissistic neuroses fail to develop transference, making them unsuitable for standard analytic treatment
positions.work: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVII: Transference (1917)

positions.title: Direct suggestion aims at suppressing symptoms by authority without investigating their motives; psycho-analysis aims at uncovering and removing the m
positions.text: Direct suggestion aims at suppressing symptoms by authority without investigating their motives; psycho-analysis aims at uncovering and removing the motives for illness, relying on the patient's understanding rather than the physician's authority
positions.work: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVIII: Analytic Therapy (1917)

positions.title: Hypnotic and suggestive therapy, though rapid and superficially effective, provides only temporary symptomatic relief; symptoms return because the und
positions.text: Hypnotic and suggestive therapy, though rapid and superficially effective, provides only temporary symptomatic relief; symptoms return because the underlying conflicts remain unresolved, and the patient remains dependent on the physician's authority
positions.work: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVIII: Analytic Therapy (1917)

positions.title: Psycho-analytic treatment makes far greater demands on the patient and the physician than suggestive therapy: it requires the patient's active intelle
positions.text: Psycho-analytic treatment makes far greater demands on the patient and the physician than suggestive therapy: it requires the patient's active intellectual participation and the physician's understanding of unconscious processes, and it is lengthy, laborious, and often unpleasant
positions.work: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVIII: Analytic Therapy (1917)

positions.title: Psycho-analysis cannot alter hereditary disposition or undo childhood experiences; it can only address the third factor in neurotic causation - real f
positions.text: Psycho-analysis cannot alter hereditary disposition or undo childhood experiences; it can only address the third factor in neurotic causation - real frustration in adult life - by helping the patient redistribute libido more advantageously and overcome internal obstacles to satisfaction
positions.work: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVIII: Analytic Therapy (1917)

positions.title: The therapeutic work of analysis consists in overcoming internal resistances: the ego must learn to tolerate previously repressed impulses, integrate
positions.text: The therapeutic work of analysis consists in overcoming internal resistances: the ego must learn to tolerate previously repressed impulses, integrate them into consciousness, and achieve better compromise-solutions than repression and symptom-formation
positions.work: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVIII: Analytic Therapy (1917)

positions.title: Analysis helps the ego in three ways: by increasing its knowledge of the unconscious (making the unconscious conscious), by accustoming it gradually t
positions.text: Analysis helps the ego in three ways: by increasing its knowledge of the unconscious (making the unconscious conscious), by accustoming it gradually to tolerate repressed material (overcoming resistance), and by providing it with more energy by reducing expenditure on maintaining repressions
positions.work: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVIII: Analytic Therapy (1917)

positions.title: The formula 'making the unconscious conscious' must be understood economically, not merely topographically: it means altering the distribution of psyc
positions.text: The formula 'making the unconscious conscious' must be understood economically, not merely topographically: it means altering the distribution of psychic energy by lifting repressions, not simply bringing unconscious content into awareness intellectually
positions.work: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVIII: Analytic Therapy (1917)

positions.title: Intellectual knowledge alone accomplishes nothing: the patient may acknowledge unconscious material intellectually while maintaining emotional resista
positions.text: Intellectual knowledge alone accomplishes nothing: the patient may acknowledge unconscious material intellectually while maintaining emotional resistance; cure requires overcoming affective resistances and achieving economic redistribution of libido
positions.work: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVIII: Analytic Therapy (1917)

positions.title: Analysis operates through the lever of transference: by analyzing transference-resistance, the analyst helps the patient recognize and overcome the sa
positions.text: Analysis operates through the lever of transference: by analyzing transference-resistance, the analyst helps the patient recognize and overcome the same patterns of resistance that maintain the neurosis, achieving alteration at the economic level
positions.work: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVIII: Analytic Therapy (1917)

positions.title: The gain from illness (Krankheitsgewinn) creates a major obstacle to treatment: neurotic symptoms provide real advantages - avoiding responsibilities,
positions.text: The gain from illness (Krankheitsgewinn) creates a major obstacle to treatment: neurotic symptoms provide real advantages - avoiding responsibilities, gaining sympathy, maintaining a dependent position - which the patient unconsciously wishes to preserve despite conscious complaints
positions.work: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVIII: Analytic Therapy (1917)

positions.title: Primary gain from illness is the advantage of escaping from internal conflict through symptom-formation; secondary gain comprises all external advanta
positions.text: Primary gain from illness is the advantage of escaping from internal conflict through symptom-formation; secondary gain comprises all external advantages subsequently accruing from being ill - sympathy, reduced expectations, compensation, relief from duties
positions.work: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVIII: Analytic Therapy (1917)

positions.title: When secondary gain from illness is considerable and no real substitute for it is available, the chances of influencing the neurosis by treatment must
positions.text: When secondary gain from illness is considerable and no real substitute for it is available, the chances of influencing the neurosis by treatment must be reckoned very low; external circumstances may make neurosis the only tolerable solution
positions.work: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVIII: Analytic Therapy (1917)

positions.title: The physician must sometimes admit that neurosis represents the most harmless and socially tolerable solution to an insoluble life-situation; not all
positions.text: The physician must sometimes admit that neurosis represents the most harmless and socially tolerable solution to an insoluble life-situation; not all suffering can or should be removed, and the analyst must recognize when neurosis serves a protective function
positions.work: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVIII: Analytic Therapy (1917)

positions.title: Successful analysis requires optimal conditions: not too old (plasticity decreases after fifty), not too young (children lack necessary reflective cap
positions.text: Successful analysis requires optimal conditions: not too old (plasticity decreases after fifty), not too young (children lack necessary reflective capacity), sufficient intelligence, moderate severity of illness (severe cases exhausted by symptoms), stable external circumstances, and adequate time and resources
positions.work: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVIII: Analytic Therapy (1917)

positions.title: Psycho-analysis effects permanent alteration in the economic distribution of psychic forces, producing lasting changes that protect against relapse; u
positions.text: Psycho-analysis effects permanent alteration in the economic distribution of psychic forces, producing lasting changes that protect against relapse; unlike suggestion, which remains foreign to the ego, analytic cure integrates previously repressed material into the ego's organization
positions.work: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVIII: Analytic Therapy (1917)

positions.title: Analysis employs suggestion only in a preliminary way to motivate the patient to work; the essential therapeutic action comes from the patient's own e
positions.text: Analysis employs suggestion only in a preliminary way to motivate the patient to work; the essential therapeutic action comes from the patient's own efforts in overcoming resistances, not from the analyst's authority or suggestions
positions.work: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVIII: Analytic Therapy (1917)

positions.title: The accusation that psycho-analytic findings are artifacts of suggestion is refuted by three facts: analyses produce uniform findings across different
positions.text: The accusation that psycho-analytic findings are artifacts of suggestion is refuted by three facts: analyses produce uniform findings across different analysts and patients, patients regularly resist rather than accept suggestions, and the same unconscious mechanisms are found in non-therapeutic contexts (dreams, parapraxes, folklore)
positions.work: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVIII: Analytic Therapy (1917)

positions.title: Patients who complain most loudly about their illness often offer the most resistance to treatment; this paradox reveals the unconscious secondary gai
positions.text: Patients who complain most loudly about their illness often offer the most resistance to treatment; this paradox reveals the unconscious secondary gains and conflicting motivations that maintain the neurosis despite conscious suffering
positions.work: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVIII: Analytic Therapy (1917)

positions.title: Every neurotic symptom, once established, acquires a secondary function as it becomes integrated into the personality: it establishes a modus vivendi
positions.text: Every neurotic symptom, once established, acquires a secondary function as it becomes integrated into the personality: it establishes a modus vivendi with other mental systems, becomes useful for new purposes, and develops a self-preservative tendency resisting removal
positions.work: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVIII: Analytic Therapy (1917)

positions.title: The ego is not a trustworthy or impartial agency in judging the neurosis: it is the very power that has created repressions and maintains them, so acc
positions.text: The ego is not a trustworthy or impartial agency in judging the neurosis: it is the very power that has created repressions and maintains them, so accepting the ego's account would mean judging the dispute by the victorious party, inevitably leading to error
positions.work: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXV: Anxiety (1917)

positions.title: Traumatic neuroses, particularly war neuroses, demonstrate a self-interested motive on the part of the ego seeking protection and advantage: the ego a
positions.text: Traumatic neuroses, particularly war neuroses, demonstrate a self-interested motive on the part of the ego seeking protection and advantage: the ego assents to the illness and maintains it when recovery would expose it again to the dangers that precipitated the neurosis
positions.work: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXV: Anxiety (1917)

positions.title: The ego makes a bad bargain by accepting the neurosis: though it gains relief from conflict and obtains secondary advantages, it pays too dearly throu
positions.text: The ego makes a bad bargain by accepting the neurosis: though it gains relief from conflict and obtains secondary advantages, it pays too dearly through the suffering attached to symptoms, which often exceed the original conflict's torments
positions.work: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXV: Anxiety (1917)

positions.title: The narcissistic neuroses (dementia praecox, paranoia, melancholia) demonstrate that the ego can become the object of libidinal cathexis: in these con
positions.text: The narcissistic neuroses (dementia praecox, paranoia, melancholia) demonstrate that the ego can become the object of libidinal cathexis: in these conditions, libido withdrawn from the external world and objects is redirected to the ego itself, producing megalomania and loss of reality-testing
positions.work: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVI: Libido Theory and Narcissism (1917)

positions.title: Sleep represents a temporary return to primary narcissism: the sleeper withdraws libidinal cathexes from objects and the external world, concentrating
positions.text: Sleep represents a temporary return to primary narcissism: the sleeper withdraws libidinal cathexes from objects and the external world, concentrating them on the wish to sleep; this narcissistic withdrawal accounts for the hallucinatory character of dreams and the sleeper's indifference to reality
positions.work: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVI: Libido Theory and Narcissism (1917)

positions.title: Physical illness causes a withdrawal of libido from objects back to the ego (hypochondriacal cathexis of the affected organ); during illness, the pati
positions.text: Physical illness causes a withdrawal of libido from objects back to the ego (hypochondriacal cathexis of the affected organ); during illness, the patient becomes narcissistic, withdraws interest from the external world, ceases to love, and concentrates on bodily sensations
positions.work: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVI: Libido Theory and Narcissism (1917)

positions.title: Megalomania is not a new creation but an exaggeration of a state that already existed: it represents magnification of the infantile narcissistic state
positions.text: Megalomania is not a new creation but an exaggeration of a state that already existed: it represents magnification of the infantile narcissistic state, to which the patient regresses by withdrawing libidinal cathexes from objects and reattaching them to the ego
positions.work: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVI: Libido Theory and Narcissism (1917)

positions.title: Being in love involves a flowing-over of ego-libido onto the object: the object is treated as equivalent to one's own ego, impoverishing the ego in fa
positions.text: Being in love involves a flowing-over of ego-libido onto the object: the object is treated as equivalent to one's own ego, impoverishing the ego in favor of the object; at the height of infatuation, the object has consumed the ego, producing a state of devotion and self-sacrifice
positions.work: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVI: Libido Theory and Narcissism (1917)

positions.title: Transference occurs not only in psycho-analysis but in all human relationships: doctors, teachers, and authorities of all kinds regularly receive tran
positions.text: Transference occurs not only in psycho-analysis but in all human relationships: doctors, teachers, and authorities of all kinds regularly receive transferences, and much of their success depends on the positive transferences directed toward them by patients, students, or followers
positions.work: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVII: Transference (1917)

positions.title: Unanalyzed transferences in non-analytic relationships exert unrecognized influence: the patient's compliance with the doctor's orders, the student's
positions.text: Unanalyzed transferences in non-analytic relationships exert unrecognized influence: the patient's compliance with the doctor's orders, the student's admiration of the teacher, the believer's faith in religious leaders all depend on unconscious transferences that remain unexamined
positions.work: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVII: Transference (1917)

positions.title: The unique feature of psycho-analytic technique is that transference, which elsewhere operates unconsciously and unexamined, is deliberately made cons
positions.text: The unique feature of psycho-analytic technique is that transference, which elsewhere operates unconsciously and unexamined, is deliberately made conscious, analyzed, and used as a therapeutic instrument; what in other treatments is a source of suggestion becomes in analysis the subject of investigation
positions.work: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis, Lecture XXVII: Transference (1917)

positions.title: Cuneiform deciphering analogy validates psychoanalytic dream interpretation method
positions.text: Cuneiform deciphering analogy validates psychoanalytic dream interpretation method
positions.work: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis (Dream Methodology Continuation, 1916-1917)

positions.title: Four distinguished decipherors independently verified translations in 1857 proving method validity
positions.text: Four distinguished decipherors independently verified translations in 1857 proving method validity
positions.work: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis (Dream Methodology Continuation, 1916-1917)

positions.title: Forced/artificial interpretations result from displacement by dream censor
positions.text: Forced/artificial interpretations result from displacement by dream censor
positions.work: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis (Dream Methodology Continuation, 1916-1917)

positions.title: Dream censor creates substitute-formations as allusions not easily recognized
positions.text: Dream censor creates substitute-formations as allusions not easily recognized
positions.work: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis (Dream Methodology Continuation, 1916-1917)

positions.title: Concealed objects found in unexpected places like contraband in boot soles
positions.text: Concealed objects found in unexpected places like contraband in boot soles
positions.work: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis (Dream Methodology Continuation, 1916-1917)

positions.title: Remote extraordinary associations between latent and manifest often comical or witty
positions.text: Remote extraordinary associations between latent and manifest often comical or witty
positions.work: Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis (Dream Methodology Continuation, 1916-1917)

positions.title: popular psychologists talk of the splitting of people’s egos, what they are thinking of is this division (in the sphere of ego-psychology) between the
positions.text: popular psychologists talk of the splitting of people’s egos, what they are thinking of is this division (in the sphere of ego-psychology) between the critical agency and the rest of the ego, and not the antithesis discovered by psycho-analysis between the ego and what is unconscious and repressed. It is true that the distinction between these two antitheses is to some extent effaced by the circumstance that foremost among the things that are rejected by the criticism of the ego are derivatives of the repressed.

positions.title: observe what the effect is of meeting one’s own image unbidden and unexpected. Ernst Mach has related two such observations in his Analyse der Empfind
positions.text: observe what the effect is of meeting one’s own image unbidden and unexpected. Ernst Mach has related two such observations in his Analyse der Empfindungen (1900, 3). On the first occasion he was not a little startled when he realized that the face before him was his own.The second time he formed a very unfavourable opinion about the supposed stranger who entered the omnibus, and thought ‘What a shabby-looking school-master that man is who is getting in!’ - I can report a similar adventure. I was sitting alone in my wagon-lit compartment when a more than usually violent jolt of the train swung back the door of the adjoining washing-cabinet, and an elderly gentleman in a dressing-gown and a travelling cap came in. I assumed that in leaving the washing-cabinet, which lay between the two compartments, he had taken the wrong direction and come into my compartment by mistake.

positions.title: Ernst Mach has related two such observations in his Analyse der Empfindungen (1900, 3). On the first occasion he was not a little startled when he rea
positions.text: Ernst Mach has related two such observations in his Analyse der Empfindungen (1900, 3). On the first occasion he was not a little startled when he realized that the face before him was his own.The second time he formed a very unfavourable opinion about the supposed stranger who entered the omnibus, and thought ‘What a shabby-looking school-master that man is who is getting in!’ - I can report a similar adventure. I was sitting alone in my wagon-lit compartment when a more than usually violent jolt of the train swung back the door of the adjoining washing-cabinet, and an elderly gentleman in a dressing-gown and a travelling cap came in. I assumed that in leaving the washing-cabinet, which lay between the two compartments, he had taken the wrong direction and come into my compartment by mistake. Jumping up with the intention of putting him right, I at once realized to my dismay that the intruder was nothing but my own reflection in the looking-glass on the open door.

positions.title: On the first occasion he was not a little startled when he realized that the face before him was his own.The second time he formed a very unfavourable
positions.text: On the first occasion he was not a little startled when he realized that the face before him was his own.The second time he formed a very unfavourable opinion about the supposed stranger who entered the omnibus, and thought ‘What a shabby-looking school-master that man is who is getting in!’ - I can report a similar adventure. I was sitting alone in my wagon-lit compartment when a more than usually violent jolt of the train swung back the door of the adjoining washing-cabinet, and an elderly gentleman in a dressing-gown and a travelling cap came in. I assumed that in leaving the washing-cabinet, which lay between the two compartments, he had taken the wrong direction and come into my compartment by mistake. Jumping up with the intention of putting him right, I at once realized to my dismay that the intruder was nothing but my own reflection in the looking-glass on the open door. I can still recollect that I thoroughly disliked his appearance.

positions.text: I was sitting alone in my wagon-lit compartment when a more than usually violent jolt of the train swung back the door of the adjoining washing-cabinet, and an elderly gentleman in a dressing-gown and a travelling cap came in. I assumed that in leaving the washing-cabinet, which lay between the two compartments, he had taken the wrong direction and come into my compartment by mistake. Jumping up with the intention of putting him right, I at once realized to my dismay that the intruder was nothing but my own reflection in the looking-glass on the open door. I can still recollect that I thoroughly disliked his appearance. Instead, therefore, of being frightened by our ‘doubles’, both Mach and I simply failed to recognize them as such.

positions.title: I assumed that in leaving the washing-cabinet, which lay between the two compartments, he had taken the wrong direction and come into my compartment b
positions.text: I assumed that in leaving the washing-cabinet, which lay between the two compartments, he had taken the wrong direction and come into my compartment by mistake. Jumping up with the intention of putting him right, I at once realized to my dismay that the intruder was nothing but my own reflection in the looking-glass on the open door. I can still recollect that I thoroughly disliked his appearance. Instead, therefore, of being frightened by our ‘doubles’, both Mach and I simply failed to recognize them as such. Is it not possible, though, that our dislike of them was a vestigial trace of the archaic reaction which feels the ‘double’ to be something uncanny?

positions.title: observe what the effect is of meeting one’s own image unbidden and unexpected. Ernst Mach has related two such observations in his Analyse der Empfind
positions.text: observe what the effect is of meeting one’s own image unbidden and unexpected. Ernst Mach has related two such observations in his Analyse der Empfindungen (1900, 3). On the first occasion he was not a little startled when he realized that the face before him was his own.The second time he formed a very unfavourable opinion about the supposed stranger who entered the omnibus, and thought ‘What a shabby-looking school-master that man is who is getting in!’ - I can report a similar adventure. I was sitting alone in my wagon-lit compartment when a more than usually violent jolt of the train swung back the door of the adjoining washing-cabinet, and an elderly gentleman in a dressing-gown and a travelling cap came in. I assumed that in leaving the washing-cabinet, which lay between the two compartments, he had taken the wrong direction and come into my compartment by mistake. Jumping up with the intention of putting him right, I at once realized to my dismay that the intruder was nothing but my own reflection in the looking-glass on the open door. I can still recollect that I thoroughly disliked his appearance. Instead, therefore, of being frightened by our ‘doubles’, both Mach and I simply failed to recognize them as such. Is it not possible, though, that our dislike of them was a vestigial trace of the archaic reaction which feels the ‘double’ to be something uncanny?

positions.title: [Freud also translated one of Putnam’s papers (1910) anonymously and added the following footnote to the translation (Zbl. Psychoan., 1 (1911), 137):
positions.text: [Freud also translated one of Putnam’s papers (1910) anonymously and added the following footnote to the translation (Zbl. Psychoan., 1 (1911), 137): ‘This lecture delivered by the Professor of Neurology at Boston University is offered to our readers as an offset to the many unjust and uncomprehending attacks that are levelled against psycho-analysis, in place of counter-criticisms which might easily lead to embittered feelings. J. Putnam is not only one of the most eminent neurologists in America but also a man everywhere greatly respected for hisunimpeachable character and high moral standards. Although he has left his youth far behind him, he took his open stand last year in the front rank of the champions of psycho-analysis.’]

positions.title: mother had been away for several hours and on her return was met with the words ‘Baby o-o- o-o!’ which was at first incomprehensible. It soon turned o
positions.text: mother had been away for several hours and on her return was met with the words ‘Baby o-o- o-o!’ which was at first incomprehensible. It soon turned out, however, that during this long period of solitude the child had found a method of making himself disappear. He had discovered his reflection in a full-length mirror which did not quite reach to the ground, so that by crouching down he could make his mirror-image ‘gone’.

positions.title: (1912) in an instructive and interesting paper which, however, is unfortunately not entirely clear to me. She there describes the sadistic components
positions.text: (1912) in an instructive and interesting paper which, however, is unfortunately not entirely clear to me. She there describes the sadistic components of the sexual instinct as ‘destructive’. A. Stärke (1914), again, has attempted to identify the concept of libido itself with the biological concept (assumed on theoretical grounds) of an impetus towards death. See also Rank (1907). All these discussions, like that in the text, give evidence of the demand for a clarification of the theory of the instincts such as has not yet been achieved.

positions.title: origin of the Platonic myth, which I give partly in his own words. It is to be remarked that what is essentially the same theory is already to be foun
positions.text: origin of the Platonic myth, which I give partly in his own words. It is to be remarked that what is essentially the same theory is already to be found in the Upanishads. For we find the following passage in the Brihadâranyaka-upanishad, 1, 4, 3, where the origin of the world from the Atman (the Self or Ego) is described: ‘But he felt no delight. Therefore a man who is lonely feels no delight. He wished for a second.

For we find the following passage in the Brihadâranyaka-upanishad, 1, 4, 3, where the origin of the world from the Atman (the Self or Ego) is described: ‘But he felt no delight. Therefore a man who is lonely feels no delight. He wished for a second. He was so large as man and wife together.

positions.title: For we find the following passage in the Brihadâranyaka-upanishad, 1, 4, 3, where the origin of the world from the Atman (the Self or Ego) is describe
positions.text: For we find the following passage in the Brihadâranyaka-upanishad, 1, 4, 3, where the origin of the world from the Atman (the Self or Ego) is described: ‘But he felt no delight. Therefore a man who is lonely feels no delight. He wished for a second. He was so large as man and wife together. He then made this his Self to fall in two, and then arose husband and wife Therefore Yagnavalkya said: "We two are thus (each of us) like half a shell." Therefore the void which was there, is filled by the wife.’ The Brihadâranyaka-upanishad is the most ancient of all the Upanishads and no competent authority dates it later than about the year 800 B.C.

positions.title: Therefore a man who is lonely feels no delight. He wished for a second. He was so large as man and wife together. He then made this his Self to fall i
positions.text: Therefore a man who is lonely feels no delight. He wished for a second. He was so large as man and wife together. He then made this his Self to fall in two, and then arose husband and wife Therefore Yagnavalkya said: "We two are thus (each of us) like half a shell." Therefore the void which was there, is filled by the wife.’ The Brihadâranyaka-upanishad is the most ancient of all the Upanishads and no competent authority dates it later than about the year 800 B.C. In contradiction to the prevailing opinion, I should hesitate to give an unqualified denial to the possibility of Plato’s myth being derived, even if it were only indirectly, from the Indian source, since a similar possibility cannot be excluded in the case of the doctrine of transmigration.

In contradiction to the prevailing opinion, I should hesitate to give an unqualified denial to the possibility of Plato’s myth being derived, even if it were only indirectly, from the Indian source, since a similar possibility cannot be excluded in the case of the doctrine of transmigration. But even if a derivation of this kind (through the Pythagoreans in the first instance) were established, the significance of the coincidence between the two trains of thought would scarcely be diminished.

positions.title: He was so large as man and wife together. He then made this his Self to fall in two, and then arose husband and wife Therefore Yagnavalkya said: "We t
positions.text: He was so large as man and wife together. He then made this his Self to fall in two, and then arose husband and wife Therefore Yagnavalkya said: "We two are thus (each of us) like half a shell." Therefore the void which was there, is filled by the wife.’ The Brihadâranyaka-upanishad is the most ancient of all the Upanishads and no competent authority dates it later than about the year 800 B.C. In contradiction to the prevailing opinion, I should hesitate to give an unqualified denial to the possibility of Plato’s myth being derived, even if it were only indirectly, from the Indian source, since a similar possibility cannot be excluded in the case of the doctrine of transmigration. But even if a derivation of this kind (through the Pythagoreans in the first instance) were established, the significance of the coincidence between the two trains of thought would scarcely be diminished. For Plato would not have adopted a story of this kind which had somehow reached him through some oriental tradition - to say nothing of giving it so important a place - unless it had struck him as containing an element of truth.

In a paper devoted to a systematic examination of this line of thought before the time of Plato, Ziegler (1913) traces it back to Babylonian origins.

positions.title: in the course of the present work. We came to know what the ‘sexual instincts’ were from their relation to the sexes and to the reproductive function.
positions.text: in the course of the present work. We came to know what the ‘sexual instincts’ were from their relation to the sexes and to the reproductive function. We retained this name after we had been obliged by the findings of psycho-analysis to connect them less closely with reproduction. With the hypothesis of narcissistic libido and the extension of the concept of libido to the individual cells, the sexual instinct was transformed for us into Eros, which seeks to force together and hold together the portions of living substance. What are commonly called the sexual instincts are looked upon by us as the part of Eros which is directed towards objects.

positions.title: We came to know what the ‘sexual instincts’ were from their relation to the sexes and to the reproductive function. We retained this name after we had
positions.text: We came to know what the ‘sexual instincts’ were from their relation to the sexes and to the reproductive function. We retained this name after we had been obliged by the findings of psycho-analysis to connect them less closely with reproduction. With the hypothesis of narcissistic libido and the extension of the concept of libido to the individual cells, the sexual instinct was transformed for us into Eros, which seeks to force together and hold together the portions of living substance. What are commonly called the sexual instincts are looked upon by us as the part of Eros which is directed towards objects. Our speculations have suggested that Eros operates from the beginning of life and appears as a ‘life instinct’ in opposition to the ‘death instinct’ which was brought into being by the coming to life of inorganic substance.

With the hypothesis of narcissistic libido and the extension of the concept of libido to the individual cells, the sexual instinct was transformed for us into Eros, which seeks to force together and hold together the portions of living substance. What are commonly called the sexual instincts are looked upon by us as the part of Eros which is directed towards objects. Our speculations have suggested that Eros operates from the beginning of life and appears as a ‘life instinct’ in opposition to the ‘death instinct’ which was brought into being by the coming to life of inorganic substance. These speculations seek to solve the riddle of life by supposing that these two instincts were struggling with each other from the very first.

It is not so easy, perhaps, to follow the transformations though which the concept of the ‘ego-instincts’ has passed.

positions.text: What are commonly called the sexual instincts are looked upon by us as the part of Eros which is directed towards objects. Our speculations have suggested that Eros operates from the beginning of life and appears as a ‘life instinct’ in opposition to the ‘death instinct’ which was brought into being by the coming to life of inorganic substance. These speculations seek to solve the riddle of life by supposing that these two instincts were struggling with each other from the very first. It is not so easy, perhaps, to follow the transformations though which the concept of the ‘ego-instincts’ has passed. To begin with we applied that name to all the instinctual trends (of which we had no closer knowledge) which could be distinguished from the sexual instincts directed towards an object; and we opposed the ego-instincts to the sexual instincts of which the libido is the manifestation.

positions.title: Our speculations have suggested that Eros operates from the beginning of life and appears as a ‘life instinct’ in opposition to the ‘death instinct’ w
positions.text: Our speculations have suggested that Eros operates from the beginning of life and appears as a ‘life instinct’ in opposition to the ‘death instinct’ which was brought into being by the coming to life of inorganic substance. These speculations seek to solve the riddle of life by supposing that these two instincts were struggling with each other from the very first. It is not so easy, perhaps, to follow the transformations though which the concept of the ‘ego-instincts’ has passed. To begin with we applied that name to all the instinctual trends (of which we had no closer knowledge) which could be distinguished from the sexual instincts directed towards an object; and we opposed the ego-instincts to the sexual instincts of which the libido is the manifestation. Subsequently we came to closer grips with the analysis of the ego and recognized that a portion of the ‘ego-instincts’ is also of a libidinal character and has taken the subject’s own ego as its object.

It is not so easy, perhaps, to follow the transformations though which the concept of the ‘ego-instincts’ has passed. To begin with we applied that name to all the instinctual trends (of which we had no closer knowledge) which could be distinguished from the sexual instincts directed towards an object; and we opposed the ego-instincts to the sexual instincts of which the libido is the manifestation. Subsequently we came to closer grips with the analysis of the ego and recognized that a portion of the ‘ego-instincts’ is also of a libidinal character and has taken the subject’s own ego as its object. These narcissistic self-preservative instincts had thenceforward to be counted among the libidinal sexual instincts.

positions.text: It is not so easy, perhaps, to follow the transformations though which the concept of the ‘ego-instincts’ has passed. To begin with we applied that name to all the instinctual trends (of which we had no closer knowledge) which could be distinguished from the sexual instincts directed towards an object; and we opposed the ego-instincts to the sexual instincts of which the libido is the manifestation. Subsequently we came to closer grips with the analysis of the ego and recognized that a portion of the ‘ego-instincts’ is also of a libidinal character and has taken the subject’s own ego as its object. These narcissistic self-preservative instincts had thenceforward to be counted among the libidinal sexual instincts. The opposition between the ego-instincts and the sexual instincts was transformed into one between the ego-instincts and the object-instincts, both of a libidinal nature.

positions.title: To begin with we applied that name to all the instinctual trends (of which we had no closer knowledge) which could be distinguished from the sexual in
positions.text: To begin with we applied that name to all the instinctual trends (of which we had no closer knowledge) which could be distinguished from the sexual instincts directed towards an object; and we opposed the ego-instincts to the sexual instincts of which the libido is the manifestation. Subsequently we came to closer grips with the analysis of the ego and recognized that a portion of the ‘ego-instincts’ is also of a libidinal character and has taken the subject’s own ego as its object. These narcissistic self-preservative instincts had thenceforward to be counted among the libidinal sexual instincts. The opposition between the ego-instincts and the sexual instincts was transformed into one between the ego-instincts and the object-instincts, both of a libidinal nature. But in its place a fresh opposition appeared between the libidinal (ego- and object-) instincts and others, which must be presumed to be present in the ego and which may perhaps actually be observed in the destructive instincts.

positions.text: With the hypothesis of narcissistic libido and the extension of the concept of libido to the individual cells, the sexual instinct was transformed for us into Eros, which seeks to force together and hold together the portions of living substance. What are commonly called the sexual instincts are looked upon by us as the part of Eros which is directed towards objects. Our speculations have suggested that Eros operates from the beginning of life and appears as a ‘life instinct’ in opposition to the ‘death instinct’ which was brought into being by the coming to life of inorganic substance. These speculations seek to solve the riddle of life by supposing that these two instincts were struggling with each other from the very first. It is not so easy, perhaps, to follow the transformations though which the concept of the ‘ego-instincts’ has passed. To begin with we applied that name to all the instinctual trends (of which we had no closer knowledge) which could be distinguished from the sexual instincts directed towards an object; and we opposed the ego-instincts to the sexual instincts of which the libido is the manifestation. Subsequently we came to closer grips with the analysis of the ego and recognized that a portion of the ‘ego-instincts’ is also of a libidinal character and has taken the subject’s own ego as its object. These narcissistic self-preservative instincts had thenceforward to be counted among the libidinal sexual instincts. The opposition between the ego-instincts and the sexual instincts was transformed into one between the ego-instincts and the object-instincts, both of a libidinal nature. But in its place a fresh opposition appeared between the libidinal (ego- and object-) instincts and others, which must be presumed to be present in the ego and which may perhaps actually be observed in the destructive instincts.

positions.text: in the course of the present work. We came to know what the ‘sexual instincts’ were from their relation to the sexes and to the reproductive function. We retained this name after we had been obliged by the findings of psycho-analysis to connect them less closely with reproduction. With the hypothesis of narcissistic libido and the extension of the concept of libido to the individual cells, the sexual instinct was transformed for us into Eros, which seeks to force together and hold together the portions of living substance. What are commonly called the sexual instincts are looked upon by us as the part of Eros which is directed towards objects. Our speculations have suggested that Eros operates from the beginning of life and appears as a ‘life instinct’ in opposition to the ‘death instinct’ which was brought into being by the coming to life of inorganic substance. These speculations seek to solve the riddle of life by supposing that these two instincts were struggling with each other from the very first. It is not so easy, perhaps, to follow the transformations though which the concept of the ‘ego-instincts’ has passed. To begin with we applied that name to all the instinctual trends (of which we had no closer knowledge) which could be distinguished from the sexual instincts directed towards an object; and we opposed the ego-instincts to the sexual instincts of which the libido is the manifestation. Subsequently we came to closer grips with the analysis of the ego and recognized that a portion of the ‘ego-instincts’ is also of a libidinal character and has taken the subject’s own ego as its object. These narcissistic self-preservative instincts had thenceforward to be counted among the libidinal sexual instincts. Our speculations have transformed this opposition into one between the life instincts (Eros) and the death instincts.

positions.title: unconscious not quite coinciding with the one adopted by psycho-analysis. Le Bon’s unconscious more especially contains the most deeply buried feature
positions.text: unconscious not quite coinciding with the one adopted by psycho-analysis. Le Bon’s unconscious more especially contains the most deeply buried features of the racial mind, which as a matter of fact lies outside the scope of psycho-analysis. We do not fail to recognize, indeed, that the ego’s nucleus, which comprises the ‘archaic heritage’ of the human mind, is unconscious; but in addition to this we distinguish the ‘unconscious repressed’, which arose from a portion of that heritage. This concept of the repressed is not to be found in Le Bon.
positions.work: Group Psychology And The Analysis Of The Ego

positions.title: unconscious mental life, we follow a technical rule of disregarding doubt and uncertainty in the narrative of the dream, and of treating every element
positions.text: unconscious mental life, we follow a technical rule of disregarding doubt and uncertainty in the narrative of the dream, and of treating every element of the manifest dream as being quite certain. We attribute doubt and uncertainty to the influence of the censorship to which the dream-work is subjected, and we assume that the primary dream-thoughts are not acquainted with doubt and uncertainty as critical processes. They may of course be present, like anything else, as part of the content of the day’s residues which lead to the dream.
positions.work: Group Psychology And The Analysis Of The Ego

positions.title: the affective life of children, and it is present as well in dream life. Thanks to the isolation of the single emotions in the unconscious, a slight a
positions.text: the affective life of children, and it is present as well in dream life. Thanks to the isolation of the single emotions in the unconscious, a slight annoyance during the day will express itself ina dream as a wish for the offending person’s death, or a breath of temptation may give the impetus to the portrayal in the dream of a criminal action. Hanns Sachs has made an appropriate remark on this point: ‘If we look in our consciousness at something that has been told us by a dream about a contemporary (real) situation, we ought not to be surprised to find that the monster which we saw under the magnifying glass of analysis turns out to be a tiny

positions.title: nearest to them exist side by side for a long time, without either of them interfering with the expression of the other and opposite one. If eventuall
positions.text: nearest to them exist side by side for a long time, without either of them interfering with the expression of the other and opposite one. If eventually a conflict breaks out between the two, it is often settled by the child making a change of object and displacing one of the ambivalent emotions on to a substitute. The history of the development of a neurosis in an adult will also show that a suppressed emotion may frequently persist for a long time in unconscious or even in conscious phantasies, the content of which naturally runs directly counter to some predominant tendency, and yet that this opposition does not result in any proceedings on the part of the ego against what it has repudiated. The phantasy is tolerated for quite a long time,until suddenly one day, usually as a result of an increase in the affective cathexis of the phantasy, a conflict breaks out between it and the ego with all the usual consequences. In the process of a child’s development into a mature adult there is a more and more extensive integration of his personality, a co-ordination of the separate instinctual impulses and purposive trends which have grown up in him independently of one another.
positions.work: Group Psychology And The Analysis Of The Ego

positions.title: If eventually a conflict breaks out between the two, it is often settled by the child making a change of object and displacing one of the ambivalent e
positions.text: If eventually a conflict breaks out between the two, it is often settled by the child making a change of object and displacing one of the ambivalent emotions on to a substitute. The history of the development of a neurosis in an adult will also show that a suppressed emotion may frequently persist for a long time in unconscious or even in conscious phantasies, the content of which naturally runs directly counter to some predominant tendency, and yet that this opposition does not result in any proceedings on the part of the ego against what it has repudiated. The phantasy is tolerated for quite a long time,until suddenly one day, usually as a result of an increase in the affective cathexis of the phantasy, a conflict breaks out between it and the ego with all the usual consequences. In the process of a child’s development into a mature adult there is a more and more extensive integration of his personality, a co-ordination of the separate instinctual impulses and purposive trends which have grown up in him independently of one another. The analogous process in the domain of sexual life has long been known to us as the co-ordination of all the sexual instincts into a definitive genital organization. (Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality, 1905d.) Moreover, that the unification of the ego is liable to the same interferences as that of the libido is shown by numerous familiar instances, such as that of men of science who have preserved their faith in the Bible, and other similar cases. - The various possible ways in which the ego can later disintegrate form a special chapter in psychopathology.
positions.work: Group Psychology And The Analysis Of The Ego

positions.title: so as to profit by one another’s warmth and so save themselves from being frozen to death. But soon they felt one another’s quills, which induced them
positions.text: so as to profit by one another’s warmth and so save themselves from being frozen to death. But soon they felt one another’s quills, which induced them to separate again. And now, when the need for warmth brought them nearer together again, the second evil arose once more. So that they were driven backwards and forwards from one trouble to the other, until they had discovered a mean distance at which they could most tolerably exist.’ (Parerga und Paralipomena, Part II, 31, ‘Gleichnisse und Parabeln’.)

positions.title: examples taken from pathology, and that we have consequently left part of the riddle of group formations untouched. A far more fundamental and compreh
positions.text: examples taken from pathology, and that we have consequently left part of the riddle of group formations untouched. A far more fundamental and comprehensive psychological analysis would have to intervene at this point. A path leads from identification by way of imitation to empathy, that is, to the comprehension of the mechanism by means of which we are enabled to take up any attitude at all towards another mental life. Moreover there is still much to be explained in the manifestations of existing identifications. These result among other things in a person limiting his aggressiveness towards those with whom he has identified himself, and in his sparing them and giving them help.
positions.work: Group Psychology And The Analysis Of The Ego

positions.title: A far more fundamental and comprehensive psychological analysis would have to intervene at this point. A path leads from identification by way of imit
positions.text: A far more fundamental and comprehensive psychological analysis would have to intervene at this point. A path leads from identification by way of imitation to empathy, that is, to the comprehension of the mechanism by means of which we are enabled to take up any attitude at all towards another mental life. Moreover there is still much to be explained in the manifestations of existing identifications. These result among other things in a person limiting his aggressiveness towards those with whom he has identified himself, and in his sparing them and giving them help. The study of such identifications, like those, for instance which lie at the root of clan feeling, led Robertson Smith (Kinship and Marriage, 1885) to the surprising discovery that they rest upon the acknowledgement of the possession of a common substance, and may even therefore be created by a meal eaten in common.
positions.work: Group Psychology And The Analysis Of The Ego

This feature makes it possible to connect this kind of identification with the early history of the human family which I constructed in Totem and Taboo.

positions.title: especially to the primal horde. The will of the individual was too weak; he did not venture upon action. No impulses whatever came into existence exce
positions.text: especially to the primal horde. The will of the individual was too weak; he did not venture upon action. No impulses whatever came into existence except collective ones; there was only a common will, there were no single ones. An idea did not dare to turn itself into an act of will unless it felt itself reinforced by a perception of its general diffusion. This weakness of the idea is to be explained by the strength of the emotional tie which is shared by all the members of the horde; but the similarity in the circumstances of their life and the absence of any private property assist in determining the uniformity of their individual mental acts.
positions.work: Group Psychology And The Analysis Of The Ego

positions.text: The will of the individual was too weak; he did not venture upon action. No impulses whatever came into existence except collective ones; there was only a common will, there were no single ones. An idea did not dare to turn itself into an act of will unless it felt itself reinforced by a perception of its general diffusion. This weakness of the idea is to be explained by the strength of the emotional tie which is shared by all the members of the horde; but the similarity in the circumstances of their life and the absence of any private property assist in determining the uniformity of their individual mental acts. As we may observe with children and soldiers, common activity is not excluded even in the excretory functions.

positions.text: No impulses whatever came into existence except collective ones; there was only a common will, there were no single ones. An idea did not dare to turn itself into an act of will unless it felt itself reinforced by a perception of its general diffusion. This weakness of the idea is to be explained by the strength of the emotional tie which is shared by all the members of the horde; but the similarity in the circumstances of their life and the absence of any private property assist in determining the uniformity of their individual mental acts. As we may observe with children and soldiers, common activity is not excluded even in the excretory functions. The one great exception is provided by the sexual act, in which a third person is at best superfluous and in the extreme case is condemned to a state of painful expectancy.

positions.title: hypnotist, while he is consciously occupied with monotonous and uninteresting perceptions, finds a parallel among the events of psycho-analytic treatm
positions.text: hypnotist, while he is consciously occupied with monotonous and uninteresting perceptions, finds a parallel among the events of psycho-analytic treatment, which deserves to be mentioned here. At least once in the course of every analysis a moment comes when the patient obstinately maintains that just now positively nothing whatever occurs to his mind. His free associations come to a stop and the usual incentives for putting them in motion fail in their effect. If the analyst insists, the patient is at last induced to admit that he is thinking of the view from the consulting-room window, of the wall-paper that he sees before him, or of the gas-lamp hanging from the ceiling. Then one knows at once that he has gone off into the transference and that he is engaged upon what are still unconscious thoughts relating to the physician; and one sees the stoppage in the patient’s associations disappear, as soon as he has been given this explanation.
positions.work: Group Psychology And The Analysis Of The Ego

positions.title: induced us to give up Bernheim’s conception of hypnosis and go back to the naïf earlier one. According to Bernheim all hypnotic phenomena are to be tr
positions.text: induced us to give up Bernheim’s conception of hypnosis and go back to the naïf earlier one. According to Bernheim all hypnotic phenomena are to be traced to the factor of suggestion, which is not itself capable of further explanation. We have come to the conclusion that suggestion is a partial manifestation of the state of hypnosis, and that hypnosis is solidly founded upon a predisposition which has survived in the unconscious from the early history of the human family.
positions.work: Group Psychology And The Analysis Of The Ego

positions.title: from investigation of the anamneses of neurotics. With the latter, however, they occur in early childhood, at the time of the early efflorescence of e
positions.text: from investigation of the anamneses of neurotics. With the latter, however, they occur in early childhood, at the time of the early efflorescence of erotic life; with our patient, who was in no way neurotic, they took place in the first years following puberty, though, incidentally, they were just as completely unconscious. Perhaps one day this temporal factor may turn out to be of great importance.
positions.work: Group Psychology And The Analysis Of The Ego

positions.title: causes of homosexuality, or in the mechanism of libidinal fixation in general, I will adduce here another analytic observation of the same kind which
positions.text: causes of homosexuality, or in the mechanism of libidinal fixation in general, I will adduce here another analytic observation of the same kind which has a special feature of interest. I once knew two twin brothers, both of whom were endowed with strong libidinal impulses. One of them was very successful with women, and had innumerable affairs with women and girls. The other went the same way at first, but it became unpleasant for him to be trespassing on his brother’s preserves, and, owing to the likeness between them, to be mistaken for him on intimate occasions; so he got out of the difficulty by becoming homosexual. He left the women to his brother, and thus retired in his favour.
positions.work: Group Psychology And The Analysis Of The Ego

positions.title: I once knew two twin brothers, both of whom were endowed with strong libidinal impulses. One of them was very successful with women, and had innumerab
positions.text: I once knew two twin brothers, both of whom were endowed with strong libidinal impulses. One of them was very successful with women, and had innumerable affairs with women and girls. The other went the same way at first, but it became unpleasant for him to be trespassing on his brother’s preserves, and, owing to the likeness between them, to be mistaken for him on intimate occasions; so he got out of the difficulty by becoming homosexual. He left the women to his brother, and thus retired in his favour. Another time I treated a youngish man, an artist, unmistakably bisexual in disposition, in whom the homosexual trend had come to the fore simultaneously with a disturbance in his work.
positions.work: Group Psychology And The Analysis Of The Ego

positions.title: causes of homosexuality, or in the mechanism of libidinal fixation in general, I will adduce here another analytic observation of the same kind which
positions.text: causes of homosexuality, or in the mechanism of libidinal fixation in general, I will adduce here another analytic observation of the same kind which has a special feature of interest. I once knew two twin brothers, both of whom were endowed with strong libidinal impulses. One of them was very successful with women, and had innumerable affairs with women and girls. The other went the same way at first, but it became unpleasant for him to be trespassing on his brother’s preserves, and, owing to the likeness between them, to be mistaken for him on intimate occasions; so he got out of the difficulty by becoming homosexual. He left the women to his brother, and thus retired in his favour. Another time I treated a youngish man, an artist, unmistakably bisexual in disposition, in whom the homosexual trend had come to the fore simultaneously with a disturbance in his work. He fled from both women and work together. The analysis, which was able to bring him back to both, showed that fear of his father was the most powerful psychical motive for both the disturbances, which were really renunciations. In his imagination all women belonged to his father, and he sought refuge in men out of submission, so as to retire from the conflict with his father. Such a motivation of the homosexual object-choice must be by no means uncommon; in the primaeval ages of the human race all women presumably belonged to the father and head of the primal horde.
positions.work: Group Psychology And The Analysis Of The Ego

positions.title: The Unconscious Mind
positions.text: Freud posited that the unconscious mind plays a crucial role in influencing thoughts, feelings, and behaviors, often without the individual's awareness. This hidden part of the psyche contains repressed memories and desires that can manifest in dreams and symptoms of neurosis.

positions.title: Dreams as Wish Fulfillment
positions.text: Freud argued that dreams serve as a form of wish fulfillment, allowing individuals to express desires that are otherwise suppressed in waking life. He believed that analyzing dreams could reveal underlying conflicts and desires, providing insight into the unconscious.

positions.title: Psychosexual Development Stages
positions.text: Freud introduced the concept of psychosexual development, suggesting that personality develops through a series of stages centered on erogenous zones. Each stage, from oral to genital, plays a critical role in shaping adult personality and behavior.

positions.title: Defense Mechanisms
positions.text: Freud identified various defense mechanisms that the ego employs to protect itself from anxiety and conflict. These mechanisms, such as repression, denial, and projection, help individuals cope with internal and external stressors by distorting reality.

positions.title: Oedipus Complex
positions.text: Freud proposed the Oedipus complex as a central element of his theory of psychosexual development, where a child experiences unconscious desires for the opposite-sex parent and rivalry with the same-sex parent. This complex is pivotal in forming the child's identity and moral framework.

positions.title: The Role of the Unconscious
positions.text: Freud posits that the unconscious mind plays a crucial role in shaping human behavior and experiences. It contains repressed thoughts and desires that influence our actions and emotions, often without our conscious awareness.

positions.title: Dreams as Wish Fulfillment
positions.text: Freud argues that dreams serve as a form of wish fulfillment, allowing individuals to express desires that are repressed in waking life. This perspective emphasizes the significance of dreams in understanding the unconscious mind.

positions.title: Psychosexual Development Stages
positions.text: Freud's theory of psychosexual development outlines stages through which a child's personality develops. Each stage is characterized by the erogenous focus of the libido, and unresolved conflicts can lead to neuroses in adulthood.

positions.title: Defense Mechanisms
positions.text: Freud identifies various defense mechanisms that the ego employs to manage anxiety and protect the individual from psychological distress. These mechanisms, such as repression and projection, are essential for maintaining mental health.

positions.title: The Oedipus Complex
positions.text: Freud introduces the Oedipus complex as a central concept in his theory of psychosexual development, suggesting that children experience unconscious desires for the opposite-sex parent and rivalry with the same-sex parent, which shapes their future relationships.

positions.title: Hysteria and Memory
positions.text: Hysterics suffer mainly from reminiscences. The determining process continues to operate in some way or other for years, not indirectly, but as a directly releasing cause. This suggests that traumatic memories can have lasting effects on psychological well-being, indicating that unresolved past experiences can manifest as symptoms in the present.

positions.title: Therapeutic Suggestion
positions.text: By taking the patient back to the moment at which the symptom first appeared, we may make him more susceptible to a therapeutic suggestion. This implies that revisiting the origin of psychological symptoms can enhance the effectiveness of therapeutic interventions.

positions.title: Role of Unconscious Processes
positions.text: It is plausible to suppose that it is a question here of unconscious suggestion: the patient expects to be relieved of his sufferings by this procedure. This highlights the importance of unconscious processes in shaping expectations and responses to treatment.

positions.title: Memory Persistence
positions.text: It seems extraordinary that events experienced so long ago should continue to operate so intensely. The fading of a memory or the losing of its affect depends on various factors, particularly the energetic reaction to the event. This suggests that the emotional intensity of memories can affect their longevity and impact.

positions.title: Auto-Hypnosis in Treatment
positions.text: Spontaneous auto-hypnoses on the part of the patient were observed to facilitate the analysis of hysteria. This indicates that self-induced altered states of consciousness can play a significant role in therapeutic processes.

positions.title: Childhood Trauma's Role in Psychopathology
positions.text: The mention of this sexual trauma in the patient’s childhood revealed not only the origin of her first obsessions but also the trauma which subsequently produced the pathogenic effects.

positions.title: Disconnection in Reminiscences
positions.text: The apparently disconnected reminiscences are closely linked in thought and that they lead quite straight to the pathogenic factor we are looking for.

positions.title: Physical Symptoms as Psychological Manifestations
positions.text: The pain I had then passed off after the treatment you recommended, and it stayed away for a long time; but now it has come back in a nervous form.

positions.title: Pressure Techniques in Therapy
positions.text: When I asked her, in concentration and under the pressure of my hand, whether anything occurred to her or whether she saw anything, she decided in favour of seeing and began to describe her visual pictures.

positions.title: Symbolism in Visual Experiences
positions.text: She saw something like a sun with rays, which I naturally took to be a phosphene, produced by pressure on the eyes.

positions.title: Resistance in Psychotherapy
positions.text: Psychical resistance, especially one that has been in force for a long time, can only be resolved slowly and by degrees. We must wait patiently and utilize the intellectual interest that the patient begins to feel after working for a short time. By explaining things and giving information about psychical processes, we can make the patient a collaborator and push back their resistance.

positions.title: Role of the Therapist
positions.text: The therapist acts as an elucidator, teacher, and father confessor, providing human assistance and support. This requires understanding the nature of the case and the motives of the patient's defense. The therapist's capacity for sympathy and respect is crucial in facilitating the patient's progress.

positions.title: Emergence of Pathogenic Recollections
positions.text: Pathogenic recollections often emerge in a fragmented manner, where patients may initially see only parts of memories or figures. It may take time for them to recognize themselves or significant others in these recollections, indicating the complex nature of memory and self-recognition in the therapeutic process.

positions.title: Intellectual Interest in Analysis
positions.text: As patients engage in analysis, they begin to develop an intellectual interest in their psychical processes. This interest can help reduce resistance and facilitate deeper exploration of their thoughts and memories, highlighting the importance of cognitive engagement in therapy.

positions.title: Value of Defense Mechanisms
positions.text: Understanding the motives behind a patient's defense mechanisms is essential for effective therapy. By recognizing and addressing these defenses, therapists can work to diminish their value and replace them with more constructive ones, aiding in the patient's healing process.
